story:
“I would rather stay here and eat salad than go to recess.”

-- Battery Urban Student Farmer, 3rd Grade

Here's what you need to know about Battery Urban Farm, and why we need your help:

First, watch the video above, and see why we are more fun than recess. Battery Urban Farm is a one-acre educational community farm located in The Battery, one of New York City’s most famous and beloved parks. We teach children how to grow and eat healthy food, and provide a thriving public farm to the 6 million visitors, residents, and commuters who pass through our park every year.

Battery Urban Farm Staff teach free and suggested-donation classes to thousands of students from all over New York City. In order to keep our programs running, we need support from YOU – our community, our city, and anyone who believes in the power of knowing where our food comes from.

Support from our community became even more crucial last fall when Superstorm Sandy hit - our offices were completely destroyed, our farm flooded.   

We have worked hard through the winter to rebuild and recover, but now we need some help. We are calling on all of you to support Battery Urban Farm and help keep us growing veggies and growing farmers. Here's how far we've already come:

  • In our first year, 2011, we taught 870 students from 11 different schools 
  • In 2012, those numbers doubled: 1,800 students from 30 schools visited, learned, and tasted from the farm
  • It’s early in 2013, and already we have requests for 1,500 students from 23 schools to come learn with us

WHAT WILL OUR NUMBERS BE IN 2013? This is up to you.

Support Battery Urban Farm and you ensure that we can say YES to every child and every request that comes our way.

As you can see from the numbers above, we receive a lot of requests, in part because we are fortunate enough to have our farm located in one of the most heavily trafficked areas in NYC, with 6 million visitors annually from across the globe. With your help in 2013, we will continue to thrive and show the world what’s possible when you combine an acre of land, an inspired community, and a whole lot of hard work.

The Battery Conservancy and Battery Urban Farm rely on the support from our generous donors to keep our programs running, and that need has grown even more since Superstorm Sandy. Help Battery Urban Farm meet our goal of $15,000 and 200 gifts in the next 40 days.

What your donation does:

  • Ensures the continuation of our program despite the tremendous damage to our organization during Superstorm Sandy;
  • Helps us continue to offer all our programs for free or a small suggested donation;
  • Supports the salaries of the four dedicated staff members who made the dream of Battery Urban Farm a reality.

The kinds of things your donation will pay for:

  • $25: New worms for our vermicompost system that was flooded in Superstorm Sandy
  • $50: Pantry items for making salads and smoothies on the farm
  • $100: A children’s bike to use with our bike blender for on-farm food prep
  • $500: A Farm Share for a local family unable to afford a donation
  • $1000: A year long share of vegetables for a school cafeteria that cannot afford a donation

Can’t donate? Here’s how else you can help!

  • Share this campaign with your friends and family via e-mail, Facebook, Twitter, carrier pigeon, or word of mouth!
  • Write a blog post about us!
  • Come to volunteer at the farm every Wednesday from 4pm-6pm and help us rebuild!

 

THE STORY of BATTERY URBAN FARM

The Battery Conservancy was created in 1994 to rebuild and revitalize The Battery and Castle Clinton National Monument. The Battery remains one of the oldest public open spaces in continuous use in New York City. The Conservancy honors and preserves this heritage by rebuilding the park’s landscape to interpret its past. The new landscape also celebrates the natural environment while meeting the needs of a growing residential population, crowds of bustling commuters and workers, and the millions of visitors who come from all over the world to see the Statue of Liberty, the magnificent harbor, and New York’s many cultural destinations.


In 2011, The Battery Conservancy received an intriguing request: Eight students from a local high school wanted to grow vegetables in the park. The Battery Conservancy saw an oppurtunity to take advantage of our highly visible location by building an interactive, productive and educational farm that had the potential to create real change in our community. So instead of saying YES to just eight students, we called every school in Lower Manhattan and invited them to come join us in building a farm right in the Financial District.

Though we only intended to run the farm for one year, the tremendous support from our community convinced us that the farm had to stay. Two years later, we have educated thousands of children and adults.

 

 2011

 2012

 2013

 870 student farmers

 1800 student farmers

 1500 (So far…)

 11 schools and camp groups

 30 schools and camp groups

 23 (So far…)

 350 volunteers

 650 volunteers

 1100 (So far…)

 

Our Mission

Here at Battery Urban Farm, our goals are to educate youth and the public on growing and eating healthy food. Here’s how:

Healthy People: Empower NYC children and community to make healthier eating choices through farm-based education.

Healthy Community: Inspire and encourage the creation of edible gardens in communities throughout NYC and globally.

Healthy Planet: Cultivate a broader awareness of sustainability through sustainable farming practices and responsible waste management.

Growing Farmers

Battery Urban Farm works with schools all over New York City on a variety of educational programs, all of which are free or ask for a suggested donation. No one is ever turned away because they cannot pay. We provide a wide array of programs for the diverse needs of our community, so teachers, parents, students and neighbors can all find something for them at Battery Urban Farm. Our programs include:

  • Farm Educator Led Classes
  • Teacher Led Classes ­­
  • Enrichment Visits
  • City Seedlings Summer Program
  • Weekly Open Volunteer Hours for Adults
  • BUF Saturdays (Volunteering, Farm Stand and Workshop Series)
  • Free Community Events such as EARTH FEST and Harvest Festival

(For more information on our programs, please visit our website)

Growing Food

Though our main focus at Battery Urban Farm is education, one way in which we are different from many other educational farms is that we are a highly productive growing space.  Battery Urban Farm focuses on growing for production and education, because we want the public to see how much food can be grown on just an acre of land. We also feel it is important that our students' farm work is modeled on real production-oriented farming practices, in order to teach them the value of hard work, patience, and cooperation.

The thousands of pounds of veggies, herbs and flowers we grow each year have three main destinations:

  • School Cafeterias: First and foremost, produce is donated to our school cafeterias through the Garden to School Café Program
  • Farm Share: Members of our community join our summer farm share (like a CSA!) and receive a bounty of fresh seasonal vegetables, herbs and flowers when school is not in session.
  • Restaurants and Soup Kitchens: These receive all excess produce that our schools or CSA members do not need/want, to ensure that no food ever goes to waste.

SAMPLE SEASONAL FARM SHARE

Week of June 5: Carrots, Red Ace Beets, French Breakfast Radishes, Harukei Turnips, Lacinato Kale, Spring Lettuce Mix, Spinach, Peas, Garlic, Rosemary, Chocolate Mint

Week of July 25: Swiss Chard, Spicy Greens Mix, Golden Beets, Cucumbers, Zucchini, Okra,  Popcorn, Heirloom and Cherry Tomatoes, Eggplant, Hot and Sweet Peppers, Edamame, Green Beans, Squash Blossoms, Ground Cherries, Sweet Basil,  Lemongrass, Cilantro, Sunflowers

Week of September 15: Sweet Potatoes, Carrots, Chiogga Beets, Broccoli, Fingerling Potatoes,  Hakurei Turnips, Cabbage, Winterbor Kale, Onions, Pea Shoots, Spinach, Head Lettuce, Mixed Greens, Swiss Chard, Collard Greens, Sage, Zinnias

 

WHY WE DO WHAT WE DO

Too many children have little or no idea how the food choices they make every day (including how the food was grown, processed, transported and prepared) affect both their health and that of our environment. Largely as a result of this disconnect, rising obesity rates among our nation’s youth have hit alarming levels. In New York City, many families are without access to fresh fruit or vegetables, as they live in “food deserts” where there are no grocery stores or farmers markets, only delis and bodegas which sell mostly highly processed foods.

In the two years since we opened, Battery Urban Farm Staff have noticed that many of our students do not understand that most of what they eat comes from a plant that was once growing on a farm. Battery Urban Farm works to help students find the connection between farming and eating, so they understand that without farms, there would be no food. We often have students guess that their pizza came from a “pizza factory,” as they do not realize that the cheese, tomatoes and flour they are eating all came from farms. They often remark that mint tastes like gum, and are surprised and delighted that the popcorn we grow on the farm could be microwaved just like the popcorn they eat at home in front of the TV.



Change that Parents and Teachers Can See

Children are notoriously finicky eaters, frequently refusing to even try new foods. And yet come harvest time, all it takes is a few weeks of tending a row of sweet little turnips and one brave, enthusiastic classmate to encourage thirty first-graders to go from “yuck!” to “Can I have seconds?” We’ve witnessed it firsthand. Ask anyone involved in gardening with kids, and they’ll tell you what we see at Battery Urban Farm almost every day: that if kids grow it, they’re more willing to eat it.

“Olivia LOVED the gardening class. She NEVER eats veggies, but she was actually munching on Swiss Chard at the farm!!  The day she brought home the tomatoes and cucumbers, she was so excited and called me at work to ask me to buy lettuce, carrots and celery so that she could chop up what she had brought home and make a salad.”

-- Battery Urban Farm Parent

 

 

And that's just the beginning. Battery Urban Farm is encouraging students to learn not just on the farm, but beyond. Children in New York City are not only often without access to fresh fruits and vegetables, but they rarely have the opportunity to explore the natural world. Many of our students have recess in their cafeterias, and some of them have never seen worms before. By giving students the opportunity to engage with flowers, plants and insects, we allow them to exercise the natural curiosity that every child enjoys.

“Nadia has been watering the trees in the playgrounds [since joining the City Seedlings summer program] - she fills up her bucket with water from the sprinklers!”

-- Battery Urban Farm Parent                                                                       

“It was a rewarding experience when [after weeding chickweed during a farm lesson] we were on another field trip at a solar estuary and some of the kids started weeding – my group of students discovered a gardener pulling chickweed and insisted on doing it for him!”

-- First Grade Teacher

 

Additionally, teachers often share stories of how students that may not excel in a classroom setting shine on the farm. Other teachers report that students are more responsible and respectful with their classmates during and after farm visits. 

“The experience of bringing students to the farm has been invaluable. There is something very powerful working in the space- as I have observed students collaborating and sharing in ways in which they haven’t in the classroom.”

-- Therapy on the Farm, Teacher

Giving Kids the Tools

The skills and concepts students learn on the farm are not limited to the farm sphere. Battery Urban Farm is an outdoor classroom that reinforces and enlivens concepts learned in school with farm-based projects, exercises and vocabulary that bloom into a broader, interconnected web of knowledge. Our lessons incorporate Math, Science, Art, History and English, so that the experiential education on the farm is interdisciplinary. In order to ensure that our curriculum is reinforcing concepts from the classroom, we make sure all our lessons correspond to NY State CORE curriculum standards.

For example: Lessons on food miles encourage kids to think about what their breakfast is made of, calculate how far it traveled, and how much energy it took to fuel that trip based on the method of transport. An introduction to the history of The Battery and traditional Dutch and Lenape farming methods encourages students to think about the history of the land and the many cultures who have farmed here before us.

 

At Battery Urban Farm, Kids are changing what they eat, how they treat plants, and how they treat each other.

 

Studies Show

Here are some people who agree with us about the importance of bringing our students outside and into the garden:

  • California Board of Education: A Healthy Nutrition Environment: Linking Education, Activity, and Food through School Gardens
  • National Science Teachers Association: School Gardens Grow Science Achievement Scores
  • Harvard Education Letter: Taking the Common Core Outside: School gardens offer lessons beyond science and healthy eating
  • School Nutrition Association: School Gardens as a Strategy for Increasing Fruit and Vegetable Consumption
  • American Journal of Preventative Medicine: Neighborhood Greenness and 2-Year Changes in Body Mass Index of Children and Youth

 

The Team: Who We Are

Camilla Hammer, Project Manager

Camilla has always been fascinated by the natural world. When she moved to the urban jungle to earn her B.A. in Environmental Philosophy and Food Ethics at NYU, she realized that her inner country girl could not be ignored. She learned how to grow vegetables by travelling through India and Europe working on a variety of small organic farms, which taught her the importance of developing your own farming method in response to your land and your community. Just prior to joining Battery Urban Farm, Camilla spent a season learning about biodynamics as an apprentice at Live Power Community Farm in Covelo, California. As the Project Manager of Battery Urban Farm, Camilla is grateful to have a job that rarely feels like work.

 

Lauren Kaplan, Project Coordinator
Lauren grew up on the North Fork of Long Island, where she developed an early and deep-seated appreciation for the value that small-scale farms and access to locally grown food bring to a community. After a six-year career in book publishing, Lauren felt the pull of her rural roots and made the decision to support diversified, sustainable and local agriculture with more than just her fork. She worked or volunteered with Red Jacket Orchards, Garden of Eve, GrowNYC, two East End wineries and a flower shop before joining The Battery Conservancy as Project Coordinator of Battery Urban Farm. Together with her Battery Urban Farm team, she cultivates young farmers, conscientious eaters, garden advocates – and vegetables, of course – from the ground up. 

 

Anna Scott Ellis, Farm Educator

As a high school student, Anna started her love of urban farming at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. There, she learned how to produce a variety of vegetables from small plot of land and teach others the joy of growing their own food - something she hasn't stopped doing since. Before becoming the Farm Educator at The Battery Conservancy, she lived on Martha’s Vineyard managing the education garden at the Farm Institute. Anna graduated from Beloit College with a B.S. in Environmental Biology and a minor in Studio Art. She is delighted to return to her New York City roots and encourage other “city kids” to go ahead and get their hands dirty.

Henry Sweets, Farm Foreman

Henry has a B.A. in Philosophy from the University of the South and has worked for the Stone Barns Center for Food and Agriculture in Pocantico Hills, NY, and Greenacres Farm in Cincinnati, OH. Henry spends most of his time out on the farm tending to plants or building and maintaining farm infrastructure. He will be growing several varieties of his favorite vegetable, Okra, because he still can't decide which one he loves most.

 

Thank you to all the teachers, parents, students, volunteers, and partners who have helped turn the dream of Battery Urban Farm into a reality. We are proud to call you our community.

Change that Parents and Teachers Can See
Children are notoriously finicky eaters, frequently refusing to even try new foods. And yet come harvest time, all it takes is a few weeks of tending a row of sweet little turnips and one brave, enthusiastic classmate to encourage thirty first-graders to go from “yuck!” to “Can I have seconds?” We’ve witnessed it firsthand. Ask anyone involved in gardening with kids, and they’ll tell you what we see at Battery Urban Farm almost every day: that if kids grow it, they’re more willing to eat it.
“Olivia LOVED the gardening class. She NEVER eats veggies, but she was actually munching on Swiss Chard at the farm!!  The day she brought home the tomatoes and cucumbers, she was so excited and called me at work to ask me to buy lettuce, carrots and celery so that she could chop up what she had brought home and make a salad.”
-- Battery Urban Farm Parent
 
 
And that's just the beginning. Battery Urban Farm is encouraging students to learn not just on the farm, but beyond. Children in New York City are not only often without access to fresh fruits and vegetables, but they rarely have the opportunity to explore the natural world. Many of our students have recess in their cafeterias, and some of them have never seen worms before. By giving students the opportunity to engage with flowers, plants and insects, we allow them to exercise the natural curiosity that every child enjoys.
“Nadia has been watering the trees in the playgrounds [since joining the City Seedlings summer program] - she fills up her bucket with water from the sprinklers!”
-- Battery Urban Farm Parent                                                                       
“It was a rewarding experience when [after weeding chickweed during a farm lesson] we were on another field trip at a solar estuary and some of the kids started weeding – my group of students discovered a gardener pulling chickweed and insisted on doing it for him!”
-- First Grade Teacher
 

Additionally, teachers often share stories of how students that may not excel in a classroom setting shine on the farm. Other teachers report that students are more responsible and respectful with their classmates during and after farm visits. 
“The experience of bringing students to the farm has been invaluable. There is something very powerful working in the space- as I have observed students collaborating and sharing in ways in which they haven’t in the classroom.”
-- Therapy on the Farm, Teacher

Giving Kids the Tools
The skills and concepts students learn on the farm are not limited to the farm sphere. Battery Urban Farm is an outdoor classroom that reinforces and enlivens concepts learned in school with farm-based projects, exercises and vocabulary that bloom into a broader, interconnected web of knowledge. Our lessons incorporate Math, Science, Art, History and English, so that the experiential education on the farm is interdisciplinary. In order to ensure that our curriculum is reinforcing concepts from the classroom, we make sure all our lessons correspond to NY State CORE curriculum standards.
For example: Lessons on food miles encourage kids to think about what their breakfast is made of, calculate how far it traveled, and how much energy it took to fuel that trip based on the method of transport. An introduction to the history of The Battery and traditional Dutch and Lenape farming methods encourages students to think about the history of the land and the many cultures who have farmed here before us.

 
At Battery Urban Farm, Kids are changing what they eat, how they treat plants, and how they treat each other.
 
Studies Show
Here are some people who agree with us about the importance of bringing our students outside and into the garden:

California Board of Education: A Healthy Nutrition Environment: Linking Education, Activity, and Food through School Gardens

National Science Teachers Association: School Gardens Grow Science Achievement Scores

Harvard Education Letter: Taking the Common Core Outside: School gardens offer lessons beyond science and healthy eating

School Nutrition Association: School Gardens as a Strategy for Increasing Fruit and Vegetable Consumption

American Journal of Preventative Medicine: Neighborhood Greenness and 2-Year Changes in Body Mass Index of Children and Youth

 
The Team: Who We Are

Camilla Hammer, Project Manager
Camilla has always been fascinated by the natural world. When she moved to the urban jungle to earn her B.A. in Environmental Philosophy and Food Ethics at NYU, she realized that her inner country girl could not be ignored. She learned how to grow vegetables by travelling through India and Europe working on a variety of small organic farms, which taught her the importance of developing your own farming method in response to your land and your community. Just prior to joining Battery Urban Farm, Camilla spent a season learning about biodynamics as an apprentice at Live Power Community Farm in Covelo, California. As the Project Manager of Battery Urban Farm, Camilla is grateful to have a job that rarely feels like work.
 
Lauren Kaplan, Project Coordinator Lauren grew up on the North Fork of Long Island, where she developed an early and deep-seated appreciation for the value that small-scale farms and access to locally grown food bring to a community. After a six-year career in book publishing, Lauren felt the pull of her rural roots and made the decision to support diversified, sustainable and local agriculture with more than just her fork. She worked or volunteered with Red Jacket Orchards, Garden of Eve, GrowNYC, two East End wineries and a flower shop before joining The Battery Conservancy as Project Coordinator of Battery Urban Farm. Together with her Battery Urban Farm team, she cultivates young farmers, conscientious eaters, garden advocates – and vegetables, of course – from the ground up. 
 
Anna Scott Ellis, Farm Educator
As a high school student, Anna started her love of urban farming at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. There, she learned how to produce a variety of vegetables from small plot of land and teach others the joy of growing their own food - something she hasn't stopped doing since. Before becoming the Farm Educator at The Battery Conservancy, she lived on Martha’s Vineyard managing the education garden at the Farm Institute. Anna graduated from Beloit College with a B.S. in Environmental Biology and a minor in Studio Art. She is delighted to return to her New York City roots and encourage other “city kids” to go ahead and get their hands dirty.

Henry Sweets, Farm Foreman
Henry has a B.A. in Philosophy from the University of the South and has worked for the Stone Barns Center for Food and Agriculture in Pocantico Hills, NY, and Greenacres Farm in Cincinnati, OH. Henry spends most of his time out on the farm tending to plants or building and maintaining farm infrastructure. He will be growing several varieties of his favorite vegetable, Okra, because he still can't decide which one he loves most.
 
Thank you to all the teachers, parents, students, volunteers, and partners who have helped turn the dream of Battery Urban Farm into a reality. We are proud to call you our community.

story:
Make sustainable choices

Making sustainable choices is an every-day matter. Often the choice needs to be made on the spot: which brand is more sustainable? what sustainable alternatives do I have?

Companies are also happy to tell you how sustainable they are, but how can you really know they are not just trying to greenwash their image? Who would you trust to give you that information?

Our app puts the community to the forefront on sustainability. You get on-the-spot advice ensuring you can choose more sustainably. And you can trust that advice because it comes from your community and not a PR agency.


Campaing milestones

We want to launch our app across the mobile app market during summer. For this we have defined the following milestones:

  • 33% - iPhone early access enabled for May, connect with friends and start completing tasks
  • 50% - Android unlocked, form teams, start quests and projects
  • 66% - Windows Phone unlocked, see leaderboards, challenge other teams
  • 100% - Full feature set on all platforms for going live before August

Why do it?

  • Do it for impact - We really believe this is the solution to drive sustainability into the broader public's daily life. That's why we're in this!
  • Do it for a sustainable community - We want to see people supporting local businesses and each other in driving in a more sustainable lifestyle.
  • Do it for fun - We believe the best way to do reach people is by making choosing sustainably rewarding on all levels.


Not available for funding, but still want to help?

In that case, you can still apply to our early-access beta testers and share us in your favorite social media. Apply on our website.

If you have other cool skills you would want to apply towards this goal (software, marketing etc.) you can reach us by email.

story:
Introduction

Small communities in the region of La Mixteca Alta, in Southern Mexico, live largely as subsistence farmers. However, soil erosion and insufficient water make agricultural practices extremely difficult. This has led to a dwindling population as people emigrate to regions with more resources. Local communities have taken many steps in an attempt to restore the natural original landscape of the region.

While community driven projects like reforestation, rainwater catchment systems, composting and soil fertilization have helped the region in the past 15 years, further international engagement and an exchange of knowledge in sustainable agriculture, will bring much needed resources and technology to the region.

The implementation of a sustainable agricultural model in the region is intended to serve as an active transfer of technical knowledge to the local population. This education component will ultimately improve quality of life in the region through the creation of rural employment and improved agriculture outputs.

In addition, the local ecosystem will be directly affected by agriculture due to the natural exchange of agriculture and ecosystem services. Over time, this synergy has a direct effect on local climate, by further improving the quality of the soil, cooling the region, creating more rain, increasing biodiversity, building crop resistance to plagues and diseases.

Factors

Prior to implementation of this project a series of factors must be examined. Any engineering solution proposed will be planned and designed in accordance to the current natural local resources, and heavily relying on the feedback of the local population. A more detailed plan of action will be possible upon return from the planned assessment trip to the region.

Agricultural factors:

The main factors that influence efficiency of agriculture practices include the climatic conditions, soil type and structure, crop type and irrigation techniques. These factors will be evaluated through a series of physical and chemical tests conducted on site with soil and water testing equipment.


The practice of polyculture, which attempts to replicate nature’s tendency to diversify ecosystem through the use of multiple and alternating crops, improves local biodiversity, decreases plant susceptibility to diseases and pest control. Evidence suggests that management systems that emphasize crop diversity through the use of polycultures, crop rotations and agroforestry can often reduce the abundance of insect pests that specialize on a particular crop, while providing refuge and alternative prey for natural enemies (Andow 1991). These factors directly affect the environmental synergies, becoming part of the local ecosystem’s feedback loop.

Water source and quality:

The depth and accessibility of the underlying aquifer is important in order to establish whether source will be sufficient for the size of plots and types of crops being considered. Crops differ both in terms of their daily water needs and the duration of their total growing period. The crop type is therefore an important factor in determining irrigation water needs. In addition, the quality of water must be tested to identify whether treatment is necessary prior to agricultural use.

Wind pattern:

For the purposes of this proposed model of sustainable agriculture, wind patterns must be studied to ensure feasibility of a wind powered water pump.

Other available energy sources:

While on site, the team will investigate the availability and nature of other energy sources in the area.

Soil capacity and properties:

Soil capacity is the ability of the soil to hold water between irrigation or precipitation events. Some determinants of soil capacity include soil depth, ratios of different soil particles that making up the soil, soil porosity, and soil water tension. These factors influence the amount of water available to the plants. Because soil properties change at various depths, it is important to know the soil capacity throughout the plant root zone.

Crop selection:

According to information provided by the community, ancient agricultural systems like the terrace farming were significant in the advance of the production system; it utilized massive manual labor for its construction and maintenance, took advantage of annual precipitation accumulation and facilitated intensive agriculture of polyculture crops of beans, corn and squash.

Degree of erosion:

It is estimated that 83% of the soils in the La Mixteca are mildly or moderately degraded and that 17% show signs of severe erosion.

Community needs and social structure:

To ensure sustainability of any agriculture model this project must be structured in the most natural manner for the local population. To achieve this goal, the traditional agriculture customs, and native crop type and cultivation methods must be incorporated into the final design. Additionally, in the region of La Mixteca Alta, many communities are structured as communal lands, or ejidos. This will be a factor in the determining the location for implementing a project of this nature. The social and political organization of the communities is also important in concluding feasibility and sustainability of the model.

 

Technical component of the model

The model has as its primary component the development of small-scale drip-irrigation systems that will be fed from the local underlying aquifer. Water from the aquifer will be pumped using a wind-pump. A pedal pump will be connected to the system for wind-less periods. This system would require no electrical power and has low implementation and maintenance costs.

story:
Our Story
The Wreck Racing League or WRL is the sanctioning body for Formula H20 Racing. Formula H2O racing is the action packed sport which combines underwater scooters and scuba diving racing on artificial reefs. The next Formula H2O race will be the Quest for Atocha Gold in Key West Florida November 12th – 14th. The race is hosted by the Florida Keys Community College and is made possible by Indian Valley Scuba and Mel Fisher’s Treasures.
 
The Quest for Atocha Gold is gearing up to be the largest, most publicized Formula H2O event of the season. This event is certain to leave racers anticipating the start of the 2011 circuit (worldwide race dates are already being scheduled).
 
As the Shark Whisperer, I spend my time with sharks reading, interpreting and interacting with them using body language and animal communication skills that I honed while working with horses.  As I interact and play with the sharks, I examine their environment and study the overall health of the reef and their food chain.   From that information, I work to present a realistic picture of sharks so that people can appreciate the importance of the animal to the ecosystem, to the oceans and to our planet.
 
The Impact
By racing in a dynamic sport like Formula H2O, we garner much media attention.  This gives us the opportunity to divulge the true nature of the shark and to draw attention to the important role it plays in our ecosystem.  In the last race, television broadcast reports show that in the US alone, we had over 8 million total audience impressions.   
 
Moreover, because our entire team works in underwater video production, we are the crew that documents and records most of the video footage that is released to the press.  As a result, our message reaches a broad audience which hears our message by visiting our web pages and watching our videos.   
 
With your participation, you directly contribute to that message by offering us the resources we need to document these races.
 
What We Need & What You Get
I race in Formula H2O as the Shark Whisperer. Although visionaries in the scuba industry sponsor us, we also require travel and entry funds to attend, participate in and document the races.  The final race of the 2010 season is in Key West and our cost is $1300.
 
Other Ways You Can Help
Please be a part of spreading the word to help sharks by telling your friends about us.  Use the share buttons to put us on your Facebook, Twitter and MySpace pages.   Get the word out, and together we can all learn from the sharks and help them at the same time.  

The easiest way that you can help sharks is to protect their their environment.  For example of the ways you can do that is it to eat fish that are caught using sustainable practices.  For information on that go to the Monterey Bay Aquarium Seafood Watch Program.  Also, work to minimize your trash as a disturbing amount of plastic products end up in the oceans. 

The best way to do something directly is to visit our partner organizations - University of Miami RJ Dunlap Marine Conservation Program and/or Shark Savers and contribute to their programs or participate in their activities.

story:
Who We Are

We are five students from the University of Tennessee raising money for the local nonprofit Ijams Nature Center. Ijams' mission stands to enhance the Knoxville community by preserving indigenous wildlife and educating future generations about the importance of protecting our environment.

As college students, we each have gained an immense appreciation for the beauty, serenity, and rejuvenation discovered through reconnecting with the great outdoors. Living in a metropolitan area limits exposure to local wildlife. Ijams remedies this by providing public access to trails, forests, and quarries only minutes from the city center.

Why Give and What You Get

Ijams currently focuses on removing invasive species that cause local habitat destruction and replacing them with native varieties. Our team is raising funds to purchase indigenous seeds and saplings that will enhance the local ecosystem of east Tennessee. Exemplifying the impact of invasive species, the overwhelming spread of kudzu currently threatens indigenous plants in the nature center. This weed both crushes native species and produces a higher output of nitrogen, which harms the environment's ability to support the healthy ecosystem.

Ijams stands as a sanctuary for countless animals that are uprooted from the city. When invasive species overtake an area, native wildlife is inadvertently harmed as the surrounding food supply and habitat becomes limited. We are raising money to remove these aggressive plants from Ijams and, therefore, revitalize wildlife in the region. 

For donations of $15 you receive a handwritten letter, for $25 you receive Ijams' decal, for $50 you receive an Ijams' water bottle, for $75 you receive a handcrafted, ceramic bowl or plate, and for $100 or more we will award the donor with an Ijams' membership.

How This Helps The Community

Ijam's maintains a place for citizens of Knoxville to enjoy nature away from the metropolitan bustle of the city. Serving as a wildlife center, Ijam's teaches local youth to respect nature, which creates a greener future for the surrounding community. Preserving wildlife in the city also benefits the environment as a whole. Greater tree density sustains the environment while providing many health benefits to those living in the surrounding area.

Protecting indigenous species preserves the habitat of Knoxville's local wildlife and maintains an ecosystem that remains exclusive to east Tennessee. The plants and animals that comprise this region are currently being attacked by invasive species. Ijam's strives to fight habitat destruction and foreign competition by replacing these invasive species with trees and undergrowth native to east Tennessee's local ecosystems.

 

 

Other Ways to Help

If you remain unable to give this month but still desire to help, please share our campaign on Facebook and Twitter! Ijams always appreciates volunteers and visitors, so please consider spreading spreading the word and taking an afternoon adventure to the nature center. You can volunteer and learn more about IJAMs here.

story:
We've reached our goal!

Any further contributions after $3000 will go towards the remaining balance of $3000 for the land. The total price for the land is $6000. Please help us get there.


The Story

As a part of the organization Quelonios del Caribe, my brother and I have been collaborating with other groups to protect the sea turtle populations that nest on the Caribbean coast of Costa Rica, north of the Pacuare River. Our
nightly patrols furtively scour the beach for nesting turtles in order to collect and hatch their delicate and precious eggs in our protected hatchery.

Four years ago, we discovered that the beach south of the Pacuare River was completely undefended. Hundreds of sea turtle eggs were systematically being poached. And so our new project began: every night we cross the mouth of the Pacuare River to protect these sea turtles. It is an incredibly dangerous journey, but up to this point, has been the only way for us to expand our work to the south.

Many turtle eggs that would have otherwise been stolen by poachers have hatched into beautiful baby turtles!

And yet this year has proven exceptionally difficult. Not only are we competing against poachers, but the local natural habitat is changing: increased erosion, rising tides, and stronger currents are endangering those nests that are not poached.

And so, we must relocate our camp to the other side of the river where we can build a fully functional hatchery with around-the-clock care for our precious babies.

How the funds will be used

The best space is being locally sold to us by a fellow member of the Pacuare community. 
50% downpayment on land (due in July 2015) $3000
*any amount over the $3000 will be used to complete the full payment

Our New Camp purchased with your help:


Our Other Work

I've been directly involved in sea turtle conservation for over 7 years. I have run several sites in Costa Rica and helped relocate thousands of eggs and protech hundreds of nesting females. 

This year we are excited to share that we are working directly with Sea Shepard on Operation Jairo. We come from humble beginnings and only crowdfund what is necessary to continue our work.

And yet this year has proven exceptionally difficult. Not only are we competing
against poachers, but the local natural habitat is changing: increased erosion,
rising tides, and stronger currents are endangering those nests that are not
poached.

And so, we must relocate our camp to the other side of the river where we can
build a fully functional hatchery with around-the-clock care for our precious
babies.

How the funds will be used
The best space is being locally sold to us by a fellow member of the
Pacuare community. 50% downpayment on land (due in July 2015) $3000*any amount over the $3000 will be used to complete the full payment


Our New Camp purchased with your help:Our Other WorkI've been directly involved in sea turtle conservation for over 7 years. I have run several sites in Costa Rica and helped relocate thousands of eggs and protech hundreds of nesting females. This year we are excited to share that we are working directly with Sea Shepard on Operation Jairo. We come from humble beginnings and only crowdfund what is necessary to continue our work.

story:
ENGLISH VERSION FOLLOWS

Cowspiracy : The Sustainability Secret explore la face cachée de l’industrie la plus destructrice à laquelle la Terre fait face aujourd’hui – et enquête sur les raisons pour lesquelles les grandes organisations environnementales mondiales ont peur d’en parler. 

Les organismes sans but lucratif Voix Animale et Vegan Québec s'allient pour amener ce documentaire choc en salle de cinéma à Québec. Mais nous avons besoin de vous! Vos dons sont essentiels pour nous aider à financer la location de la salle et les droits de projection du film. 

Aidez-nous à exposer la vérité sur les impacts environnementaux de l'industrie animale en rendant possible la projection de Cowspiracy en cinéma à Québec!

Plusieurs récompenses sont offertes en fonction du montant de votre don. Une bonne façon de nous aider est aussi de partager notre projet à vos amis! Un grand merci à tous.

_______________________________________________________________________

"COWSPIRACY: The Sustainability Secret" is a groundbreaking feature-length environmental documentary following an intrepid filmmaker as he uncovers the most destructive industry facing the planet today – and investigates why the world's leading environmental organizations are too afraid to talk about it. 

Not-for-profit advocacy groups Animal Voice and Vegan Quebec join forces to bring this eye-opening documentary to a professionnal theater in Quebec city. But we need you to make it happen! Donations are essential to help us fund projection rights and the location of the theater auditorium. 

Help us expose the truth about the environmental impacts of animal agriculture by contributing to bring Cowspiracy to a professional theater in Quebec city!

story:
The current product of emphasis is  synthetic gasoline; however other hydrocarbon fuels such as methanol, diesel, jet fuel and a substitute for natural gas – dimethyl ether (DME).  These  may be produced with similar equipment and  processing approach.

Environmental impact summary of the ORCA system

The name Orca was chosen because of the oxygen replacing and carbon absorbing properties of our system.  Every gallon of synthetic gasoline we produce will release 19.4 pounds of oxygen and absorb 17.7 pounds of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Each of these floating factories would produce 5 million gallons of synthetic gasoline per year, represents a 20 acre footprint and consumes 40,000 metric tons of carbon dioxide each year.  If we were the sole source for the 135 billion gallons of gasoline consumed in the United States each year we would remove 1.08 billion metric tons of carbon dioxide each year while only utilizing an ocean surface area equivalent to a 29 by 29 mile square. The Orca system also compares favorably with bio-fuel. An acre of soybeans will yield ethanol equivalent to 40 gallons of gasoline per acre per year and remove 16 metric tons of carbon dioxide.  Our Orca system produces 250,000 gallons of synthetic gasoline per acre of ocean surface per year and removes 2,000 metric tons of carbon dioxide each year without displacing crops, forest, or pastureland. 

The synthetic gasoline we produce has the same carbon dioxide content as gasoline with 10% ethanol (17.68 lbs/gal.) and can be utilized without any changes to our vehicles or fuel delivery infrastructure. Synthetic gasoline produced by our system would provide the same level of economy and performance as the gasoline we are presently using.  Straight gasoline (without ethanol) has a carbon dioxide content of 19.64 lbs/gal.  So we not only provide a lower carbon dioxide content gasoline that will operate seamlessly in our current vehicles, but we also reclaim that same amount of carbon dioxide from the air (or seawater) when we create each new gallon of synthetic gasoline.  Now that's recycling.  We have chosen to scrub the carbon dioxide from the air rather than from seawater because extracting it from the air provides $0.17 per gallon credit through the sale of carbon credits on the international market.

Since the ORCA fleets operate on the Continental Shelves, the fleets to not degrade the aesthetics: no windmills to spoil the views, no intrusion into the coastal areas to be the sites of anchored, near coastal wave conversions sites that are being considered. No spoiling the commercial or recreational fishing, surfing and beach recreational sites.  One might think that such a source and production of renewable energy would be expensive, and probably need subsidies and government mandatory consumer rules  such as exists by the ethanol industry.  In fact, the production and distribution of ORCA renewable fuel should undercut the price of gasoline at the pump after its  further  development and introduction. Capital investment in this new industry would  result in an impressive  return on investment. 

The AEEA Business Plan

The long term business plan is to develop the ORCA concept to a sufficient  level of maturity to organizations  capable and willing to complete its  development,  introduce the  product into the national economy and will buy or lease our intellectual property. To attract potential investors it may be  necessary to develop the ORCA concept beyond its present level of maturity.  The AEEA group will achieve  this level through further technical and promotional increments. This crowd funding effort will be used  to finance continued system development and promotional activities. If we are fortunate enough to receive funding beyond our committed  goal, we will enhance our estimates of size, shape and performance of the principal system components. This invention has been conceived by retired, independent consultants without the assistance of the systematic research and development laboratories routinely  performed by  major industrial or academic institutional organizations.  

The  senior partners of AEEA have spent most of their careers working in those organizations  (see resumes on our web site) and have had to improvise and stretch limited funding.  Since these resources have not been available, investment in the enterprise has been entirely  provided by the partnership and greatly assisted by  volunteers providing technical council and access to simulated wave facilities. All theoretical and applied engineering and financial analyses, model development and testing has been performed in-house (or in garages!) and improvised wave simulation facilities. The crowd funding received in this phase of development will enable us to pay for the help needed from volunteers. AEEA senior partners will draw no money from the crowd funding sources.  

Short Term Planning – Advanced Model Construction and Testing at the Puyallup High School (PHS)- The short term goal would be crowd funded and would complete the instrumentation and  support the testing of the existing four  8’x4’ models and wave generation system developed and constructed by student volunteers and their Vocational teacher, Mr. Macdonald  of the Puyallup High School, Puyallup, Washington (PHS). The  high school swimming pool and their wave generation system would make use of the PHS pool facility  if and when available. If the PHS pool is not available, one of several  suitable small lakes in the vicinity will be used. Linkages, power take off devices, a measurement system, data recording and reduction and documentation would be performed. The results of earlier testing using existing four 4’ models will be  used to obtain scaling data and  a baseline performance comparison with the larger models. Since the patent proposal was submitted, other power take off devices have been suggested for examination for possible improvements in efficiency beyond the baseline hydraulic approach. If funding is available, candidate mechanisms including Rack and Pinion, Ball Screw drives, and Linear Permanent Magnet generation may be considered for incorporation in the  models after completion of trade studies. This data will be used to project performance to full scale barge flotillas.

Possible extensions of near term activities –If the committed crowd funding goals were exceeded or became  available from other sources, the following candidate increments of development will be performed as useful follow- on activities:These increments of activity would include the preliminary design of the Steinberg Atmospheric CO2  to Gasoline method based on his two patents. It is anticipated that the next increment of development would include the  testing and display of advanced models at the Hinsdale Wave Energy Laboratory operated by the Oregon State University, in Corvallis, Oregon.  As part of these long term goals, recent interest by  the Seattle University and our cadre of volunteers may result in teaming for National Science Foundation  grant applications to sponsor advanced technology tasks.  Examples include  preliminary development work on the adaptive wave  resonance system described in the AEEA patent which will optimize or “tune” the fleet to varying wave lengths, amplitudes, phases and direction.

The Importance of Your Help

An exceptional opportunity to participate in this breakthrough, “game changing “ energy quest exists. You contributors are at the most important stage of the Concept  Development Phase. This  goal will  enable AEEA to collect data  providing the assurance   to potential private investor or government sponsorship to support the development of prototype hardware and software. Your contributions should change the direction of renewable energy research directed to the stabilization of global warming through the reduction of CO2 in the atmosphere. In addition you can assist in the seamless conversion of an economy based on gasoline to one of methanol or other clean automotive fuels as those become feasible. We will strive to meet or exceed our modest goal of $50,000 for period of time negotiated with Indiegogo of 45 days.

AEEA needs your help in other ways as well. The technology required to establish this concept covers the state-of-art in chemical processing, software development, electronic and electrical engineering, oceanography and marine engineering. We have some gallant volunteers at this time, but if others would like to participate in this exciting area please read our web site and contact us. We need every one interested in these goals to contact their representatives in government to awaken them to the possibilities described in this program and to  call for support to this effort from the appropriate government research organizations.

Volunteer Assistance

A highly supportive article in the Seattle Times newspaper of November 11, 2010 (Reporter Danny Westneat) resulted in a number of volunteers providing assistance to the ORCA concept  development.  Vocational Arts classes of the Puyallup, WA High School, taught by Alex McDonald,  have been assisting the ORCA effort in the construction of eight foot barge models a motor driven wave generator and model testing. The High School swimming pool has been made available as a test basin.  This activity was considered beneficial to the students by the school authorities as they have the privilege to be participants in a state-of the-art renewable energy program. And more lately an interested technician, Peter Ricthie constructed another wave generator that will be used to generate scale model wind waves to test orthogonal wind and swell wave effects.

The AEEA organization gratefully acknowledges this assistance.  Other volunteers with suitable academic and professional credentials, such as Peter Anast, engineer experiencd in analytical studies of wave energy conversion,  Dr. Thomas Mathai, Senior Associate in Ocean Engineering and William Hurley Jr, Principal and COB, at The Glosten Associates a Seattle-based marine architectural firm, Dick Metz a retired Marine Architect serving as Program Manager of the Hydrofoil Ferry Program for the Boeing Company. Peter Anast performed analytical studies of wave energy conversion efficiency of linked vessels that included equal length rafts, and Thomas Mathai used the assistance of AEEA in a joint effort proposal to NOAA. William Hurley made cost estimates of unmodified barge costs. Dick Metz was the designer of the wave generator constructed by the Puyullap High School.  Jim Collins, helped by suggesting designs for hydraulic cylinders and rack and pinion designs and Sean Nelson of Custom Steel Works have assisted in two of our proposals to the DoE.   Gary Flores of NAVSEA Keyport, WA helped by rewriting a proposal previously submitted by us to the DoE, but for the use of forward based fleets  and an introductory technical meeting with NAVSEA, Keyport.  Jason Schuler, a former nuclear technician and now an operations analyst, is assisting with chemical processing and business at the NAES Corp.,  has taken interest in our chemical processing and contributed to our business promotion.  And most recently George Bieda, a retired Navy Captain and nuclear engineer, is assisting with computer modeling and liaison with the US Navy's efforts to produce jet fuel at sea, using a process similar to the ORCA system.

And not least of all the assistance we received was that from the chemist, Meyer Steinberg, the inventor of the three cell Electrolyzer used in the AEEA patent as a very efficient means of making Methanol, the feedstock for gasoline. He has assisted us in writing of proposals to numerous petroleum companies, the Methanol Institute and the Department of Energy.

We are exploring opportunities to collaborate with Dr. John Carter and other faculty and staff of the College of Science and Engineering at Seattle University to evaluate the relative merits of four different mechanizations of wave energy convertors.

story:
Fleet Farming

Hi There! My name is Justin Vandenbroeck, Founder of Fleet Farming Oakland and Vice President of IDEAS For Us. To begin, Fleet Farming is a solution, incubated by the non-profit organization IDEAS For Us, whose mission is to develop, fund and scale solutions to the world's most pressing social and environmental challenges. 

Fleet Farming transforms lawns into productive small organic farms, operate and maintain them, and sharecrop 5-10% of our harvests with the homeowners or tenants. The remaining produce is sold in the marketplace through farmers markets, local distributors and chefs. Revenues are reinvested into the program to expand to other properties and employ urban farmers.

Bi-weekly, we host a community bike ride were volunteers can join us on a bicycle powered urban farming experience, biking from site to site learning how to build beds, install irrigation, seed, weed, harvest and more. It's an incredible experience and if you're in one of our operating cities - come join!

To date, Fleet Farming is operating in Orlando, FL; Oakland, CA; and Kampala, Uganda. But do to our recent publications on Fleet Farming, we're receiving a massive amount of interest from people all over the country (and even the world - someone from the Philippines reach out this week - no joke!). 


Raising $5,000 to Participate in Millennial Trains Project

We're at a critical point in our program where the interest and the experience from scaling to Oakland has made us realize we ought to improve our existing 25 page toolkit!

We've been accepted to join the Millennial Trains Project and are raising $5,000 to participate in the crowd-funded transcontinental train journey from August 1st - August 7th where we'll be meeting with leading urban farmers, touring their sites and hosting Hive's (design-thinking workshops) in Pittsburgh, Chicago, Kansas City, Albuquerque and Los Angeles.

There we'll learn about the unique challenges and opportunities facing the Fleet Farming model in their community! We believe it's this platform that will enable us to improve our tools and resources, engage local communities and empower the next generation of urban farmers. 


Fleet Perks!

We've developed some unique perks to give back to those who contribute to our project!


$10 - Fleet Thank You! A custom, hand-written, 4”x6” thank you card with a photo from the trip depicting one of the many empowering urban farm tours we’ll embark on;  PLUS the perks above!


$25 - Fleet Seeds: A collection of heirloom seeds, native to the various regions we will be visiting during the MTP adventure;  PLUS the perks above!


$50 - Fleet Greens Delivery: A bicycle powered delivery of Fleet Greens to your home or business [Oakland/San Francisco and Audubon/Winter Park Specific];  PLUS the perks above!


$100 - Fleet T + Fleet Toolkit: An American Apparel Sustainable Edition (Organic Cotton & Made in the U.S.) Fleet Farming silk-screen printed T-Shirt; and our Fleet Farming Toolkit;  PLUS the perks above!


$250 - Fleet Fotos: A beautiful 20x20cm square Sticky9 Photo Album of 20 Fleet Fotos, delivered, from the MTP adventure and archives from the Fleet Farming Instagram;  PLUS the perks above!


$500 - Fleet Farm to Table: Dinner and conversation with one of our Founding Fleet Farmers and our partnering chef's at one of our partnering restaurants [Oakland, CA and Orlando, FL Specific] who will be serving our Fleet Greens among other delicious local food;  PLUS the perks above!


$1,000 - Fleet Farmlette Perk: You will be joining our portfolio of farmlettes! This includes the Installation of a 250 sq ft Fleet Farm in your front, side or back yard, maintenance and an indefinite 10% of the farmlettes harvest! [West Oakland, CA specific]; PLUS the perks above!


Think Global, Act Local

Your contribution will make a significant impact in our ability to scale Fleet Farming around the country. In Orlando, we're currently operating 15 sites and expect to be farming 20 by the end of 2016; to add, we've managed to employ a few young women from our community as part-time urban farmers; and of course, we've grown thousands of pounds of produce and have engaged over 500 people from the community in our SWARM rides. 

As for Oakland, we're 3 months old, are operating 3 sites and are employing a couple youth from our neighborhood in West Oakland. To date we've sold several hundred pounds of produce and have partnerships with 6 Oakland-based restaurants. 

We know this program hits the triple bottom line and has the opportunity to make a major difference around the world. In May alone, we received over 300 email inquiries from people either wanting to join and existing Fleet Farming program or start their own! We see this trip as a crucial opportunity to ensure we're equipping ambitious people with the tools and resources they need to succeed! 

Your contributions towards our campaign will go directly to Millennial Trains Project to help underwrite our expenses associated with the journey (on-train accommodation, meals, and all MTP-related programming activities). To add, they are tax-deductible.

Thank you so much for considering this project and becoming part of the Fleet Family. 

Other Ways You Can Help

In case you can't donate, please feel free to spread the word about our campaign, your can use the Indiegogo share tools on your screen to push it through your network!

Additionally, feel free to follow our Facebook, Instagram and Twitter outlets for updates before, during, and after the journey; in addition to the exciting happening within our communities!

Fleet Perks!
We've developed some unique perks to give back to those who contribute to our project!


$10 - Fleet Thank You! A custom, hand-written, 4”x6” thank you card with a photo from the trip depicting one of the many empowering urban farm tours we’ll embark on;  PLUS the perks above!

$25 - Fleet Seeds: A collection of heirloom seeds, native to the various regions we will be visiting during the MTP adventure;  PLUS the perks above!

$50 - Fleet Greens Delivery: A bicycle powered delivery of Fleet Greens to your home or business [Oakland/San Francisco and Audubon/Winter Park Specific];  PLUS the perks above!



$100 - Fleet T + Fleet Toolkit: An American Apparel Sustainable Edition (Organic Cotton & Made in the U.S.) Fleet Farming silk-screen printed T-Shirt; and our Fleet Farming Toolkit;  PLUS the perks above!

$250 - Fleet Fotos: A beautiful 20x20cm square Sticky9 Photo Album of 20 Fleet Fotos, delivered, from the MTP adventure and archives from the Fleet Farming Instagram;  PLUS the perks above!

$500 - Fleet Farm to Table: Dinner and conversation with one of our Founding Fleet Farmers and our partnering chef's at one of our partnering restaurants [Oakland, CA and Orlando, FL Specific] who will be serving our Fleet Greens among other delicious local food;  PLUS the perks above!

$1,000 - Fleet Farmlette Perk: You will be joining our portfolio of farmlettes! This includes the Installation of a 250 sq ft Fleet Farm in your front, side or back yard, maintenance and an indefinite 10% of the farmlettes harvest! [West Oakland, CA specific]; PLUS the perks above!





 
Think Global, Act Local
Your contribution will make a significant impact in our ability to scale Fleet Farming around the country. In Orlando, we're currently operating 15 sites and expect to be farming 20 by the end of 2016; to add, we've managed to employ a few young women from our community as part-time urban farmers; and of course, we've grown thousands of pounds of produce and have engaged over 500 people from the community in our SWARM rides. 
As for Oakland, we're 3 months old, are operating 3 sites and are employing a couple youth from our neighborhood in West Oakland. To date we've sold several hundred pounds of produce and have partnerships with 6 Oakland-based restaurants. 
We know this program hits the triple bottom line and has the opportunity to make a major difference around the world. In May alone, we received over 300 email inquiries from people either wanting to join and existing Fleet Farming program or start their own! We see this trip as a crucial opportunity to ensure we're equipping ambitious people with the tools and resources they need to succeed! 
Your contributions towards our campaign will go directly to Millennial Trains Project to help underwrite our expenses associated with the journey (on-train accommodation, meals, and all MTP-related programming activities). To add, they are tax-deductible.
Thank you so much for considering this project and becoming part of the Fleet Family. 

    Other Ways You Can Help In case you can't donate, please feel free to spread the word about our campaign, your can use the Indiegogo share tools on your screen to push it through your network!
Additionally, feel free to follow our Facebook, Instagram and Twitter outlets for updates before, during, and after the journey; in addition to the exciting happening within our communities!

story:
Hi! We are Kids 4 Hydrogen, a group of students and young adults dedicated to developing a sustainable energy infrastructure in the United States. Fossil fuels not only release harmful greenhouse gases when burned, but they are also a limited, dwindling resource in this country. Hydrogen fuel cells offer a promising solution to this resource crisis because it harnesses the energy potential of hydrogen, a widely available resource.

Hydrogen fuel cell cars are already being manufactured, but not many people are willing to buy them due to a lack of hydrogen refueling stations throughout the country. We are going to travel through California in a fuel cell car to educate the public about hydrogen technology, simultaneously showing car companies that the public is interested in their fuel cell cars. Mercedes has agreed to let us drive their F-Cell (the “invisible car”) on our tour.  



We will also be displaying the new impressive home-power system, the Joule Box, a smart energy system that can easily integrate any renewable source (solar, wind, etc.), and store energy using both hydrogen and battery technologies. We are very excited to be presenting the Joule Box on our tour, and the Joule Box will be on permanent display at the Kids 4 Hydrogen headquarters at Merit Academy in Santa Cruz County.  To make this 10-day fuel cell tour possible, we need to raise $62,650 to fund travel, presentation, and Joule Box expenses.



The Cause
Imagine a world without cars. Now imagine a world with unpredictable, severe weather and insufferable pollution problems.  At the rate that we are using fossil fuels, one of these two worlds will be ours in just a few decades. Our consumption of finite resources is not only unsustainable, but it also releases harmful greenhouse gases that contribute to the overall deterioration of the planet.

However, there is hope.  Independent researchers have made incredible progress in developing hydrogen fuel cells to create a sustainable energy infrastructure for the future. The technology is here -- now; all we need is consumer awareness and momentum.

Global warming is not a future problem; it is a pressing issue that must be solved by building a renewable energy infrastructure to meet the world’s needs.

The Problem
While there are a number of hydrogen fueling stations in Southern California, the rest of the state has yet to build them. All major car companies have hydrogen fuel cell cars ready to put on the assembly line but they will not put these cars into production until they know that the public will buy them.  Refueling stations take approximately two years to build and will only be built when there are enough hydrogen fuel cell cars on the road to demand them.  This “Chicken and Egg” dilemma is the problem!  

The Solution
To solve this Chicken and Egg problem, we have started a waiting list on our Kids 4 Hydrogen website.  Visitors can view their hydrogen fuel cell car options and select their favorite car. Our goals are to introduce fuel cell cars to Californians and educate them about our need to stop purchasing gasoline-guzzling internal-combustion engine vehicles.  When 55,000 people sign the list to demonstrate their interest in purchasing a hydrogen fuel cell car in 2015, this will give fueling station developers the numbers they need to start building hydrogen fueling stations throughout California.  The solution is with the people. When we, the people, sign up for hydrogen fuel cell cars, both car manufacturers and refueling stations will begin production to build the clean sustainable car-refueling solution we need.  The Joule Box can provide energy to remote areas where the hydrogen infrastructure does not reach and to supplement areas where clean alternative energy is not available.

Who Are We?

Founded in 2004, Kids 4 Hydrogen is an educational outreach organization consisting of eight students from California. Kids 4 Hydrogen’s goal is to lead America in developing a sustainable energy infrastructure that will meet the world’s needs in 2050.  By giving demonstrations of how fuel cells work and presenting the hydrogen fuel cell vehicles on well-publicized tours, we hope to encourage people to get on our waiting list to purchase fuel cell vehicles to move toward a sustainable hydrogen economy.

On our 10-day hydrogen car tour, we will be driving the Mercedes F-Cell to various public and private venues to raise awareness about global warming and hydrogen fuel cell technology. We will also be debuting the Joule Box; a “smart” home-energy system designed to easily integrate hydrogen and renewable technologies to power homes. After our tour, the Joule Box will be permanently featured in Northern California as an educational tool for public demonstration of hydrogen technologies.

The tour is set to take place during the summer of 2013 or as soon as we raise the necessary funds, but we need your help to fund presentation expenses, the Joule Box, and travel costs to make this tour possible.

What We Need
We need $62,650 to cover this 10-Day Hydrogen Fuel Cell Tour.

$1850 - Permits for various sites where the tour will stop.

$7,610 - Kids 4 Hydrogen Coordinators (Director, Office Assistant, Website Manager, Graphic Designer, Video Producer, Bookkeeper). Our director will organize the entire 10-day tour by working with Mercedes to secure the hydrogen fuel cell car, arranging to have hydrogen gas delivered at demonstration sites, and coordinating the travel arrangements.  She will also work with Hydrogen House to build the demonstration model of the Joule Box for our tour.  The office assistant will work with the Kids 4 Hydrogen team, families, and teachers to make sure that team completes all paperwork and contracts and parents sign liability and travel releases. Our website manager and graphic designer will work with the team to design and prepare all printed materials: brochures, information sheets, business cards, bumper stickers, sign-up forms, etc. ).  Our videographer will film the 10-day tour and produce an educational video for the Kids 4 Hydrogen website and YouTube.

$9,510 - Presentation Materials (Brochures, Display Systems, Portable TV Monitor, Banners, Information Sheets, Sound System, T-shirts, Photo Albums, Demonstration Kits, Photography).  These costs will cover our printed materials that we will give to guests at each venue.  It also includes our display boards, tables, and everything we need to do our presentations both indoors and outdoors.  We’ll be giving a slideshow presentation as well as the ride-and-drive experience for guests.  Our goal is to get the guests excited by our professional presentation and demonstration.  

$13,680 - Travel and Transportation Expenses (Rental, Trailer, Airfare, Hotel, Per Diem).  Our team will be on the road for 10 days.  

$30,000- Covers the cost of building and shipping the Joule Box for our 10-day tour.  The Joule Box will include a wind turbine, solar panels, hydrogen fuel cell, electrolyzer, inverter, storage tanks, and batteries.  It will also include a smart energy calculator that will determine daily power consumption and energy storage needs. The Joule Box will be on permanent display and available for educational demonstrations at Merit Academy.  

We are confident that we’ll reach our goal for our 10-Day Hydrogen Fuel Cell Tour, but if we don’t quite reach our goal by our deadline, we will reduce the number of days of the tour and present the Mercedes F-Cell and Joule Box at the highest profile venues and cities.  

The Impact
Your contribution will give Kids 4 Hydrogen the funds to educate Californians about the eminent need to build a hydrogen infrastructure now.  If we continue to drive internal-combustion engine vehicles and rely on fossil fuels without developing a sustainable alternative now, we won’t have enough time to build the fuel cell fleets and hydrogen fueling stations when we run out of petroleum.  

We can’t rely on the oil companies, government, or auto industry to supply clean sustainable fuel options in a timeframe that will reduce CO2 emissions and stop climate change.  It’s up to people like you, people who understand that climate change will continue to cause worldwide devastation, who can contribute funds to help Kids 4 Hydrogen educate others to make smarter choices about the cars they drive and the fuel they use.

About Us
Kids 4 Hydrogen’s founder, Jaclyn D’Arcy, was 9 years old when she joined Merit Academy’s Hydrogen Fuel Cell team in 1998.  We were the first middle school students in the world to build a fuel cell.  We toured the nation and spoke at the Renewable Energy Caucus in Washington DC, eco conventions across the country, California universities (Stanford, Berkeley, and more), high schools, middle schools and elementary schools. To cover the costs of these tours, we received over $45,000 in funding from the Dept of Energy, museums, conventions, foundations, and individuals. We have been featured in dozens of newspapers, magazines, radio and TV interviews, and documentaries since 1998.  

We are now launching the most important piece of our outreach now.  Californians are restless about our energy future and they need to learn more about why they should purchase a hydrogen fuel cell car in 2015.  When California becomes the first state to build a hydrogen infrastructure (from San Diego to San Francisco/Sacramento), we’ll lead the nation in moving away from fossil fuels and towards a clean, sustainable energy source.

Meet the Team:
Jaclyn D'Arcy founded Kids 4 Hydrogen when she was in 9th grade.  She spoke at the American Lung Association's Breathe Easy Conference and she has worked with industry leaders to explore the hydrogen economy. After graduating from Merit Academy (high school) and Claremont McKenna College (Environment, Economics, and Politics), Jaclyn is thriving in marketing and communication at Lutron. Jaclyn continues to support Kids 4 Hydrogen by sitting on the Board of Directors and appreciates the success of the organization she started back in 2005.

Nicole D'Arcy was the first middle-school student in the world to build a hydrogen fuel cell.  She presented the fuel cell at the National Hydrogen Association's Annual Conference, the Renewable Energy Caucus, and conventions and universities across the nation.  After graduating from Merit Academy, Stanford University, and Stanford School of Medicine, Nicole will start her residency at Harbor UCLA in Emergency Medicine.

Michael Beck is the Project Leader and head of R&D. He has attended all of the 2012 and 2013 educational seminars, and he has met with leaders in the alternative energy community. He is currently an Electrical Engineering major. Michael is training Lexie Lyons to take over as Team Leader for Fall of 2013.

Rebecca Fang is a high school senior from Los Altos, California. In her free time, she plays the guitar, plays badminton, and writes poetry. She also enjoys nature and dreams of one day living in a treehouse.

Taylor Honda is a senior and will be attending UC Berkeley as an economics major in the fall of 2013. He works on the Kids4Hydrogen team as a writer and copyeditor. He is also managing editor for his school’s newspaper, which has placed 3rd, 5th, 8th, and 9th in the NSPA national competition for newspapers. In addition, he has won several awards in write-off and layout design competitions at local, state and national levels.

Zohar Wouk is a junior at Merit Academy and joined Kids 4 Hydrogen to explore clean sustainable energy technologies.  Zohar enjoys exploring business opportunities, filmmaking, and engineering.

Daniel Kodama is an Environmental Studies major at SDSU.  He videotaped the time-lapse photography and Mercedes Fuel Cell tour in Palo Alto.  He is also an avid guitar player.

Lexie Lyons is a junior and the whiteboard artist for Kids 4 Hydrogen's latest video.  A passionate member of the team, Lexie is preparing to be the 2013-2014 Project Lead for Kids 4 Hydrogen. After the team toured the Hydrogen House in New Jersey, Lexie has become a true believer that America needs to invest in non-oil-based energy.  In her spare time, she started a new whiteboard video business called Drawsome, where she creates whiteboard videos for businesses and organizations.

Sam Artioli has long supported a hydrogen economy and has supported the Kids 4 Hydrogen team by contributing his programming expertise.  He helped launch Kids 4 Hydrogen's new website and continues to offer research assistance to the team. Sam is a true entrepreneur -- he designs and programs unique devices to improve lifestyles.

Natalie Kassel is from Santa Cruz, California and is receiving her Bachelor of Science degree in Anthropology and Environmental Studies at Santa Clara University in June of 2013. She studied abroad in Costa Rica studying the social behaviors of capuchin monkeys and has also interned in the planning department for an environmental consulting firm. She was on the water polo team at Santa Clara University for 4 years and enjoys hiking, kayaking, swimming, and music.

Patrick Logsdon is known as “The Squirrel Whisperer." Patrick Logsdon is able to bend small fluffy rodents to his will, but does not use this power for evil. In the remainder of his time, he is a web and graphic designer and a Certified Usability Analyst.

Susan Tatsui-D’Arcy is the director at Merit Academy, college advisor at Merit Educational Consultants, LLC, and advisor at Kids 4 Hydrogen.  She guides and organizes Kids 4 Hydrogen team members to ensure that all events and activities are successful.  Susan has worked with hundreds of students as they define and launch their projects. In addition to writing Beat the College Admissions Game: Do a Project!, she has written several books on education, parenting, and time management.

Other Ways You Can Help
Can't make a donation?  Don't worry; you can still contribute to the cause!

Sign our Hydrogen Car Waitlist to show your interest:

      http://kids4hydrogen.org/hydrogen-cars/get-on-t...

Sign our petition to contact California lawmakers:

      http://signon.org/s/fcTxFn

Share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter!

Learn more at http://kids4hydrogen.org/


Thank you for your interest and support!
