story:
By funding this project you are supporting an investigation into conservation and reclamation of contaminated ecosystems.  I will adapt medical protocols, now used to observe human disease progression, to be indicators of ecosystem health. 



Toxic mining effluent exits a drainage pipe and enters the North Fork of Clear Creek 50 miles west of Denver, Colorado. 


Over 200 human diseases have been linked to oxidative stress.[1]  In healthy organisms, oxidants and antioxidants are balanced.  However, oxidative stress occurs when that balance shifts towards oxidants.[1,2] As a consequence, there are accelerated rates of free radical generation that leads to both targeted and indiscriminant cellular injury.[1,2,3,4]  Many pollutants, including metals, cause disease through mechanisms involving oxidative stress.[1,4]

Protein oxidation by free radicals is a particularly important mediator of cellular damage.[1,2,3,5] As a result, doctors and medical researchers are beginning to measure the ‘fingerprints’ of protein oxidation as indicators of disease progression in cancers, Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, and other diseases.[1,2,3,5,6] Although the oxidation warning signal does not specifically tell physicians which disease a patient is liable to be afflicted with, they alert of worsening health and the need for close observation. Thus, treatment can be implemented before the full onset of a patient’s symptoms.[3]  So far, these warnings, which also occur in plants, animals and insects, have not been adequately utilized in environmental monitoring.

This project will explore protein carbonylation, the most common and well studied fingerprint of protein oxidation, by using a commercially-available, enzyme-linked immunosorbant assay (ELISA).[3,4]  Because protein carbonylation correlates with human disease progression, this assay may also prove to be useful for monitoring disease status in plants, animals and insects. 



A toxicologist collects toxic mining effluent from a drainage pipe for use in this experiment.


The groundwork for this project has been completed.  At Colorado State University’s Artificial Stream Laboratory, a precise exposure scenario was carried out; native insects, gathered from local rivers, were exposed to various concentrations of toxic metal rich mining effluent collected directly from the pollution source.  Water chemistry was meticulously tested and insect respiration rates were tracked.  Once the exposures were complete, insect samples were preserved by flash freezing in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80˚C. The next step is to measure protein carbonylation, to correlate metals exposure to their toxic effects.

Please support this project, which applies tools used for monitoring human disease progression to monitoring pollutant-impacted ecosystems. 


Budget:

(6) OxiSelect™ Protein Carbonyl ELISA Kits = $2900

OxiSelect™ Protein Carbonyl Spectrophotometric Assay Kit $360

Coomassie (Bradford) Protein Assay Kit $100

Protease Inhibitor Cocktail =$155

Miscellaneous reagents and laboratory supplies = $250

Incidentals = $500

Taxes and shipping costs = $400

Credit card/PayPal and Indiegogo fees (if funding goal of $5000 is reached) = $450

Total = $5115


Notice the red staining caused by metal deposition from mining pollution at one of our study sites on the North Fork of Clear Creek.  


Below, frequently asked questions are answered in the context of this proposal: 

Who is conducting this research?

  • My name is Sam Duggan and I am a graduate student studying environmental contaminants at Colorado State University.  I have degrees in Molecular Biology and Ecology, but importantly I have substantial experience working on pristine and impacted ecosystems.  In recent years, I have focused on developing the laboratory skills required to take a biomedical approach to the conservation and repair of polluted ecosystems.  I am participating in a multi-institute, interdisciplinary study on the effects of toxic metals to aquatic ecosystems.  The larger project includes a team of graduate students, toxicologists, chemists, public health officials and additional stakeholders. Because consent has not been given from the supporting institution for this particular funding opportunity, the exact programs nor a full list of collaborators can be named at this time.
Why use insects?
  • The importance of insects to the structure and function of ecosystems cannot be overstated.  Insects are a critical connection between primary producers and top predators.  They act as a food source to higher organisms, but also as cleaning crews recycling decaying matter.  They are often the last to be extirpated from contaminated sites and first to recolonize once conditions improve.   Because of these reasons (and others), insects are very useful for monitoring environmental change.        
What are proteins?
  • Proteins are the building blocks of life.  Proteins act as components of cellular architecture, messengers, and healers, but also as a cellular weapons and a policing force.  They have very specific structures that correspond with a very specific function.  When protein structure is compromised by free radicals then protein function is also compromised. 
What is pollution?
  • Pollution can be almost anything. This is the exact reason pollution is so difficult for lawmakers to regulate and why prevention is challenging.  Pollution is any substance occurring at a concentration high enough to be harmful to life, or to cause a shift in the balance of ecosystems.  Pollutants range from highly toxic cyanide (used in gold mining) and certain pesticides which can directly lead to death, to less toxic nitrogen and phosphorous compounds produced by sewage and agricultural run-off.
What is environmental change?
  • Environmental change is merely a change in conditions of the environment.  Whether due to  natural disaster, pollution, epidemic, climate, development or invasive species, environmental change is becoming increasing common in our human dominated world. 
What is a free radical?
  • A free radical is an extremely reactive molecule containing electrons in unstable arrangements.  These unstable electrons seek stability by any means necessary.  In order to achieve stability they react in a rampaging frenzy with the body’s cellular machinery (including membranes, proteins and DNA) causing harm to delicately balanced cellular processes. 
Where do free radicals come from?
  • Some free radicals are natural.  They are the bi-products of normal processes including cells producing energy from food.  Over one's lifetime, free radical damage increases during the normal aging process due, in part, to the bodies deteriorating antioxidant defense system.  However, large quantities of free-radicals can be produced by pathogens, radiation and exposure to toxins.  Natural and unnatural damage by free radicals is a leading theory for why all organisms age (some prematurely) and eventually die. 
What is toxicity?
  • Toxicity is a somewhat abstract concept, although it can be simplified for our purposes as the quantity of a substance required to damage an organism. 

Those who have additional questions are encouraged to contact me at sambduggan@gmail.com

References:

1.  Fedorova, M., R. C. Bollineni, and R. Hoffmann. "Protein Carbonylation as a Major Hallmark of Oxidative Damage: Update of Analytical Strategies." Mass Spectrometry Reviews 33.2 (2014): 79-97.

2.  Dalle-Donne, I., R. Rossi, D.Giustarini, A. Milzani, R Colombo, "Protein Carbonyl Groups as Biomarkers of Oxidative Stress." Clinica Chimica Acta 329.1-2 (2003): 23-38.

3.  Dalle-Donne, I., D. Giustarini, R. Colombo, R. Rossi, A. Milzani. "Protein Carbonylation in Human Diseases." Trends in Molecular Medicine 9.4 (2003): 169-76.

4.  Moller, I. M., A. Rogowska-Wrzesinska, and R. S. P. Rao. "Protein Carbonylation and Metal-Catalyzed Protein Oxidation in a Cellular Perspective." Journal of Proteomics 74.11 (2011): 2228-42.Bottom of Form

5.  Wehr, N., R. Levine. “Quantification of Protein Carbonylation.” Methods in Molecular Biology 965 (2013): 265-81.

6.  Baraibar, M. A., R. Ladouce, and B. Friguet. "Proteomic Quantification and Identification of Carbonylated Proteins Upon Oxidative Stress and During Cellular Aging." Journal of Proteomics 92 (2013): 63-70.
story_txt:
By funding this project you are supporting an investigation
into conservation and reclamation of contaminated ecosystems.  I will adapt medical protocols, now used to
observe human disease progression, to be indicators of ecosystem health. 


Toxic mining effluent exits a drainage pipe and enters the North Fork of Clear Creek 50 miles west of Denver, Colorado. Over 200 human diseases have been linked to oxidative stress.[1]  In healthy organisms, oxidants and
antioxidants are balanced.  However,
oxidative stress occurs when that balance shifts towards oxidants.[1,2]
As a consequence, there are accelerated rates of free radical generation that
leads to both targeted and indiscriminant cellular injury.[1,2,3,4]  Many pollutants, including metals, cause
disease through mechanisms involving oxidative stress.[1,4]
Protein oxidation by free radicals is a particularly
important mediator of cellular damage.[1,2,3,5] As a result, doctors and medical researchers are beginning
to measure the ‘fingerprints’ of protein oxidation as indicators of disease
progression in cancers, Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, and other diseases.[1,2,3,5,6]
Although the oxidation warning signal does not specifically tell physicians which
disease a patient is liable to be afflicted with, they alert of worsening
health and the need for close observation. Thus, treatment can
be implemented before the full onset of a patient’s symptoms.[3]  So far, these warnings, which also occur
in plants, animals and insects, have not been adequately utilized in
environmental monitoring. 
This project will explore protein
carbonylation, the most common and well studied fingerprint of protein
oxidation, by using a commercially-available, enzyme-linked immunosorbant assay
(ELISA).[3,4]  Because protein
carbonylation correlates with human disease progression, this assay may also prove
to be useful for monitoring disease status in plants, animals and insects. 


A toxicologist collects toxic mining effluent from a drainage pipe for use in this experiment.


The groundwork for this project has
been completed.  At Colorado State
University’s Artificial Stream Laboratory, a precise exposure scenario was
carried out; native insects, gathered from local rivers, were exposed to
various concentrations of toxic metal rich mining effluent collected directly
from the pollution source.  Water
chemistry was meticulously tested and insect respiration rates were
tracked.  Once the exposures were
complete, insect samples were preserved by flash freezing in liquid nitrogen
and stored at -80˚C. The next step is to measure protein carbonylation, to
correlate metals exposure to their toxic effects.
Please support this project, which applies tools used for monitoring human disease
progression to monitoring pollutant-impacted ecosystems.  

Budget:
(6) OxiSelect™ Protein Carbonyl ELISA Kits = $2900
OxiSelect™ Protein
Carbonyl Spectrophotometric Assay Kit $360
Coomassie (Bradford)
Protein Assay Kit $100
Protease Inhibitor
Cocktail =$155 
Miscellaneous reagents
and laboratory supplies = $250
Incidentals = $500
Taxes and shipping costs = $400
Credit card/PayPal and Indiegogo fees (if funding
goal of $5000 is reached) = $450
Total = $5115
Notice the red staining caused by metal deposition from mining pollution at one of our study sites on the North Fork of Clear Creek.  Below, frequently asked questions are answered in the context of this
proposal: 
Who is conducting this research?


My name is Sam Duggan and I am a graduate student studying environmental contaminants at Colorado State University.  I have degrees in Molecular Biology and Ecology, but importantly I have substantial experience working on pristine and impacted ecosystems.  In recent years, I have focused on developing the laboratory skills required to take a biomedical approach to the conservation and repair of polluted ecosystems.  I am participating in a multi-institute, interdisciplinary study on the effects of toxic metals to aquatic ecosystems.  The larger project includes a team of graduate students, toxicologists, chemists, public health officials and additional stakeholders. Because consent has not
been given from the supporting institution for this particular funding opportunity,
the exact programs nor a full list of collaborators can be named at this time.
Why use insects?
The importance of insects to the structure and function of ecosystems cannot be overstated.  Insects are a critical connection between primary producers and top predators.  They act as a food source to higher organisms, but also as cleaning crews recycling decaying matter.  They are often the last to be extirpated from contaminated sites and first to recolonize once conditions improve.   Because of these reasons (and others), insects are very useful for monitoring environmental change.        

What are proteins?Proteins are the building
blocks of life.  Proteins act as components of cellular
architecture, messengers, and healers, but also as a cellular weapons and a
policing force.  They have very specific
structures that correspond with a very specific function.  When protein structure is compromised by
free radicals then protein function is also compromised.  
What is pollution? Pollution can be almost
anything. This is the exact reason
pollution is so difficult for lawmakers to regulate and why
prevention is challenging. 
Pollution is any substance occurring at a concentration high enough to
be harmful to life, or to cause a shift in the balance of ecosystems.   Pollutants range from highly
toxic cyanide (used in gold mining) and certain pesticides which can directly
lead to death, to less toxic nitrogen and phosphorous compounds produced
by sewage and agricultural run-off. 
What is environmental change?Environmental change is merely
a change in conditions of the environment.  Whether due to  natural disaster, pollution, epidemic, climate, development or invasive species, environmental change
is becoming increasing common in our human dominated world.  What is a free radical? A free radical is an extremely
reactive molecule containing electrons in unstable arrangements.  These unstable electrons seek stability by
any means necessary.  In order to achieve stability they react in a rampaging
frenzy with the body’s cellular machinery (including membranes, proteins and
DNA) causing harm to delicately balanced cellular processes.  Where do free radicals come from? Some free radicals are
natural.  They are the bi-products of normal processes including cells
producing energy from food.  Over one's lifetime, free radical damage increases during the
normal aging process due, in part, to the bodies deteriorating antioxidant
defense system.  However, large quantities of free-radicals can be
produced by pathogens, radiation and exposure to toxins.  Natural and
unnatural damage by free radicals is a leading theory for why all organisms age
(some prematurely) and eventually die. What is toxicity? Toxicity is a somewhat
abstract concept, although it can be simplified for our purposes as the
quantity of a substance required to damage an organism. 

Those who have additional questions are encouraged to contact me at sambduggan@gmail.com


References:

1.  Fedorova, M., R. C. Bollineni, and R. Hoffmann.
"Protein Carbonylation as a Major Hallmark of Oxidative Damage: Update of
Analytical Strategies." Mass Spectrometry Reviews 33.2
(2014): 79-97.
2.  Dalle-Donne, I., R. Rossi, D.Giustarini, A. Milzani, R Colombo, "Protein Carbonyl Groups as Biomarkers of
Oxidative Stress." Clinica Chimica Acta 329.1-2 (2003):
23-38.
3.  Dalle-Donne, I., D. Giustarini, R. Colombo, R.
Rossi, A. Milzani. "Protein Carbonylation in Human Diseases." Trends
in Molecular Medicine 9.4 (2003): 169-76. 
4.  Moller, I. M., A. Rogowska-Wrzesinska, and R. S.
P. Rao. "Protein Carbonylation and Metal-Catalyzed Protein Oxidation in a
Cellular Perspective." Journal of Proteomics 74.11
(2011): 2228-42.Bottom of
Form
5. 
Wehr, N., R. Levine. “Quantification of Protein Carbonylation.” Methods in Molecular Biology 965 (2013):
265-81.
6.  Baraibar, M. A., R. Ladouce, and B. Friguet.
"Proteomic Quantification and Identification of Carbonylated Proteins Upon
Oxidative Stress and During Cellular Aging." Journal of
Proteomics 92 (2013): 63-70.

story:
Dear Children of Mother Earth and Father Sky,

My name is Elouise Brown, I am from the Navajo Nation, NM, US. My volunteer work is very important to the environment, all living species and human health.

In 2006, I have learned that there was a 3rd coal-fired power plant being proposed on the Navajo Reservation. I just had to stand-up to the proponents to stop them from progressing with their plans of this 1500 megawatt coal-fired power plant (desert rock power plant). There were already two coal-fired power plants approximately 15 miles apart next to where they wanted to build this so called desert rock. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RdbqkNu6UVM&lis...

For many years, the communities near these power plants have been and are very ill with respiratory ailments of some sort and many have developed cancer illnesses.

I just couldn’t let Sithe Global, LLC. continue to add more deadly pollution that caused health problems for the communities.

Two in a half years later, along with many support from others, we managed to successfully stop the proposal of desert rock power plant. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FjSlKyb3L0A

Afterwards I have noticed that our campaign was much bigger than that……… so to this day, we continue to protect Mother Earth and Father Sky. We now travel to various locations to educate, protest, speak or physically help where environmental organizations  or any groups call us.

We need your financial help to continue our volunteer work.

Thank you in advance for your contribution.


Elouise Brown,

505-592-1453

thebrownmachine@hotmail.com

story:
Who we are and what is our Mission:  

 We are Integrity Waste - Ron, Rick, Joby, Angela and Beth. Five people that are excited and motivated to make a difference. With your help we can do it! LET'S GO!

Our Vision: TO CHANGE THE WORLD, ONE COMPOST PAIL AT A TIME. 

We see a future of greener communities & a lower trash footprint. We want to encourage and make it easier for everybody to get on board of the GREEN cycle: REDUCE, REUSE, RECYCLE! We dream of a healthier Earth! 

Our Mission: GET A COMPOST PAIL INTO THE HANDS OF EVERY SINGLE APARTMENT RESIDENT!

Our main tool: what makes the difference is our focus on EDUCATION: We will teach and advocate on the importance of composting. We will educate the residents on everything from what to compost to how they are helping change the world through their efforts. They will simply put their full compost pail on their doorstep and we will pick it up and take it to places that will responsibly compost this waste. The best part is, once composted, this waste is turned into rich soil that can be used to grow more food.

Why compost and what's the environmental impact if we don't: 

Did you know that more than half of the waste in your kitchen trash can consists of “organic waste” such as fruit & vegetable scraps, coffee grinds, soiled paper towels, and bread, just to name a few?

Compostable organics make up about 30% of the waste stream in California, contributing over 12 million tons annually to our state's landfills. In landfills, this material undergoes anaerobic decomposition and produces significant quantities of methane, up to 80% of which is not captured by a landfill gas system.  Composting is a fundamentally aerobic process and well managed facilities do not produce any methane. This has a substantial impact on greenhouse gas reduction because methane is up to 21 times worse than carbon dioxide to the environment.

Landfills are currently filling up at an unsustainable speed.  In 2000, nearly 100 landfills had to close because they were filled.  It has been estimated that within the next 50 years or so the majority of our landfills will have reached maximum capacity.  Integrity Waste wants to change this and you can help us! 

What we've done and what we need:  

We currently service more than 1200 residents in California and have successfully diverted thousands of tons of waste from the landfills. Integrity Waste has educated these residents on what they can compost, we pick it up from their doorstep, and take it to composting centers and local farmers. There is so much more we need to do and so many more people to educate on how this small change in behavior can change the world. 

Yet, we're a startup and we want to grow organically. We really need your help to reach further and keep making Compost available and easy to all.  

Your contribution will help:

-purchase more compost pails

-fund community outreach / education sessions

-purchase vehicles needed to transport the organic waste from the properties to     proper recycling/composting centers (including local farms)

A donation of $25 will divert about 2 tons of food waste from the landfills in 1 year.  

A donation of $50 will divert about 5 tons of food waste from the landfills in 1 year.

A donation of $100 will divert about 12 tons of food waste from the landfills in 1 year. 

Other ways you can help: 

Grassroots movement - SHARE THIS with your family and friends! Many people don't know that it takes small steps to make a difference: simply discarding breakfast leftovers into the green pail can divert excess waste from going to our landfills. Let's get this information viral and make a difference! Let's get the social media machine rolling and change the world!!!

FYI: 

Below is a very helpful infographic from missmodish.com that gives a basic breakdown of what you can include in the compost pail:

story:
Le projet Jardin de rue

C'est un projet qui vise à restaurer des espaces qui sont asphaltés en espaces verts à Montréal. Dans la vidéo, vous pouvez voir plusieurs exemples de ce que notre organisme a pu faire durant les trois dernières années. On peut voir l'amélioration des jardins communautaires, des toits blanc, des pistes cyclables et surtout des 4 nouveaux kilomètres de jardins de rue. Ces nouveaux espaces ont contribué à améliorer la qualité de vie des gens qui habitent dans les secteurs transformés. Entre autres, le projet permet de :

  • Réduire le déneigement (sels de déneigement, machinerie, etc.)
  • Réduire les infiltrations d'eau dans les sous-sols
  • Faire disparaître des îlots de chaleur urbains
  • Améliorer la qualité de l'air, de l'eau à Montréal
  • Embellir le quartier

Tous ces efforts sont faits par une équipe de bénévoles. Aucun n'est rémunéré !

Ce dont nous avons besoin

Nous avons besoin de financement afin de :

  • Louer des marteaux-piqueurs et des brouettes qui nous aideront dans notre tâche 
  • Acheter de la terre en grande quantité pour remplir les trous
  • Acheter des arbres et des arbustes
Notre budget est surveillé par la Ville de Montréal et les surplus sont remis dans un compte pour l'an prochain (ça ne nous est jamais arrivé, on est toujours dans le rouge !)

Vos dons font toute la différence pour notre projet. Sans ces derniers, nous ne pouvons louer les outils nécessaires et notre travail est considérablement plus difficile. Il est certains que nous ferons moins de plantations d'arbres sans l'argent pour les acheter ou pour louer l'équipement pour les planter.

Au nom de l'équipe, je vous remercie énormément pour votre aide et votre soutien ! 

Laurent Richer (Coordonnateur / Fondateur)

story:
Akwamag in the News: 

Link: Akwamag in Yahoo! Finance

Link: "Salty, hard water? Akwamag wants to soften things up" 

Link: "New Magnetic Water Softening Solution is Effective and Sustainable"


More Links on Akwamag in the news: Sacramento Business Journal -- Sacramento Bee -- Broadway World.com (BWW Geeks)    


Elevator Pitch - The Short Version

Eco-friendly, Affordable, Effective Water Softening

Akwamag is empowering consumers with better choices for a highly effective water softener that requires no salt change-outs and no maintenance.

We've seen the scale damage done


Today’s Homeowner Hard Water Challenge:

  • Hard water scale damages pipes and home appliances, and creates unsightly scale on fixtures, dishes and shower glass.
  • Current solutions require too much maintenance, are expensive and damage our already fragile clean-water sources with salt pollution.

How Akwamag Can Help:

  • No maintenance& easy installation
  • Inexpensive to own & operate (100% more affordable than the average water softener!)
  • Highly effective
  • Saves water & protects the environment—no salt needed

Why We’re Bringing Akwamag to Indiegogo:

We need your help to go into production to bring this award-winning product to market!

The Akwamag is backed by a strong team, including partners from NASA-Ames, San Jose State University and expert advisors.  With your support, we can establish ourselves and compete with current large manufacturers who produce ineffective, costly, polluting solutions. Help us give homeowners a better answer to hard water! #Nomorehardwater

  •                                                                                                                                       AKWAMAG INSTALLATION IS EASY! Akwamag Design Engineer, Rich Schmidt, shows you how to do the installation. Please check our media gallery for the installation video clip or click here to view.

                                                                                                                                                                    

    Let's Talk Detail - The Long Version:

    The Hard Water Challenge:

      • Homeowners dealing with hard water suffer from scale damage to pipes,endure the degradation of water heaters and other cope with mineral deposits on dishes, shower doors and plumbing fixtures.
      • Current water softeners are either expensive, minimally effective, or require regular salt replenishment.
      • Regular maintenance of salt-based softeners is costly and requires a huge amount of personal effort--lugging salt bags around, changing them out and using water to flush the excess brine.
      • Current salt-based solutions create a brine by-product that pollutes our water: local municipalities aren’t able to filter it out of at the waste water treatment plants.


    How Akwamag Can Help:

    The Akwamag uses High Intensity Multipass™ magnetic technology (patent pending) to:

      • Soften water at an unlimited capacity while requiring no maintenance
      • Protect the environment (and relieve your back muscles) by eliminating salt changes and brine dumping.
      • Yes, “High Intensity Multipass™ magnetic technology” is as cool as it sounds! And, it was developed by Tuyen Vo, a scientist and our founder.
      • It’s more affordable, effective, and eco-friendly than any water softener in the market.


    Glamor Shot of an Akwamag Waiting for Installation:

    We've seen the scale and damage done

    Hard water left untreated can cause scale build-up on plumbing fixtures, which requires extra effort and wasted water to clean off. Scale build-up can clog water pipes and shorten the life of your home appliances. This leads to added cost, maintenance, and is a major inconvenience. And it's everywhere.                                 


    Akwamag replaces salt softeners and improves the environment

    So, why does anyone still buy salt-resin water softeners?

    We’re not sure. They probably haven’t heard about Akwamag yet. If you’re using a salt-based water softener, you’re likely dealing with some of these issues:

      • It requires constant salt feeding which is a hassle.
      • It consumes salt and water, which both cost money.  According to the US Environmental Protection Agency, salt-softeners consume as much as 800 pounds of salts and 24,000 gallons of water a year. Read more about it, here! That water utilization is equivalent to 2-months use per year. And here! An additional 10-25% more water is wasted due to unnecessary rinsing.
      • It releases a brine solution into the sewer, creating environment problems.

    Unfortunately, other available softeners like reverse osmosis, activated carbon, nanocrystal-seeding, and strapped-on magnets are either very expensive or ineffective.  There has not been a breakthrough water softener design that is both inexpensive and effective in the last 30 years. It’s time to move this industry forward!

    Geek Out — The Science Behind Akwamag:

    Magnetic water softening has been widely studied by scientists. Applied effectively, it induces the crystallization of calcium and magnesium salts, and prevents them from scaling or fouling. It is game-changing because it softens water without the discharge of brine solution or salt, and has unlimited capacity.

    The Akwamag was developed from a deep understanding of magnetohydrodynamics (the interaction between magnets and moving water). Our proprietary High Intensity Multipass™ magnetic technology converts dissolved lime-scale into a structure that is easily and safely removed from your water fixtures.


    ____________________________________________________________________

    Go, Akwamag, go! Performance Details:

    Microscopic view (200X optical microscope images)

    The image on the left shows scaling effects, which are the results of untreated hard water. The image on the right shows water that has been treated by the Akwamag. This scale forms a different crystal structure that is easily broken down, and will not clog or damage your water fixtures.

    Macroscopic appearances

    The differences below are visible to the naked eye. There are no unsightly, difficult-to-clean stains on water fixtures when using the Akwamag.


    Who We’re Working With:
    Akwamag is partnered with NASA - Ames Research Center and San Jose State University, and is negotiating a partnership with WETSUS to take the technology even further, from home to industrial use and potentially to the space station to address fouling problems in water lines.                                                                                  

                                                                   

                                                                                                                                         As a result of AkwaMag’s technological breakthrough, it was chosen as a Semifinalist in the CleanTech Open 2013 Competition. Now, we need your help to make it a market success! Please help supporting our eco-friendly solution.           

    Team Akwamag  

    Akwamag was invented by Tuyen Vo, who has developed multiple products, some of which are award-winning and industry-standard. Its progress is under the guidance of advisers with excellent track records in science and business. Team Akwamag includes the following (our names link to our LinkedIn profiles):


    Tuyen Vo                            Rick Quan                  Rich Schmidt


    Dr. John Crockett            Chuck Erickson              Dr. Friedemann Freund


    Marc Gottschalk             Dick Jacquet                   Steve Payne


    Dr. Bradley Stone


    Your Contributions

    Thank you for taking the time to learn more about the Akwamag. If we’ve inspired you, please help us get the Akwamag to market.

    Bonus: Act fast--the "early birds" will receive our Akwamag Filtration system at no cost (a $300 value). All contributors will be listed on our website honoring each and every person who helps us reach our goal!

    1.   VIP Supporter ($1 donation): We really appreciate your support. Please help all of us save water: tell your friends about the Akwamag.

    2.   Honorary Supporter ($20 donation): We’ll send you note a personal thank you note from our founding team for your support.

    3.   Sand & Chlorine Filtration Unit ($199 donation): We’ll send you a thank you note from our founding team for your support, Akwamag  filtration system  reduces sediment and chlorine for the whole house while improving taste and odor. Bid farewell to chlorine!

    4.   Compact Unit ($250 donation): We’ll send you a thank you note from our founding team for your support, Akwamag compact system (good for a household of 2). You save 30% off MSRP, and $150 off current market price. Get ready for no more hard water! 5.   Early Adopter –Standard Unit ($350 donation): We’ll send you a thank you note from our founding team for your support, and an Akwamag standard system and filtration system ($750 off MSRP, and $850 off current market price). We’re thrilled that you’ll be one of our early customers!

    6.   Standard Unit – Firm Believer ($599 donation): We’ll send you a thank you note from our founding team for your support, Akwamag standard system (good for a family of 4). You save 30% off MSRP, and $250 off current market price. Be ready to say goodbye to water scale! Please add $100USD for shipping outside the US

    7.   Kindred Spirit ($3,000 donation): We’ll send you a thank you note from our founding team for your support, list your name on our website's platinum supporters, and donate an installation to the site of your choice such as a church, school or recreation center. We can’t thank you enough, but we’ll try. We’re so grateful for your support!

    Please note: Shipping cost is additional and provided at cost.  The Akwamag is designed for easy installation by DIY-ers. However, upon your request, we will search for a licensed plumber in your area and arrange a schedule between you (homeowner) and the plumber.


    System Costs and Specifications

    Akwamag PlusTM  Compact system: $350.00 MSRP.
    Designed for two people. Performs similar or better than the entry-level salt-resin softener GE GXSF30V, Whirlpool WHES30 models (which costs $400).

    Akwamag PlusTM  Standard system: $800 MSRP.
    Designed for a family of four. Performs similar or better than the salt-resin softener GE GXSH45V, Whirlpool WHES48 models (which cost $850).

    AkwaMag Filtration system: $300 

    Designed for the whole house. Reduces sediment and chlorine while improving taste and odor. It performs similar or better than a 2-stage filter Isopure ISO-WH2-20B, Perfect Water Technologies HMF2SdgC models (which cost $379).

    ____________________________________________________________________

    Risks

    Prototype stage

    Akwamag is a prototype that has been tested successfully at a number of locations utilizing municipal water supply. However, we can not guarantee that the early products will work under all water conditions and will be error free and long-lived, though our intention is to build a long-lasting and reliable product with components that are robust. 

    Delivery time

    Our aim is to deliver all products ordered in this campaign in July 2014 with priority given to each donor in order of donation. 

    Warranty
    We warrant the product (parts and labor) for three (3) years of operation under normal operating conditions.  All claims will be reviewed and required authorization by Akwamag. Donor will be responsible for return expenses. Warranty claims will result in product repair or replacement at our expense including return delivery.
story_txt:
Akwamag in the News: Link: Akwamag in Yahoo! FinanceLink: "Salty, hard water? Akwamag wants to soften things up" Link: "New Magnetic Water Softening Solution is Effective and Sustainable" More Links on Akwamag in the news: Sacramento Business Journal -- Sacramento Bee -- Broadway World.com (BWW Geeks)     Elevator Pitch - The Short Version 


Eco-friendly, Affordable, Effective Water SofteningAkwamag is empowering consumers with better
choices for a highly effective water softener that requires no salt change-outs
and no maintenance.We've seen the scale damage done
Today’s Homeowner Hard Water Challenge:

Hard
     water scale damages pipes and home appliances, and creates unsightly scale
     on fixtures, dishes and shower glass.
Current
     solutions require too much maintenance, are expensive and damage our
     already fragile clean-water sources with salt pollution.
How Akwamag Can Help:

No maintenance& easy installation
Inexpensive to own & operate (100% more affordable
     than the average water softener!)
Highly effective 
Saves water & protects the environment—no salt
     needed
Why We’re Bringing Akwamag to Indiegogo:
We need your help to go into
production to bring this award-winning product to market!

The Akwamag is backed by a strong team, including
partners from NASA-Ames, San Jose State University and expert advisors.  With your support, we can establish ourselves
and compete with current large manufacturers who produce ineffective, costly,
polluting solutions. Help us give homeowners a better answer to hard water!
#Nomorehardwater
                                                                                                                                      AKWAMAG INSTALLATION IS EASY! Akwamag Design Engineer, Rich Schmidt, shows you how to do the installation. Please check our media gallery for the installation video clip or click here to view.
                                                                                                                                                                 
Let's Talk Detail - The Long Version:


The
Hard Water Challenge:

Homeowners dealing with hard water suffer from scale
      damage to pipes,endure the degradation of water heaters and other cope
      with mineral deposits on dishes, shower doors and plumbing fixtures.
Current water softeners are either expensive,
      minimally effective, or require regular salt replenishment.
Regular maintenance of salt-based softeners is costly
      and requires a huge amount of personal effort--lugging salt bags around, changing
      them out and using water to flush the excess brine.
Current salt-based solutions create a brine by-product
      that pollutes our water: local municipalities aren’t able to filter it
      out of at the waste water treatment plants. 


How Akwamag Can Help:
The Akwamag uses High Intensity Multipass™ magnetic technology (patent pending) to:

Soften water at an unlimited capacity while requiring
      no maintenance
Protect the environment (and relieve your back
      muscles) by eliminating salt changes and brine dumping.
Yes, “High Intensity Multipass™ magnetic technology”
      is as cool as it sounds! And, it was developed by Tuyen Vo, a scientist
      and our founder.
It’s more affordable, effective, and eco-friendly than
      any water softener in the market.


Glamor Shot of an Akwamag Waiting for Installation:








We've seen the scale and damage done

Hard water left untreated can cause scale build-up on plumbing fixtures, which requires extra effort and wasted water to clean off. Scale build-up can clog water pipes and shorten the life of your home appliances. This leads to added cost, maintenance, and is a major inconvenience. And it's everywhere.                                  


Akwamag replaces salt softeners and improves the environment


So, why does anyone still buy salt-resin
water softeners? 


We’re not
sure. They probably haven’t heard about Akwamag yet. If you’re using a
salt-based water softener, you’re likely dealing with some of these issues:

It requires constant salt feeding which is a hassle.
It consumes salt and water, which both cost
      money.  According to the US Environmental Protection Agency, salt-softeners
      consume as much as 800 pounds of salts and 24,000 gallons of water a
      year. Read more about it, here! That water utilization is equivalent to
      2-months use per year. And here! An additional 10-25% more water is wasted
      due to unnecessary rinsing.
It releases a brine solution into the sewer, creating
      environment problems.

Unfortunately,
other available softeners like reverse osmosis, activated carbon, nanocrystal-seeding,
and strapped-on magnets are either very expensive or ineffective.  There
has not been a breakthrough water softener design that is both inexpensive and
effective in the last 30 years. It’s time to move this industry forward! 
Geek
Out — The Science Behind Akwamag:
Magnetic water softening has been
widely studied by scientists. Applied effectively, it induces the
crystallization of calcium and magnesium salts, and prevents them from scaling
or fouling. It is game-changing because it softens water without the discharge
of brine solution or salt, and has unlimited capacity. 


The Akwamag
was developed from a deep understanding of magnetohydrodynamics (the
interaction between magnets and moving water). Our proprietary High Intensity
Multipass™ magnetic technology converts dissolved lime-scale into a structure
that is easily and safely removed from your water fixtures.

____________________________________________________________________
Go, Akwamag, go! Performance Details:

Microscopic view (200X optical microscope images)
The image on the left shows scaling effects, which are the results of untreated hard water. The image on the right shows water that has been treated by the Akwamag. This scale forms a different crystal structure that is easily broken down, and will not clog or damage your water fixtures.

Macroscopic appearances 


The differences below are visible to the
naked eye. There are no unsightly, difficult-to-clean stains on water
fixtures when using the Akwamag.


Who We’re Working With:Akwamag is partnered with NASA - Ames Research Center and San Jose State University, and is negotiating a 
partnership with WETSUS to take the technology even further, from home 
to industrial use and
potentially to the space station to address fouling problems in water
lines.                                                                                                                                                    
                                                                                                                                      As a
result of AkwaMag’s technological breakthrough, it was chosen as a Semifinalist
in the CleanTech Open 2013 Competition. Now, we need
your help to make it a market success! Please help supporting our eco-friendly
solution.            
Team Akwamag   


Akwamag was invented by Tuyen Vo, who has developed multiple products, some of which are award-winning and industry-standard. Its progress is under the
guidance of advisers with excellent track records in science and business. Team
Akwamag includes the following (our names link to our LinkedIn profiles):
Tuyen Vo                            Rick Quan                  Rich SchmidtDr. John Crockett            Chuck Erickson              Dr. Friedemann FreundMarc Gottschalk             Dick Jacquet                   Steve PayneDr. Bradley Stone
Your Contributions


Thank you for taking the time to learn more about the
Akwamag. If we’ve inspired you, please help us get the Akwamag to market. 
Bonus: Act
fast--the "early birds" will receive our Akwamag Filtration system
at no cost (a $300 value). All contributors will be listed on our website
honoring each and every person who helps us reach our goal!

Supporter ($1 donation): We really appreciate your support. Please help all of us save water: tell your friends about the Akwamag.

from our founding team for your support.

hard water!

note from our founding team for your support, and an Akwamag standard system
and filtration system ($750 off MSRP, and $850 off current market price). We’re thrilled that you’ll
be one of our early customers! 

6.   Standard Unit – Firm

from our founding team for your support, Akwamag standard system (good for a
family of 4). You save 30% off MSRP, and $250 off current market price. Be

7.   Kindred

We’re so grateful for your support! 

Please note: Shipping cost is
additional and provided at cost.  The Akwamag is designed for easy installation
by DIY-ers. However, upon your request, we will search for a licensed plumber

System Costs and Specifications

story:
Short Summary

I wanted to do something to raise awareness for Earth Day, improve the environtment, and raise some funds as well. So, together we can  contribute to the Nature Conservancey to raise funds for their Plant a Billion Trees program to restore the Brazilian Atlantic Rain forest and you can have a reward for helping ! 

I have fond memories of trees as a child. While my grandparents lived in the city, I often helped my Grandfather in his garden. It was hard work pulling weeds and I did not always enjoy it, but I learned many life lessons during that time with my Grandfather.

One summer, I was eating a peach and I wondered out loud if this peach seed would grow if we planted it. My grandfather and I went out to the side yard and planted the peach seed together that same day.

I moved away for several years and returned to visit and noticed a new tree in the yard. I had forgotten about the peach tree. My Grandmother told me it was the peach tree that Pop and I had planted years ago. And that he had diligently cared for the tree to ensure it's growth. 

Today, as a Father, I often remind my kids that it is my job to help them grow tall, strong, and straight like a tree trunk as my grandparents did for me.

If you have a fondness for trees, family, and mother earth as I do; choose your level of support and together we will plant many trees this Earth Day and celebrate the global human family.

 

What We Need & What You Get

I am donating 10% of everything raised to the Nature Conservancy to plant trees in the Brazillian Rain forest. We will plant at least ONE tree for each person that contributes to the campaign. 

In return for your contribution, you will recieve BRANDED merchandise for this EARTH DAY with a LOGO that I had professionally designed  !

 

The LOGO says "I made a difference!" and has the words EARTH DAY 2013 around the globe with a tree growing. AWESOME.

 

If you like the campaign LOGO, it can be YOURS printed on your choice of a certificate, mouse pad, shoppping bag, or a T-shirt for a reasonalbe donation. 

1. For a $9 contriubtion, you will get a PDF certificate personalized with your name and the campaign logo.

2. For $14 you will get a mouse pad made from recyclable materials AND the LOGO on it. 

3. For a $19 contribution, you will get a simple white canvas shopping bag with the LOGO.

4. For $27, you can have a T-Shirt with the LOGO showing that you made a difference this Earth Day. (Large Size Only)

5. Finally, for just $57, you can get ALL FOUR items with LOGO and celebrate the importance of trees this Earth Day. 

 

The Impact

We all know the benefits of planting more trees. But in case you need a reminder, here is a list of benefits of trees from treepeople.org:

Some of these positive benefits include - 

Cleaner Air

Cool Shade

Save Household Energy

Minimize water polluion and soil erosion

Provide food and fuel, paper, and shelter !

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you decide to contribute or not, please share this campaign with your friends who may be interested in helping out. 

Let's get 1,000 people working together and plant 1,000 trees this Earth Day, 2013. 

Thanks ! 

PS - Why not pledge to plant a tree in your neighborhood or back yard and we will DOUBLE our results.

story:
UPDATE: 

The Indiegogo campaign is no longer active but you can still Stand with Science! Your donation –through our host, The University of California, Merced — is 100% tax-deductible and still qualifies for receiving your perks! (Let us know which perk(s) you want to claim here). All contributions above and beyond our original goal will go directly towards building a better website for Climate Feedback.

 

Climate Feedback is bringing together scientists from around the world to sort fact from fiction in mainstream media coverage of climate change, helping the public know which climate news to trust. 

We also provide feedback for journalists and editors to help improve their accuracy and increase the visibility of the most reliable media sources.

 

These new interactions between scientists, journalists and editors have already produced more accurate climate information. Last year The Telegraph misrepresented science when it claimed  that researchers predicted the onset of a “mini ice age” in 15 years. An evaluation of this article by Climate Feedback led The Telegraph to issue a public correction and substantially modify its online content.

But this is only a hint of what Climate Feedback can achieve. We want to increase the frequency of our analyses and aggregate scientists’ comments and ratings into an index that rates the major news sources on their reporting of climate change. We call it the Scientific Trust Tracker.

The money we raise through this campaign will contribute to hire a Scientific Editor to coordinate article reviews and help scientists create clear and accessible analyses for the media and the public.

With your support, we will bring more accurate information to readers, accountability to news sources, and a stronger voice for science.
 

We won't address Climate Change without accurate information

When you read the news, you expect the facts. But online journalism often features sensational headlines that tempt you to click, buzz-worthy anecdotes that don't tell the whole story, and misinformation that spreads like wildfire on social media.

As scientists, we’ve watched the politicization of climate change create an environment where it has become difficult to determine which stories are based on scientific facts. With Climate Feedback, we’re bringing the voice of scientists directly into the conversation.

 

The Climate Feedback Project

We are a global network of 100+ scientists and counting, specializing in everything from biogeochemistry to oceanography, climate variability to paleoclimate.

 

We use an open source technology developed by the nonprofit Hypothesis to annotate online articles so you can read scientists’ insights right on top of the original page. 

 

How it works

1. Select

We select an article for review based on its scientific claims, relevance, and influence on the public. We also take suggestions from our network of scientists and journalists themselves, and as our project grows we’d like to welcome suggestions from the general public.

2. Annotate

Scientists from our network evaluate the article’s scientific basis, providing additional content like references, charts and figures, and drawing attention to errors and misleading statements where they exist.

3. Evaluate

Scientists give the article a score out of five for accuracy, logic, fairness, and precision of facts. We provide a summary of the scientists’ comments in clear language.

In the News

 

Climate Feedback has already been featured in the following publications:

 

What people are saying about Climate Feedback

The bigger vision

We plan to bring on board hundreds of other scientists from around the world, so we will be in a position to provide feedback on any breaking climate story that shapes public opinion!

We will then aggregate scientists’ comments and credibility ratings – dozens and eventually hundreds of them – to build the Scientific Trust Tracker: a reliable reference allowing the public to compare and contrast the credibility of a variety of websites and news organizations.

Here is a mockup:

 

Stand with science!

Support our campaign by making a donation at any level today! Remember that your donation is 100% tax-deductible.

Then spread the word. Share this page on social networks. Email it to your family, friends, and colleagues. Follow Climate Feedback on Twitter and Facebook and help us amplify the voice of science.

Your donation will ensure that Climate Feedback is fully driven by the broad community who want more accurate reporting on climate change.

When you contribute to our campaign, you’ll be able to cast a "vote" for any source of climate change information online—whether it be a website, reporter, columnist, or politician. At the end of the campaign we’ll announce the sources our backers have chosen, and take a close look at every big story they publish on climate change throughout the year.

 

FAQ

1. What’s wrong with climate change reporting?
You’ve probably already read a lot of great journalism on climate science. But all too often the hard work of journalists who report the facts is undermined by self-proclaimed experts who make claims that have no basis in science. Climate Feedback has already identified articles online right now, and which have been viewed by hundreds of thousands of people, that misrepresent the science the articles claim to report. This sows doubt and confusion. We want to make sure that all science journalism reflects science, rather than the ideology of the editors.

2. Are you promoting certain political agendas with these reviews?

No. Scientists are asked to assess the accuracy of factual statements related to climate change with respect to the body of scientific knowledge and the logic of the reasoning. If a statement is unsupported by science, we will mention it, regardless of the political ideology of its author or source.

3. Isn’t the point of journalism to fact-check everyone else, not the other way around?

Many scientific topics are extremely complex and require decades of dedicated full-time work to master. It is hard to fully grasp a complex field such as climate change and recognize what is actually based on sound science—especially when there are special interests, politicians, corporations and public relations teams working hard to push unscientific information in order to advance a biased agenda.

4. I’m a journalist. Why would I want scientists evaluating my story? Are they going to comment on anything besides the scientific facts?

Climate Feedback requires scientists to stick to what they know when they annotate an article. Having scientists checking a journalist’s story in their field of expertise can be valuable in several ways:

  1. You will get valuable feedback on whether people actually working on this topic everyday endorse the message you’re sending.

  2. You get references to reliable sources of information and connections to scientists who can serve as new sources in the future.

  3. You get a credibility boost if scientists validate the information, because they are trusted by the public.

Having scientists take a look at your work can also lead to better understanding and relationships between scientists and journalists in the future, which is what we at Climate Feedback are trying to foster.

5. What is web annotation?

Climate Feedback’s scientists use the open source web platform built by the nonprofit,Hypothesis. The platform allows users to post comments directly onto a webpage. In our case, it adds an extra layer of knowledge to the article being evaluated. By simply following a link or installing the Hypothes.is browser plug-in, readers can easily view the scientists’ annotations.

6. I’m just a reader interested in climate change. How will this help me?

You probably know all too well how difficult it is to find reliable online information these days, especially when it comes to climate change and other politically controversial topics. With Climate Feedback, you’ll get to know which sources of climate news you can trust, and which ones you should be especially skeptical about. You can even share this with your friends and colleagues who might be confused by inaccurate statements they have read on otherwise respectable outlets. And, if you follow us on Twitter, like us on Facebook, or sign up for our newsletter, you’ll be the first to receive updates about the latest articles we evaluate.

7. What type of media are you going to evaluate?

We will start by evaluating the most influential news organizations focusing on climate change. As we scale up this project, we are open to analyzing any type of information on the internet, including popular blog posts and political speeches.

8. With that many articles every day on climate, how are you going to evaluate them all?

We won’t. But we want to be in a position to evaluate any influential article on climate change. And by aggregating our evaluations into a Trust Tracker, you’ll already know which media outlets are likely to publish information you can trust.

9. How did Climate Feedback start?

As scientists, we came up with Climate Feedback after seeing that our friends and colleagues were genuinely confused by contradictory stories on climate change. We found many scientists who shared our frustration after reading articles that were inconsistent with current scientific knowledge. We decided to take it into our own hands to help readers find the most trustworthy information.

Scientists give the article a score out of five for accuracy, logic, fairness, and precision of facts. We provide a summary of the scientists’ comments in clear language. 
In the News
   
Climate Feedback has already been featured in the following publications:

 
What people are saying about Climate Feedback


The bigger vision
We plan to bring on board hundreds of other scientists from around the world, so we will be in a position to provide feedback on any breaking climate story that shapes public opinion!
We will then aggregate scientists’ comments and credibility ratings – dozens and eventually hundreds of them – to build the Scientific Trust Tracker: a reliable reference allowing the public to compare and contrast the credibility of a variety of websites and news organizations.
Here is a mockup:

 
Stand with science!Support our campaign by making a donation at any level today! Remember that your donation is 100% tax-deductible.Then spread the word. Share this page on social networks. Email it to your family, friends, and colleagues. Follow Climate Feedback on Twitter and Facebook and help us amplify the voice of science.Your donation will ensure that Climate Feedback is fully driven by the broad community who want more accurate reporting on climate change.When you contribute to our campaign, you’ll be able to cast a "vote" for any source of climate change information online—whether it be a website, reporter, columnist, or politician. At the end of the campaign we’ll announce the sources our backers have chosen, and take a close look at every big story they publish on climate change throughout the year. FAQ1. What’s wrong with climate change reporting?You’ve probably already read a lot of great journalism on climate science. But all too often the hard work of journalists who report the facts is undermined by self-proclaimed experts who make claims that have no basis in science. Climate Feedback has already identified articles online right now, and which have been viewed by hundreds of thousands of people, that misrepresent the science the articles claim to report. This sows doubt and confusion. We want to make sure that all science journalism reflects science, rather than the ideology of the editors.2. Are you promoting certain political agendas with these reviews?No. Scientists are asked to assess the accuracy of factual statements related to climate change with respect to the body of scientific knowledge and the logic of the reasoning. If a statement is unsupported by science, we will mention it, regardless of the political ideology of its author or source.3. Isn’t the point of journalism to fact-check everyone else, not the other way around?Many scientific topics are extremely complex and require decades of dedicated full-time work to master. It is hard to fully grasp a complex field such as climate change and recognize what is actually based on sound science—especially when there are special interests, politicians, corporations and public relations teams working hard to push unscientific information in order to advance a biased agenda.4. I’m a journalist. Why would I want scientists evaluating my story? Are they going to comment on anything besides the scientific facts?Climate Feedback requires scientists to stick to what they know when they annotate an article. Having scientists checking a journalist’s story in their field of expertise can be valuable in several ways:
You will get valuable feedback on whether people actually working on this topic everyday endorse the message you’re sending.
You get references to reliable sources of information and connections to scientists who can serve as new sources in the future.
You get a credibility boost if scientists validate the information, because they are trusted by the public.
Having scientists take a look at your work can also lead to better understanding and relationships between scientists and journalists in the future, which is what we at Climate Feedback are trying to foster.5. What is web annotation?Climate Feedback’s scientists use the open source web platform built by the nonprofit,Hypothesis. The platform allows users to post comments directly onto a webpage. In our case, it adds an extra layer of knowledge to the article being evaluated. By simply following a link or installing the Hypothes.is browser plug-in, readers can easily view the scientists’ annotations.6. I’m just a reader interested in climate change. How will this help me?You probably know all too well how difficult it is to find reliable online information these days, especially when it comes to climate change and other politically controversial topics. With Climate Feedback, you’ll get to know which sources of climate news you can trust, and which ones you should be especially skeptical about. You can even share this with your friends and colleagues who might be confused by inaccurate statements they have read on otherwise respectable outlets. And, if you follow us on Twitter, like us on Facebook, or sign up for our newsletter, you’ll be the first to receive updates about the latest articles we evaluate.7. What type of media are you going to evaluate?We will start by evaluating the most influential news organizations focusing on climate change. As we scale up this project, we are open to analyzing any type of information on the internet, including popular blog posts and political speeches.8. With that many articles every day on climate, how are you going to evaluate them all?We won’t. But we want to be in a position to evaluate any influential article on climate change. And by aggregating our evaluations into a Trust Tracker, you’ll already know which media outlets are likely to publish information you can trust.9. How did Climate Feedback start?As scientists, we came up with Climate Feedback after seeing that our friends and colleagues were genuinely confused by contradictory stories on climate change. We found many scientists who shared our frustration after reading articles that were inconsistent with current scientific knowledge. We decided to take it into our own hands to help readers find the most trustworthy information.

story:
Keep the thunder rolling!

Our Delegation has reached it's goal. High fives everybody! This campaign is still open and the next $5,000 will be used to make a short documentary about this trip, which will be distributed online for free. Let's keep the thunder rolling—help us bring the Norway Delegation story home. $15,000 will launch Clayoquot Action’s Salmon Farm Watch program, which will closely monitor salmon farming activities in Clayoquot Sound, with frequent field visits. Please help spread the word!

Get salmon farms out of Clayoquot Sound

Wild salmon are being put at risk by industrial salmon farming—Clayoquot Sound has 20 open net pen fish farm sites. Salmon farms are polluting, and magnify pathogens such as sea lice and viruses. Wild salmon are in exceptional decline everywhere feedlots are in operation around the world, from Norway to Scotland to Canada.

Clayoquot Action will be travelling to Norway this January to put pressure on Norwegian salmon farming giant Cermaq. We’ll deliver a clear message: get your polluting fish farms out of the pristine waters of Clayoquot Sound!

The team: Joe Martin of Tla-o-qui-aht First Nations, John Rampanen from Ahousaht and Kelsemaht First Nations, and Bonny Glambeck & Dan Lewis from Clayoquot Action in Tofino. You can help send us north of the Arctic Circle to Alta, to attend a wild salmon conference where we'll meet with the President of the indigenous Sami Parliament and build alliances with the cutting edge of Norway's wild salmon movement. Then on to Bergen, the global capital of salmon farming, to meet Norwegians working to get salmon farms out of Norway’s waters, and to the capital of Norway to deliver a petition from Alexandra Morton asking Norway to divest from dirty salmon farming companies.

Salmon farming is a global industry based in Norway. It's time to develop a global response to protect wild salmon. This trip will link indigenous people from Canada and Norway, and environmental advocates from both countries as well.

Opposition to salmon feedlots in Clayoquot Sound is growing. Just this fall members of Ahousaht First Nations occupied Cermaq’s new salmon feedlot at Yaakswiis and camped out there until the company towed it away. The Ahousaht chiefs made it clear that as long as there are Ahousaht people alive, there will never be a fish farm at Yaakswiis.

The momentum has begun. It’s time to pull together to remove salmon farms from the waters of Clayoquot Sound. You can be part of this!



What We Need & What You Get

This project is two-thirds funded thanks to Mountain Equipment Coop and a private donor. Now we need to raise another ten thousand dollars to cover the cost of travel to and within Norway.

Local businesses in Tofino have generously donated some fantastic perks to help raise the needed funds. Perks include stickers, art cards from local artists, t-shirts, limited edition prints of Tla-o-qui-aht artist Joe David’s Salmon People, limited edition giclee reproductions of Leanne Hodges' Clayoquot Wolf painting, and a Tofino Getaway package including two nights beachfront accommodation, gourmet meals, and adventure outings.

What if we exceed our goal?

By joining Clayoquot Action’s Indiegogo community you will be helping to get salmon farms out of Clayoquot Sound. After Norway there will be much more action on behalf of wild salmon! If the goal of raising ten thousand dollars is exceeded, there is so much more to do. Here's a few items from the top of our to-do list: 

  • $5,000 will fund the making of a short documentary about this trip, which will be distributed online for free.
  • $15,000 will launch Clayoquot Action’s Salmon Farm Watch program, which will closely monitor salmon farming activities in Clayoquot Sound, with frequent field visits.
  • $45,000 will hire a full-time salmon farm campaigner for a year to increase pressure on Cermaq to get their farms out of Clayoquot!

Who is Clayoquot Action?

Clayoquot Action is a Tofino-based conservation society committed to protecting the biocultural diversity of Clayoquot Sound. Our goals are accomplished through public education, citizen research and monitoring, and advocacy. Clayoquot Action stands for democratic rights, indigenous rights and the rights of Mother Earth.

What is Clayoquot Sound?

Clayoquot Sound UNESCO Biosphere Reserve near Tofino BC is the Last Great Rainforest on Vancouver Island—world famous for monumental cedars, bears, wolves and whales. It is home to the Hesquiaht, Ahousaht and Tla-o-qui-aht First Nations.

Wild salmon are the lifeblood of these ancient forests and cultures, providing food and fertilizing the ecosystem which sustains life.

Want to learn more?

Check out Clayoquot Action's website.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us promote this campaign—share this page with your family and friends!

story:
Fundraising Campaign to Support Travel Expenses of a Machi (Mapuche Spiritual, Ritual, and Medicinal Authority) to Attend the Hearing of the Inter-American Court of Human Rights in San José, Costa Rica, on May 29-30, 2013

Mari mari pu peñi, pu lamngen ka kom pu che:

On May 29th and 30th, the Inter-American Court of Human Rights will meet in San José, Costa Rica, to hear and rule on a case presented by the families of Mapuche political prisoners from Chile. This case is based on the severe psychological and social damage and the traumatic effects that their imprisonment has had on Mapuche families, communities, elders, adults, and children in recent years as the result of state repression in southern Chile.

The presence of all Mapuche petitioners and the participation of a Machi—a Mapuche spiritual and medicinal authority—are essential for the success of this petition. The Mapuche petitioners have suffered from state repression that has affected their families, their communities, and themselves in recent years. They have also experienced precarious economic conditions as a the result of the social, economic, and cultural marginalization of Mapuche communities by centuries of colonialism and discrimination within Chilean history. Therefore, solidarity and support from the international community is vital.

The petitioners would like to make possible the presence of a Machi through this fundraising campaign. The Machi is a Mapuche authority who attends the collective health of communities and establishes symbolic, ritual, and physical communication with the land, the spirits, and the community, all of which are fundamental parts of the Mapuche Being (Mapuche Ngen). Therefore, a Machi presence in Costa Rica will strengthen the claim of the Mapuche petitioners.

 If you are able to contribute to this endeavor, please make your deposit before May 16, 2013. All the collected funds will be invested in supporting the attendance of a Machi to this important meeting and the basic expenses of the Mapuche petitioners during the hearings at the Inter-American Court. Any remaining funds from this campaign will be saved for other upcoming Mapuche cases that will be brought to international courts.

This fundraising campaign is mainly designed  to cover the travel expenses of a Machi for the Inter-American Court meeting in San José, Costa Rica. We are receiving donations through the institutional website of The Center for Justice and International Law (CEJIL), based in Washington, D.C. By contributing a minimun of $20 you can support this great cause, please insert the word “MAPUCHE” in the box for Comments, which will allow us to keep track of the funds raised. You can proceed to make your donation by clicking on the following link:

https://app.etapestry.com/hosted/CenterforJusticeInternational/OnlineDonation.html

Case Background

This case is presented before the Inter-American Court by the Center for Justice and International Law (CEJIL), based in Washington D.C., and the International Federation for Human Rights (FIDH), based in Europe.

On August 12, 2011, the Inter-American Court on Human Rights decided to give full consideration to this case on behalf of Mapuche community leaders and activists Pascual Pichun—who recently passed away—, Segundo Aniceto Norin, Jaime Marileo, José Huenchunao, Juan Marileo, Juan Millacheo, Victor Ancalaf, and Chilean supporter of the Mapuche cause, Patricia Troncoso. The litigation intends to challenge the “judicial” processes staged in Chile and to expose the traumatic effects of repressive state policies that have increasingly aggravated the issue of Indigenous rights in the country and that have harmed Mapuche families, and communities.

This claim against the Chilean State at the Inter-American Court constitutes a collective and urgent effort from several families and relatives of Mapuche activists in prison. In recent years, Mapuche people have experienced grave violations to their spiritual, physical, familiar and social integrity of their homes, communities, and loved ones. This is part of a long colonial history of discrimination, racism and state violence against Indigenous peoples in Chile and throughout Latin America. The appeal to an international institution emerges as the result of the unjust incarceration and harassment by state police to activists and leaders from communities who have stood up for their land rights and the recovery of communal territories in southern Chile.

I respectfully urge you to support this fundraising campaign by contributing a minimum of $20 for the travel expenses of a Machi for the Inter-American Court meeting in San José, Costa Rica.

Your individual or group support can contribute to creating a global environment in which human rights and indigenous rights are respected.

Truly yours,

 

Luis Cárcamo-Huechante

Mapuche Scholar

Comunidad de Historia Mapuche

carcamohuechante@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

Diamondback Terrapins need conservatory attention because of the negative effects of human development and pollution in their native environment.

  • We are working on a project to better our community and make a dent.
  • We want to 
  • We will create a place that is ideal for Diamondback Terrapins so that they can live away from pollution.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We Need $650 to go towards supplies.
  • The highest contributor get his/her name on a plaque and to name a turtle. Next two highest also get to name a turtle.
  • The Funds still go to the project if we don't reach our goal but the impact will be less.

The Impact

  • The project will help the problem of pollution and how it affects turtles will become more prevalent.
  • We have already successfully built an amphitheater, treehouse, stage, and basketball court so we know how to build large projects.
