story:
With the eerie and distant bellowing of the Howler Monkeys just overhead, you spy Orchids and Bromeliads in every direction...A Giant Strangler Fig engulfs the remnants of a forgotten Cecropria tree. The wind from the waterfall refreshes like no other, and crisp swirling pools quench your thirst after an all day hike. You take a sip as you plunge in to the cold clean waters of which you drink...! You laugh with your friend and smile deeply at each other as you both know ...THIS is Los Cedros.

Los Cedros Biological Reserve consists of 17,000 acres of premontane wet tropical and cloud forest in Northwestern Ecuador.  Of this, 2,650 acres is formerly colonized (now reforested) land, while the remainder is primary forest. The reserve is a southern buffer zone for the 450,000 acre Cotocachi-Cayapas Ecological Reserve and both are part of the Choco Phytogeographical Zone. The Choco region is perhaps the most biologically diverse and endemic habitat on Earth. Researchers are still finding new and undescribed species yearly in Los Cedros – most recently a new species of frog discovered in the reserve named Pristimantis Mutabilis which is the first reptile which can change the texture of its skin back and forth from all warts to slippery smooth in minutes. A new phenomenon to science.

A dedicated group of forest activists, lead by reserve creator Jose DeCoux, has managed and protected the LCBR for the last 26 years and counting.  This biodiversity gem would have long ago succumbed to deforestation, pastures, cows and corn if it weren't for the continued presence of this team. The constant search for new arable land for subsistence agriculture and illegal logging would have turned this rich and magical forest ecosystem to a simple pasture.

Flora and Fauna

It is known that there are over 240 species of birds in the reserve. Tanagers, Hawks, Eagles, Parrots, Owls, and Toucans to name but a few. Over a dozen species of hummingbirds whizz around throughout the forest, some only an inch long. The stunning Andean Cock-of-the-Rock, the Toucan Barbett, and the colourful Golden Headed Quetzal make their home here.

Click here for Birdlife International’s entry for Los Cedros 

Encompassing thousands of species, the invertebrates dominate the faunal biomass. In Los Cedros there are over 900 species of nocturnal moths most with amazing wing patterns and colours. There are also thousands of species of butterflies, ants, beetles, spiders, and bees. Often seen is the Pepsis Wasp (Hercules Wasp), and it may be dragging a tarantula home to serve as a living nest for its young. The largest cockroach in the world lives here, along with the first aquatic cockroach found in South America . The reserve is also home to several species each of snakes, lizards and frogs which are often seen but have been little researched.

Evidence in the form of scat, tracks, cameras and the occasional sighting provide the assurance that five species of felines roam their territories here in the reserve. Common names are the Jaguarundi, Margay, Oncilla, Puma, and Jaguar. In the morning, along with the chorus of birds, you are likely to be woken by the Mantled Howler Monkey. He is the loudest, so can often be heard, and sometimes seen, in the canopy. The two other primates are the White-Throated Capuchins and the rare Brown-Headed Spider Monkey. The only species of South American bear, the Spectacled Bear, inhabits the higher elevations of the reserve and is seen on occasion. Other mammals include the Opossum, Nine-Banded Armadillo, Kinkajou, Tayra, Southern River Otter, Collared Peccary, Red Brocket Deer, Paca, Agouti, Spiny Pocket Mouse, Bicolo-Spined Porcupine, Western Dwarf Squirrel, and Red-Tailed Squirrel.

Abundant tree species include Copal, Madrono, Avocatillo, Strangler Fig and Podocarpus and the Cedars that give the reserve its name.  Fifty more tree species  have been identified, but this represents only a small fraction of the diversity present in the area. The dense forest floor and understory is a thick web of buttress roots, lianas, vines, prop roots, drop roots, and decomposing plant material. Characteristic of a cloud forest, the trees on the ridge lines are more stunted in size and laden with masses of luxuriant ephiphytes, with a more open canopy allowing a thicker and richer understory.

Also strong through the upper story are climbing philodendrons, bromeliads, heliconia, and cyclanthaceae. The area is especially rich in orchidaceae, with 190 species identified, with a predicted (by Cal Dodson) 200 yet to be discovered.


Why we need your help

The Ecuadorian government has stepped in with an ill-conceived and poorly executed update to the management plan for the reserve. Since the reserve’s inception, the staff has worked hard to build trust and communication with the local community through workshops and education and jobs in the reserve.  Our boundaries have been carefully managed with dedicated neighbors of the reserve creating allies in the protection and management of this biodiversity hotspot. 

Now illegal hunting, mining and forest conversion have picked up around the reserve and we fear for what could happen, for the magic we could lose, the forest that we love, the project we have built for the last quarter of a century.

What We Need 

We need to raise $12,000 immediately to be able to re-survey the boundaries of the reserve and for our staff to have the living expenses to be able to travel to Ibarra and Quito to meet with government officials to advocate for the integrity of the reserve.  

Patrol must be hired to assist the community members who watch the trails for illegal logging and hunting. 

We also need to maintain all that we have built to house volunteers, researchers and tourists that are the backbone of the monthly support for the reserve’s management. 

These are the kinds of expenses that are incredibly hard to raise for a small, grassroots NGO.  This campaign can make a huge difference in the future of neotropical biodiversity conservation.

  • If you would like to make a substancial donation please note that your donations are tax-deductible via the Los Cedros Umbrella foundation,  Ancient Forests International. For information please contact burningleaf@asis.com.

PERKS for Contributing

$100:  Murray Cooper Print of the Forests of Los Cedros

8x10 print of the Forests of Los Cedros photographed by Internationally known wildlife photographer Murray Cooper who lived in Los Cedros for eight years and continues to support the reserve as a trusted friend and advisor.

$250 Collection of Murray Cooper 8x10 prints

Receive a collection of five Murray Cooper 8x10 prints of Los Cedros Flora and Fauna.  

$500 Los Cedros, The Movie

Receive a High Definition download or DVD of this beautiful documentary by Italian/Australian film maker David Nicastro and narrated by John Seed (Trailer for movie shown above).

A beautiful documentary by Italian/Australian film maker David Nicastro and narrated by John Seed has just been released to help in the education and  awareness of Los Cedros. The movie celebrates the unique wildlife and the efforts to protect Ecuador’s last intact forested watersheds from illegal logging, mining and degradation.

Words from David Nicastro, Director of feature film Los Cedros :

“Over nine weeks of filming in the cloud forests of Northwest Ecuador we captured a seemingly endless amount of stunning flora and fauna. To our dismay, we also filmed illegal loggers and pastoralists destroying the remaining primary forests nearby. All we could do was film and bear witness. What started out as a wildlife documentary quickly turned into something much bigger.”

“It is hoped that this film will raise the international profile of Los Cedros Biological Reserve, its incredible biodiversity and the threats to its survival. This film is a call to action. Visit these magical places, if you can, volunteer." 
$750 Canvas Print 
"Receive a 12x12 Canvas Print of original painting by Jennifer Metz “Mariposas de Los Cedros" 

$1000 Your Name Engraved in Los Cedros

Your name will be engraved on a plaque at The Los Cedros Reserve center to remind all who visit of your generosity.

$5000 Three night stay and guided tour 

We will guide you along with long term resident staff to the most beautiful place on the planet! We will host you for three nights and take you on the adventure of a lifetime to giant trees and waterfalls in the depths of this lush and rich cloud forest. (airfare not included)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute money, please help by passing this on to others:

  • Get the word out to absolutely everyone you can. Acting now is incredibly important – the threats are real and imminent, but there are real solutions to protect this amazing and diverse place on the planet.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools, and send this out to everyone you know, via Facebook, Twitter, and email. Let's go viral!
  • Host a movie night. Contact us to get the Los Cedros movie out to the world so that we can educate others about its immense beauty and diversity .
  • If you would like to make a substancial donation please note that your donations are tax-deductible via Ancient Forests International. For information please contact burningleaf@asis.com.
  • For More information:    http://reservaloscedros.org                 https://www.facebook.com/cloudforestloscedros?f...
story_txt:
With the eerie and distant bellowing of the Howler Monkeys just overhead, you spy Orchids and Bromeliads in every direction...A Giant Strangler Fig engulfs the remnants of a forgotten Cecropria tree. The wind from the waterfall refreshes like no other, and crisp swirling pools quench your thirst after an all day hike. You take a sip as you plunge in to the cold clean waters of which you drink...! You laugh with your friend and smile deeply at each other as you both know ...THIS is Los Cedros.



Los Cedros Biological Reserve consists of 17,000 acres of premontane wet tropical and cloud forest in Northwestern Ecuador.  Of this, 2,650 acres is formerly colonized (now reforested) land, while the remainder is primary forest. The reserve is a southern buffer zone for the 450,000 acre Cotocachi-Cayapas Ecological Reserve and both are part of the Choco Phytogeographical Zone. The Choco region is perhaps the most biologically diverse and endemic habitat on Earth. Researchers are still finding new and undescribed species yearly in Los Cedros – most recently a new species of frog discovered in the reserve named Pristimantis Mutabilis which is the first reptile which can change the texture of its skin back and forth from all warts to slippery smooth in minutes. A new phenomenon to science.
A dedicated group of forest activists, lead by reserve creator Jose DeCoux, has managed and protected the LCBR for the last 26 years and counting.  This biodiversity gem would have long ago succumbed to deforestation, pastures, cows and corn if it weren't for the continued presence of this team. The constant search for new arable land for subsistence agriculture and illegal logging would have turned this rich and magical forest ecosystem to a simple pasture.
Flora and Fauna

It is known that there are over 240 species of birds in the reserve. Tanagers, Hawks, Eagles, Parrots, Owls, and Toucans to name but a few. Over a dozen species of hummingbirds whizz around throughout the forest, some only an inch long. The stunning Andean Cock-of-the-Rock, the Toucan Barbett, and the colourful Golden Headed Quetzal make their home here.



Click here for Birdlife International’s entry for Los Cedros 



Encompassing thousands of species, the invertebrates dominate the faunal biomass. In Los Cedros there are over 900 species of nocturnal moths most with amazing wing patterns and colours. There are also thousands of species of butterflies, ants, beetles, spiders, and bees. Often seen is the Pepsis Wasp (Hercules Wasp), and it may be dragging a tarantula home to serve as a living nest for its young. The largest cockroach in the world lives here, along with the first aquatic cockroach found in South America . The reserve is also home to several species each of snakes, lizards and frogs which are often seen but have been little researched.



Evidence in the form of scat, tracks, cameras and the occasional sighting provide the assurance that five species of felines roam their territories here in the reserve. Common names are the Jaguarundi, Margay, Oncilla, Puma, and Jaguar. In the morning, along with the chorus of birds, you are likely to be woken by the Mantled Howler Monkey. He is the loudest, so can often be heard, and sometimes seen, in the canopy. The two other primates are the White-Throated Capuchins and the rare Brown-Headed Spider Monkey. The only species of South American bear, the Spectacled Bear, inhabits the higher elevations of the reserve and is seen on occasion. Other mammals include the Opossum, Nine-Banded Armadillo, Kinkajou, Tayra, Southern River Otter, Collared Peccary, Red Brocket Deer, Paca, Agouti, Spiny Pocket Mouse, Bicolo-Spined Porcupine, Western Dwarf Squirrel, and Red-Tailed Squirrel.


Abundant tree species include Copal, Madrono, Avocatillo, Strangler Fig and Podocarpus and the Cedars that give the reserve its name.  Fifty more tree species  have been identified, but this represents only a small fraction of the diversity present in the area. The dense forest floor and understory is a thick web of buttress roots, lianas, vines, prop roots, drop roots, and decomposing plant material. Characteristic of a cloud forest, the trees on the ridge lines are more stunted in size and laden with masses of luxuriant ephiphytes, with a more open canopy allowing a thicker and richer understory.



Also strong through the upper story are climbing philodendrons, bromeliads, heliconia, and cyclanthaceae. The area is especially rich in orchidaceae, with 190 species identified, with a predicted (by Cal Dodson) 200 yet to be discovered.

Why we need your helpThe Ecuadorian government has stepped in with an ill-conceived and poorly executed update to the management plan for the reserve. Since the reserve’s inception, the staff has worked hard to build trust and communication with the local community through workshops and education and jobs in the reserve.  Our boundaries have been carefully managed with dedicated neighbors of the reserve creating allies in the protection and management of this biodiversity hotspot.  Now illegal hunting, mining and forest conversion have picked up around the reserve and we fear for what could happen, for the magic we could lose, the forest that we love, the project we have built for the last quarter of a century.
What We Need 


We need to raise $12,000 immediately to be able to re-survey the boundaries of the reserve and for our staff to have the living expenses to be able to travel to Ibarra and Quito to meet with government officials to advocate for the integrity of the reserve.  
Patrol must be hired to assist the community members who watch the trails for illegal logging and hunting. 
We also need to maintain all that we have built to house volunteers, researchers and tourists that are the backbone of the monthly support for the reserve’s management. 
These are the kinds of expenses that are incredibly hard to raise for a small, grassroots NGO.  This campaign can make a huge difference in the future of neotropical biodiversity conservation.


If you would like to make a substancial donation please note that your donations are tax-deductible via the Los Cedros Umbrella foundation,  Ancient Forests International. For information please contact burningleaf@asis.com.





PERKS for Contributing

$100:  Murray Cooper Print of the Forests of Los Cedros
8x10 print of the Forests of Los Cedros photographed by Internationally known wildlife photographer Murray Cooper who lived in Los Cedros for eight years and continues to support the reserve as a trusted friend and advisor.


$250 Collection of Murray Cooper 8x10 prints

Receive a collection of five Murray Cooper 8x10 prints of Los Cedros Flora and Fauna.  

$500 Los Cedros, The Movie

Receive a High Definition download or DVD of this beautiful documentary by Italian/Australian film maker David Nicastro and narrated by John Seed (Trailer for movie shown above).
A beautiful documentary by Italian/Australian film maker David Nicastro and narrated by John Seed has just been released to help in the education and  awareness of Los Cedros. The movie celebrates the unique wildlife and the efforts to protect Ecuador’s last intact forested watersheds from illegal logging, mining and degradation.



Words from David Nicastro, Director of feature film Los Cedros :

“Over nine weeks of filming in the cloud forests of Northwest Ecuador we captured a seemingly endless amount of stunning flora and fauna. To our dismay, we also filmed illegal loggers and pastoralists destroying the remaining primary forests nearby. All we could do was film and bear witness. What started out as a wildlife documentary quickly turned into something much bigger.”“It is hoped that this film will raise the international profile of Los Cedros Biological Reserve, its incredible biodiversity and the threats to its survival. This film is a call to action. Visit these magical places, if you can, volunteer." 
$750 Canvas Print 
"Receive a 12x12 Canvas Print of original painting by Jennifer Metz “Mariposas de Los Cedros" 


$1000 Your Name Engraved in Los Cedros
Your name will be engraved on a plaque at The Los Cedros Reserve center to remind all who visit of your generosity.
$5000 Three night stay and guided tour 
We will guide you along with long term resident staff to the most beautiful place on the planet! We will host you for three nights and take you on the adventure of a lifetime to giant trees and waterfalls in the depths of this lush and rich cloud forest. (airfare not included)


Other Ways You Can Help
 

If you can't contribute money, please help by passing this on to others:


Get the word out to absolutely everyone you can. Acting now is incredibly important – the threats are real and imminent, but there are real solutions to protect this amazing and diverse place on the planet.


Use the Indiegogo share tools, and send this out to everyone you know, via Facebook, Twitter, and email. Let's go viral!

Host a movie night. Contact us to get the Los Cedros movie out to the world so that we can educate others about its immense beauty and diversity .
If you would like to make a substancial donation please note that your donations are tax-deductible via Ancient Forests International. For information please contact burningleaf@asis.com.
For More information:    http://reservaloscedros.org                 https://www.facebook.com/cloudforestloscedros?f...

story:
WATER, A RIGHT WE ALL HAVE

(Versión en español abajo)

I feel we have the right to make informed decisions, particularly when this affects the environment, the lives of animals and our own. But in most parts of the world there is a lack of information on the levels of pollution and consumption of water that the cattle industry generates. Colombia is one of the six countries in the world with most water resources but there is a lack of research in the country in this field. 

That’s why I want to do my dissertation research on the impact that cattle industry has on water and the way economy affects this impact. I find that the MSc in Holistic Science at Schumacher College offers me the integration of diverse elements to understand a complex phenomenon like the relation between water and animals in a holistic way.

My aim is that this research will contribute to gathering the information we need in order to take correct actions in what concerns the protection of water and animals; that will contribute to generating transformative educational exercises on the relationship we establish with water and animals; and that it will support the transition to the understanding of water as a fundamental right. Water is essential to all living beings; well cared water is not only a human right; it’s a right of nature as well.  

That's why I'm asking for support to pay the college tuition fee. Your support is fundamental to make this happen. We can make it together.


A HOLISTIC FLUX

I studied physics, mathematical education and ecology with environmental management.  My professional carrier has been as a high school teacher in science and as an advisor to create research groups through a program of the Colombian government’s Institute for Science, Technology and Innovation. Before coming to Schumacher College I was the head of an ethno-mathematics research group that is investigating the ancestral mathematics of the Nasa people, an indigenous community of Colombia.   

Beyond my profession, I have committed my life to raising awareness and creating change regarding the qualities of the relationship we establish with the environment and other animals, and to supporting the autonomy of communities, in particular indigenous.

Education has been one of the main ways; not only from an institutional approach but also  through building up grassroots movements: youth, non-violence, bicycle, animal rights, trees, water and environmental issues in general. On behalf the Federación de Liberación Animal (Federation of Animal Freedom) , I run the only school in Colombia for animal rights activist, that has an ecological approach. Independent media is another of the ways I am raising awareness about our relationships with the environment and animals. I have coordinated a radio program Juventud Siglo XXI (Youth XXI century), currently edit the Vida Libre (Free Life) magazine and will be starting an interview-format TV program in Colombia with thinkers and transformation experiences from the UK.

As a global citizen, I do workshops and talks in different countries in South America. I have been part of the campaign of one of the coalitions (Ecological Constitution)  that established in Ecuador the rights of nature as a constitutional right. I am also member of the international network for the abolition of bullfighting in the countries where it still exists. In England, I have just started campaigning for the protection of the participation rights and the life of the Nasa people, who have been threatened in the past weeks. (Please see the link at the end)

For a long time I had been looking for a college with commitment to the protection of nature. At Schumacher College I found a unique approach for comprehending the complex relationship between water and cattle in a holistic way. I want to take this opportunity to irrigate the knowledge, experience, reflections and research gathered through this journey as far as possible. I expect that my dissertation will provide a scientific input to the media and the grassroots movements protect the environment and spread the word and protect the territories.

I had I bursary from Schumacher College and paid part of the tuition fee from my savings; and I traveled with money given to me by friends and family. Now I need your help. By supporting me you are supporting a new way of understanding the planet, supporting the movements with which I am involved, and taking care of the environment, water and animals. We can do it together.


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Let’s make this also an opportunity to built a network of people wanting to action in different ways regarding water and the lives of animals. Whether it be research, activism, communication, education or any project or idea that you are developing, let me know so we can come together.

About Cali’s horse Parade  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RftheHSTMwQ&hd=1

Campaign in the UK to support the Nasa People https://www.facebook.com/NasaPeople

Federation of Animal Freedom www.fcliberacionanimal.org

An interview from a Colombian newspaper http://www.eluniversal.com.co/ambiente/es-que-los-humanos-tambien-somos-animales-terry-hurtado-animalista-152406



EL AGUA UN DERECHO QUE TODOS TENEMOS

Creo que tenemos  el derecho a tener información suficiente para tomar decisiones, particularmente en temas ambientales, de la vida de los animales y la nuestra. Pero en la mayor parte del mundo hay una carencia de información de la contaminación y gasto de agua que genera la industria ganadera. Colombia es uno de los seis países con mayores recursos hídricos del mundo pero hay una escasez de investigación en esta área en el país.

Por lo anterior quiero hacer la investigación para mi tesis de maestría en el impacto que la industria ganadera tiene sobre el agua y como la economía influye en este impacto. La Maestría en Ciencia Holística de Schumacher College me ofrece la integración de diversos elementos para entender un fenómeno complejo como la relación entre animales y el agua de una manera holística.

Mi objetivo es que esta investigación sirva para recoger información necesaria para tomar las acciones pertinentes en la protección del agua y los animales. Esto contribuirá a la generación de ejercicios de educación transformativa sobre la relación que entablamos con el agua y los animales; para así avanzar en la transición de entender el agua como un derecho fundamental. El agua es esencial para todos los seres vivientes. Tener agua bien cuidada no solo es un derecho humano, también lo es de toda la naturaleza.

Por eso estoy solicitando ayuda para pagar la matrícula de la universidad. Tú apoyo es fundamental para lograrlo. Lo podemos Hacer juntos.


UN FLUJO HOLÍSTICO

Estudie física, licenciatura en matemáticas, y Ecología y manejo ambiental. Mi desarrollo profesional ha sido como un profesor de secundaria y asesor del programa Ondas del Instituto para el Avance de la Ciencia, la Tecnología y la Innovación del gobierno colombiano (Colciencias). Antes de venir a estudiar a Schumacher College me encontraba coordinando el grupo de investigación en etnomatematicas que está estudiando la matemática del pueblo indígena Nasa en Colombia.

Más allá de mi trabajo profesional mi compromiso personal ha sido crear conciencia y cambio sobre la relación que establecemos con el medio ambiente y otros animales; así como el apoyo a la autonomía de las comunidades, especialmente indígenas.

La educación ha sido una de mis maneras principales para lograr los cambios. La educación desde instituciones educativas y también desde las organizaciones de base como: de juventud, no violencia, la bicicleta, de liberación animal, arboles, agua y ambiente en general. Como parte de la Federación de Liberación Animal he coordinado la única escuela para activistas animalistas con un enfoque ambiental. Atreves de los medios independientes también he creado conciencia sobre el tipo de relación que establecemos con el ambiente y los animales. He coordinado el programa de radio Juventud Siglo XXI y dirijo la revista Vida Libre. En breve estaré iniciando un programa de televisión de entrevistas con intelectuales y experiencias transformativas de Inglaterra.

Como un ciudadano global realizo talleres y conferencias en diferentes países de Latinoamérica y he sido parte de la campaña de una de las coaliciones (Constitución Ecológica) que logro incluir en la constitución de Ecuador los Derechos de la Naturaleza. Soy miembro de la Red Mundial para la Abolición del Toreo y en Inglaterra acabo de comenzar una campaña para proteger los derechos sobre participación y la vida del pueblo Nasa, quienes han sido amenazados en las últimas semanas( Por favor mirar el Link al final).

Por mucho tiempo he estado buscando una universidad con compromiso en la protección de la naturaleza. En Schumacher College encontré un enfoque único para comprender las complejas relaciones entre el agua y el ganado desde una perspectiva holística. Quiero aprovechar esta oportunidad para irrigar lo máximo posible  el conocimiento,  reflexiones, investigación y experiencias recogidas durante este periodo. Mi expectativa es que el trabajo de tesis sirva como información científica para que los medios de comunicación y las organizaciones de base puedan informar a la población y proteger los territorios.

Obtuve una beca de Schumacher College, otra parte de la matricula la pague de mis ahorros y viaje con dinero que mi familia y amigos me dieron. Ahora necesito tú ayuda. Al apoyarme a mí estas respaldando una nueva forma de relacionarse con el planeta, respaldando los movimientos de los que hago parte y cuidando el ambiente, el agua y los animales.


OTRAS FORMAS EN QUE PUEDES AYUDAR

Que esta sea una oportunidad para crear una red de personas con deseos de actuar de maneras diversas en la protección del agua y los animales. Cualquiera sea la forma, investigación, activismo, comunicación, educación o cualquier proyecto o idea que estés desarrollando déjamelos saber para podamos conectarnos. Lo podemos Hacer juntos.

Documental sobre la Cabalgata de Cali  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RftheHSTMwQ&hd=1

Campaña en el Reino Unido en apoyo al pueblo indígena Nasa https://www.facebook.com/NasaPeople

Federación de Liberación Animal www.fcliberacionanimal.org

Una entrevista en un periódico Colombiano http://www.eluniversal.com.co/ambiente/es-que-los-humanos-tambien-somos-animales-terry-hurtado-animalista-152406

educación o cualquier proyecto o idea que estés desarrollando déjamelos saber
para podamos conectarnos. Lo podemos Hacer juntos.
Documental sobre la Cabalgata de Cali  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RftheHSTMwQ&hd=1
Campaña en el Reino Unido en apoyo al pueblo indígena Nasa https://www.facebook.com/NasaPeople
Federación de Liberación Animal www.fcliberacionanimal.org
Una entrevista en un periódico Colombiano http://www.eluniversal.com.co/ambiente/es-que-los-humanos-tambien-somos-animales-terry-hurtado-animalista-152406

story:
Last September, I received a phone call from Susan R. Eaton, a geophysicist, conservationist and diver, asking me if I would be part of a 10 women team to snorkel across the Northwest Passage. Extreme environments and wild places have always fascinated me; all my life I’ve been devoted to understanding Nature and I love sharing my experiences with all who are willing to listen. So, as you can guess, my answer was quickly yes!

The SEDNA expedition is named for the Inuit goddess of the sea and with all the rapid changes taking place, the Arctic Ocean may need her protection. In just the last few years it has become possible for commercial vessels to navigate  the Northwest Passage. Shipping traffic increased from 9 ships in 2007 to 30 in 2012, and is expected to triple by 2040. As a land use planner and an environmental conservationist, the question that came to my mind was "are we ready for this"?

The Arctic Ocean is such an inaccessible region due to logistical challenges, extreme weather conditions, and the high costs of conducting field research, investigators actually know very little about the biodiversity and habitat of this Arctic marine environment. The SEDNA Expedition will gather crucial data and help inform future decisions about habitat use, change, and appropriate uses for other human activities. The resulting TV documentaries will share these results with the public.

The SEDNA team includes filmmakers, educators and marine scientists. I have participated as field scientist on five ocean science research expeditions throughout the Pacific Ocean and would like to offer to the rest of the world a window to the Arctic snorkel zone, a dynamic land-sea-air-ice-interface. To this end, I will have to face the challenge of the unforgiving and unpredictable arctic seas by snorkeling the Northwest Passage in 2016: 3,000km in 3 months!

But first, I have to fund my share of the costs - $18,000 - in time for the Sedna Proof-of-Concept Expedition from July 13-27, 2014 where we will test the concept and ourselves. These funds will pay for my place on the vessel and my transport fees. I need your help to get there!

This is much more than just a personal adventure I am excited about what this expedition can accomplish scientifically, culturally and educationally.

Your donation can make this expedition a reality and you will be able to follow the 2014 expedition on my Facebook page (facebook.com/francoise.gervais.50). All donations are greatly appreciated but I also need you to spread the word so that this crowdfunding campaign will be a success. Please donate, and then share my project with your friends via email and on facebook, twitter, etc.

Merci, Françoise

http://divermag.com/snorkel-relay-sedna-expedition/

http://divermag.com/team-sedna-women-explorers/


Le passage du Nord-Ouest en plongée libre relais

Projet 

En relais à la nage avec masque et snorkel, 10 femmes vont parcourir le passage arctique du Nord-Ouest

Nom 

Sedna Expedition

But 

Recueillir des données essentielles relatives à ce milieu marin peu fréquenté jusqu’ici, aider la communauté scientifique à mieux connaître ces écosystèmes, faire prendre conscience de leur fragilité

Année 

2016

Petite histoire — Septembre 2013 : je reçois un appel de Susan R. Eaton, géophysicienne et plongeuse spécialisée en conservation. Elle me demande si je suis intéressée à faire partie d’une équipe de 10 femmes pour parcourir en plongée libre à relais la totalité du passage du Nord-Ouest dans l’Arctique. L’équipe SEDNA comprend des cinéastes, des éducatrices et des scientifiques. Tout de suite j’ai accepté. La nature me fascine depuis toujours. J’aime la sonder en dépit parfois des conditions difficiles qu’il faut affronter pour cela. Au cours des dernières années, j’ai pris part à cinq missions océanographiques dans le Pacifique à titre de scientifique de terrain.

Sedna, déesse inuite—L’expédition emprunte son nom à la déesse inuite de la mer, Sedna. Nous croyons en effet que l’océan Arctique a besoin de sa protection! Depuis quelques années, le passage du Nord-Ouest est accessible à la navigation commerciale. Entre 2007 et 2012 déjà, le trafic annuel est passé de 9 à 30 navires et en 2040 ce trafic aura triplé. Aussi, pour l’aménagiste du territoire que je suis, la question se pose : sommes-nous prêts?

Connaissance et sensibilisation — L’océan Arctique est difficile d’accès. Son étude nécessite une logistique considérable, les conditions climatiques y sont extrêmes, les relevés sur le terrain coûtent très cher. Aussi connaissons-nous encore très peu cette région du point de vue notamment de sa biodiversité. L’expédition SEDNA permettra de recueillir des données indispensables aux décisions qui seront prises pour utiliser de façon planifiée et responsable ce territoire. Volet sensibilisation : l’émission télévisée que nous réaliserons va permettre de partager nos découvertes dans les écoles et avec le grand public.

La zone d’intérêt — Pour moi, cette expédition est l’occasion d’offrir au monde une fenêtre sur ce que nous appelons la snorkel zone, cette interface dynamique où la mer, la terre, l’air et la glace se rejoignent. Pour ce faire, il me faut, avec mes partenaires, oser l’Arctique dans ce qu’il a d’imprévisible et d’exigeant : parcourir en plongée libre le passage du Nord-Ouest, soit 3000 kilomètres en 3 mois.

Préexpédition — Une préexpédition est nécessaire pour tester le concept. Nous la ferons du 13 au 27 juillet 2014. En plongée libre, nous irons du Labrador au Groenland en passant par l’île de Baffin.

Votre aide — Mais mon premier défi est de trouver du financement dans le délai fixé. 18 000 $ sont nécessaires pour couvrir mon transport et ma place à bord du navire. Cette somme doit être amassée avant la préexpédition de juillet prochain. La réalisation du projet est impossible sans vos dons et je sollicite donc instamment votre aide. Toutes les contributions sont bienvenues. Passez le mot au plus grand nombre de personnes possibles, de vive voix, par courriel ou par les réseaux sociaux, afin que je réussisse ma campagne de financement. J’espère aussi que vous suivrez l’expédition Sedna sur ma page Facebook (facebook.com/francoise.gervais.50).

J’ai confiance qu’en menant à bien cette expédition, on accomplira quelque chose d’important pour la science, la culture et l’éducation.

Merci de croire au projet.

Merci à l’avance de votre contribution.

Françoise Gervais

story:
RAINBOW JOURNEY 

+ AWAKENING THE WORLD PROJECT

A JOURNEY OF PRAYER FOR THE AWAKENING OF NEW CONSCIOUSNESS ON OUR PLANET FROM INDIGENOUS WISDOM AND PLANETARY CONSCIENCE
JOIN US AND SUPPORT US AS WE TRAVEL FROM NEW ZEALAND SACRED GROUNDS THROUGH THE AMERICAN SOUTHWEST TO THE U.N. & THE BIGGEST CLIMATE MARCH IN HISTORY - THE PEOPLES CLIMATE MARCH


What we want to do*

Bring people of all nations together face-to-face in actual physical contact to do sacred ceremony together in the ancient language - on the land, for the land and for the people - to acknowledge our shared values and wisdom as human beings. Today, cross-cultural, cross-spiritual, trusting relationships are essential to retrieve and reinforce the ‘original’ wisdom carried down through the ages by indigenous cultures.

Starting 8/27/14, Ojibwa, Maori and Sufi Medicine Men and Women will travel in New Zealand doing ceremonies for the earth with Maori Healers and Wisdom Keepers on their Marae (Sacred Space). Then on 9/9/14 all will go to Arizona and New Mexico to do ceremonies with Havasupai, Hopi, Apache, Yaqui, Polynesian and Navaho Wisdom Keepers and Healers. 

The group will fly to New York City, where two of the participants have delegate seats at the United Nations World Conference on Indigenous Peoples. A final event will be held in NYC.

Jane Feldman (award-winning photojournalist who has photographed for Nelson Mandela and Archbishop Desmond Tutu) will document this journey through film, social media and the web.

Awakening Of The World Project aims to do more - and will create a promotional video based on this journey in the hopes of creating a movie down the line. Sessions with Elders, Prayers, and Gatherings will be filmed in hopes of kindling wisdom's fire to light a way through difficult times.  

LISTEN TO DR. RANGIMARIE TURUKI ROSE PERE SING THE PRAYER IN MAORI FOR THE AWAKENING OF THE WORLD THAT LAUNCHED THIS JOURNEY: https://soundcloud.com/devi-tide/maori-chant-for-the-birthing-to-a-new-worldmp3

Translation of the  Chant of Birthing from Rose Pere: 

Ko te Kuranui
Ko te Kuraroa
Ko te Kura Tu Hae Po

The immense violet flame
The patient violet flame
That stands forth from the darkness

Ko Naa wai nui
Ko Naa wai roa
Ko Naa wai A huruhuru

The immense waters
The patient waters
The cherishing water

Ko te manawa nui
Ko to Manawa roa
Ko te Manawa aroha

The immense heart
The patient heart
The Divine heart of unconditional Love

Ko te iti Kahurongi

The blue diamond links to the blue diamond bridge
from whence we came to where we’re going.
Divine Source realigns, sharing the vibrations of the energy – clearing.
The violet flame transmutes and protects, the cherishing waters cleanse
and strengthen, the Divine Heart
It is time for people to remember their own power and wisdom

Why*

Making war and mistreating the earth are not sustainable practices. Beyond politics and borders we are all one human people. It’s time to return to our essential wisdom. 
Our purpose is to bring together the original and shared wisdom of many indigenous peoples, working with sacred ancient ceremony that has been safeguarded for thousands of years, to help build trust among us.

Maori elder, the revered Tohuna (re-incarnated spiritual leader) Dr. Rangimarie Rose Pere, notes that people all over the world have begun to realize our inter-connectedness. Rose asked her friend, Devi Tide, Kefayat (head of the Sufi Healing Order of North America), to initiate this movement. 

Individual, respected holders of ancient wisdom are courageously stepping out and forging new relationships to make this coming together possible. Yet the focus is not on these individuals, but on their teachings, our shared wisdom. And it is being discovered, again, that this wisdom appears to be the same.

The shared experience of this journey promises to help us overcome old patterns of anger, mistrust and withholding, and to sense how we are all important parts of one living, precious whole.


THE MONEY & THE COSTS

We are asking you for $10,000 to help us perform this journey of blessing. 
This journey pays for part of itself by having paying participants travel with the Wisdom Keepers through New Zealand and the American SW. (Costs are tight and we could use some breathing room.) The portion in New York City has no paying participants, and needs funding. In addition, we are cutting costs really close for the rest of the trip, and request your assistance. These are all booked and sitting on our credit cards - we hope you'll help us take on these costs to bring the wisdom of these beautiful spiritual healers and leaders to the United Nations meeting and to the People's Climate March. 
Why So Many People?
  • To Video and Record the prayers shared by these Wisdom Keepers
  • To photograph this journey, get an article published with Jane Feldman's work
  • Live video streaming content - when possible - to connect more people to the message of this journey
  • Driving 1,500 miles through the SW with many Elders to care for
  • To create lasting videos and recordings of these incredible prayers to share with all of you and with all of the world 
Some Of Our Costs: 
  • $2,000: 11 Plane tickets to NYC from Phoenix
  • $2,900: 3 Nights in a 4BR apartment near the UN building
  • $1,500: Professional Photographic coverage from Jane Feldman (She normally charges much, much more than this - please give extra!)
  • $1,500: Food, Transportation, Supplies 4 Days for the 12 person group in NYC
  • $3,000+: Documentary Seed Video for the Awakening Of The World Project
  • Organization of Awakening Of The World Projects Yet To Come! 

The Perks - Gorgeous Photos, Powerful Videos...

  • $10: Audio Download of Prayers from Awakening of the World Project
  • $15: CD of Prayers from Awakening of the World Project mailed to you
  • $25: Video Download of Sessions from the Project 
  • $50: Audio + Video Download
  • $50: DVD of Sessions with Elders mailed to you.
  • $50: Gorgeous 5x7 Nature Photo by Daniel Weinstein shot on Project mailed to you. You choose from 1 of 5 images, OR, photo of one of the Wisdom Keepers
  • $75: Gorgeous Framed Nature Photo by Daniel Weinstein shot on Project. You choose from 1 of 5 images. 
  • $100: DVD of Sessions with Elders + Audio and Video Download
  • $120: Unframed Gorgeous 8x10 Archival Print by Jane Feldman shot on Project
  • $250: Framed Gorgeous 8x10 Archival Print by Jane Feldman shot on Project. You will be able to select from 1 of 5 different images once the tour is finished. (Production Cost: $50 for materials. Normal Price: $400)
  • $500: Framed Gorgeous 11x14 Archival Print by Jane Feldman shot on Project. You will be able to select from 1 of 5 different images once the tour is finished. (Production Cost: $85 for materials only. Normal Price: $750)
  • $1,000: Framed Gorgeous 16x10 Archival Print by Jane Feldman shot on Project. You will be able to select from 1 of 5 different images once the tour is finished (Production Cost: $50 for materials. Normal Commercial Price: $2,000). + Audio & Video + DVD
  • . . . & . . . Other Rewards will be announced as we go...Stay Tuned!
 Examples of Jane's Photography are at www.janefeldman.com
Article by Jane in Yes! Magazine: The Spiritual Side of Photographic Mandela, Tutu, and the Dalai Lama: http://www.yesmagazine.org/issues/the-human-cost-of-stuff/an-uncommon-view
Photo by Daniel Weinstein


If you are in NYC this September 21st
Join us for 2 Events

9:30 am, Sheep's Meadows In Central Park, we will come together for a circle gathering with Indigenous, Sufi, and possibly other traditions' Wisdom Keepers to pray for the planet before the People's Climate March 

11:00 am March with Us - in The People's Climate March - the largest organized march addressing Climate Change in History!

Other Events in NYC TBA...

Not in New York City this September? 

LIVESTREAMED VIDEOS: https://new.livestream.com/accounts/3116574
FACEBOOK: https://www.facebook.com/devi.tide
WEBSITE W/ VIDEOS:  https://rainbowofbeing.wordpress.com
WHO WE ARE: Bios Click Here: http://rainbowofbeing.wordpress.com/videos-1-8/
http://rainbowofbeing.wordpress.com/devis-dailies/

Please, most importantly, hold the planet in your heart - remember her waters, her air, her earth, her beings, and share this campaign with friends. 
Thank you.

$1,000: Framed Gorgeous 16x10 Archival Print by Jane Feldman shot on Project. You will be able to select from 1 of 5 different images once the tour is finished (Production Cost: $50 for materials. Normal Commercial Price: $2,000). + Audio & Video + DVD

. . . & . . . Other Rewards will be announced as we go...Stay Tuned!

 Examples of Jane's Photography are at www.janefeldman.com
Article by Jane in Yes! Magazine: The Spiritual Side of Photographic Mandela, Tutu, and the Dalai Lama: http://www.yesmagazine.org/issues/the-human-cost-of-stuff/an-uncommon-view

9:30 am, Sheep's Meadows In Central Park, we will come together for a circle gathering with Indigenous, Sufi, and possibly other traditions' Wisdom Keepers to pray for the planet before the People's Climate March 
11:00 am March with Us - in The People's Climate March - the largest organized march addressing Climate Change in History!
Other Events in NYC TBA...

Not in New York City this September?

Thank you.

story:
Summary

  • My name is David Harris, owner of Associated Island Developers, Ltd.  We are a small development company that is dedicated to sustainable living and marine research.  We are purchasing an island in the beautiful waters of Exuma, Bahamas and developing a small sustainable vacation destination that focuses on the oceanic beauty only found in the Exumas.
  • The mission for education on the island is: To create a marine sanctuary with the smallest human footprint and the largest ocean impact through engaged learning experiences in marine research, data collection, observation, and creation of self-contained ecosystems.
  • The education site will house a classroom, research lab, public display gallery, aquariums, and library.  The classroom will be used for seminars, classes, conferences, and meetings.  The research lab will hold scientific instruments, such as water quality testing, microscopes, attachable cameras, video and digital still cameras, logbooks, measuring devices, collection equipment, and computers.  Aquariums will be contained within the public display gallery and maintained by students / researchers on site.  It may be necessary to also place species / research specific aquariums within both classroom and lab.  A library of current oceanographic materials pertaining to southern Atlantic species and issues will be designed by use for education and island residents.
  • The ocean environment is the foundation for life on Earth.  It is a critical resource for land and water plants, and animals.  Human impact places ever-increasing dangers and threats upon this delicate ecological reserve.  Overuse, exploitation, habitat destruction, and neglect by man take their toll.  We must practice preservation if man and water are to survive on this Earth as co-inhabitants.  Humans must understand the ocean as a living, breathing, life force that is truly the base for survival.  Conservation starts today, and it starts with you!

What We Need & What You Get

  • The funding of $2,100,000 will go toward the island acquisition and infrastructure development to house the research facility and supporting structures.

$5

Every cent counts in raising money for conservation.  If everyone does a little, great things can be accomplished.  For your $5 perk, you will receive a personalized e-mail from our owner and e-mailed photographs of the beautiful landscape the island has to offer.  Thank you for your support!

$10

Show your support financially and through your day-to-day commute with your Escape Cay window decal for your vehicle.  Every mommy and mini van needs one!  Thank you for your support!

$25

Each perk member will receive a personalized Thank You Photo from our Executive Island Staff Members and a Escape Cay Window Decal.  Thank you for your support!

$125

Each perk member will receive a personalized thank you for supporting our research.  The perk member will also receive photograph documentation where your commemorative personalized paver is honored at the entrance of our research facility, personalized thank you photo from our executive staff, and a Escape Cay window decal.  Thank you for your support!

$750

This perk is truly a remarkable offering.  We will house ten different research aquariums, and each aquarium will be named in honor of their donors.  You will receive a personalized thank you, photograph of your honored aquarium in our research facility, and a Escape Cay window decal.  Thank you for your support!

$1,500

This is one of the most incredible collectible perk items we have to offer.  A 16 GB Wifi iPad mini in a Ultra Custom Wood Inlay Maple and Walnut iPad Case.  This case even has wooden hinges.  Unbelievable craftsmanship.  You're gonna love it.  Thank you for your support!

$5,000

A 10 on the cool factor.  Through the NOAA Cooperative Shark Tagging Program, you will name the captured shark and receive a personalized photograph and plaque detailing the information on the Tag Card.  Your plaque will denote the species, location of the tag, length, weight, sex, and a first hand story account of the expedition. A truly one time experience that will make a difference in ongoing research and oceanic sustainability.  Thank you for your support!

$10,000

Imagine yourself on a private island in the Bahamas with the most beautiful waters in the world at your doorstep.  Exuma is know for its unbelievable turquoise blue waters.  You will receive a one week stay in our private 4 BR, 4 1/2 bath villa.  Once our accommodations have been constructed, you can experience one of the most relaxing vacations imaginable.  Our island is only a 15 minute boat ride from the capital of Exuma, Georgetown.  Enjoy a week on us!  Thank you for your support!

$75,000

From New York, Chicago, Washington, Atlanta, Charlotte, Miami, Dallas, or anywhere in between, enjoy private jet service for four (4) and a week long stay at Escape Cay in one of our 4 BR 4 1/2 Bath Villas.  The epitome of relaxation and escape.  Private chef provided.  Have a week on us!  Thank you for your support!

$250,000

This is the most honored perk of everything we are offering.  You will have the honor of naming the research facility on Escape Cay that will be used in all of our publications and advertisements world wide.  Every student and guest that visits the facility will know first hand of your ever-lasting legacy. Your bronze plaque will be proudly displayed in our main corridor of our research facility.  You will also receive personalized credit on all of our video documentaries produced for research.

$350,000

We are offering a three quarter acre private island lot with up to 200' of the most beautiful ocean frontage.  Huge tax advantages in owning property in a country that does not have Income Tax.  Your own private island lot that is just 9 miles from the international airport.  This sustained private island development will offer accommodations rarely seen in typical vacation settings.  A must have for the most discerning buyer.  Thank you for your support!

$1,500,000

This is the ultimate perk.  You will receive a three quarter acre ocean front lot with a fully constructed 2,650 sq. ft. villa with 4 Bedrooms 4 1/2 Baths.  Each villa has been engineered for ultimate efficiency but not sacrificing luxury.  Solar power energy with backup generators, saltwater reverse osmosis, full time maintenance staff, on-site fine dining, and all the amenities you would expect in a private island experience.  Oh, did I mention our research submarine?

  • All of the funds raised will be applied to the project as described above.  If we don’t raise all the money needed, no worries, we have a private donor that will match funds raised.  What an excellent opportunity to double our capabilities.

Research

  • The Escape Cay research / education site will be designed to create and enhance learning for all ages.  It will be a lab for student research and observation, a point of current species data monitoring and observation, and information for island visitors and residents.  The goal is to offer a NO COST site for college / grad school level research and intensive summer camp experiences for middle to high school students wishing to pursue marine based careers.  All research will work closely with the Government of the Bahamas on conservation efforts, local community awareness and education, and enforcement of marine protection policy.

Research Goals

  *Development of data collection

  *Census of marine life

  *Least imprinting observation methods

  *Animal Behavior

  *Invasive species impact study

  *Shark protection

  *Fishing method impact study

  *Development of individual interest for educational area

  *Development of marine species protection

Education Goals

  *To teach marine conservation

  *To provide a site for independent ocean based research for college students

  *To promote invasive species research

  *To promote shark data collection

  *To provide water quality analysis and data collection

  *To offer education on local marine species

  *To work in partnership with other local agencies as pertaining to conservation

Challenges

  In the end, we will conserve only what we love. 

  We will love only what we understand, and

  We will understand only what we are taught – Baba Dioum Senegal

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can’t afford to help with funding, then please share this with all your friends using the Indiegogo share tools.  Even small numbers can accomplish great things. 
  • We invite you to share our dream.  Once the research facility is up and running you will be able to follow us with Facebook and Twitter posts, live video feeds, and interactive research programs. 

A special Thank You to BJ Ramer for her tireless contribution to conservation.

story:
Gray's Reef National Marine Sanctuary and Foundation

Photo taken at Gray's Reef National Marine Sanctuary                                              Photo: NOAA Gray's Reef


Located just 17 miles off Georgia's gorgeous coast, the Gray’s Reef National Marine Sanctuary is a national landmark and local treasure: a dynamic setting preserving

vibrant marine life and providing learning, recreational and other
opportunities to our community. The new Gray’s Reef National Marine Sanctuary Foundation has been created to support that important work.

 Gray’s Reef is the best example of subtropical reefs in the United States.
With dazzling soft coral and colorful sponge habitats, it provides a home for a vast array of fish, whales, sharks and sea turtles. It is just one of 14 areas that make up the National Marine Sanctuary System. With the Foundation's support, the Gray’s Reef National Marine Sanctuary fulfills many roles.

Many people are unable to visit Gray's Reef, so we bring the reef to them! Our education and outreach events are vital to sharing this unique environment with the community.

Gray's Reef National Marine Sanctuary is
22 square miles and located approximately
 17 miles off the coast of Georgia.


Gray's Reef National Marine Sanctuary Foundation Website


Gray's Reef National Marine Sanctuary Website



Did you know Gray's Reef National Marine Sanctuary is home to over 200 fish species and 480 invertebrates species? That includes this cute star-eyed hermit crab!                                                                                                                                               Photo: NOAA Gray's Reef


What We Need

We need $99 for the halftime shark suit that will be used at Gray's Reef events. Raising awareness of the reef is a priority and this shark suit will be an excellent way to grab people's attention and start a conversation about Gray's Reef National Marine Sanctuary. The halftime shark suit is made possible through this Indiegogo campaign.

Any additional funds received will go directly to the foundation to support ocean stewardship, education, research, and conservation for Gray's Reef.  If we do not receive enough funding for the shark suit, the money raised will still support the Gray's Reef National Marine Sanctuary Foundation. 


Examples of how the halftime shark suit can be used for Gray's Reef outreach events.

Photobooth image from the 2015 Gray's Reef Ocean Film Festival with shark suit added.  This event promotes ocean stewardship and conservation, and this year we had over 1,500 attendees! Our goal is to draw a larger audience for next year's film festival. Utilizing the shark suit to walk through downtown Savannah will be a great way to advertise for this event.


Remote Operated Vehicle (ROV) setup for the Skidaway Institute of Oceanography Marine Science Day with shark suit added. Gray's Reef National Marine Sanctuary participates in many marine science outreach events. The halftime shark suit will help attract attendees of these events to our booth!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, please share this campaign with your friends! You can also volunteer for Gray's Reef events.

Contact Chris Hines for more information about volunteering: chris@nmsfocean.org

story:
Bref résumé

Mon nom est Tulasi Lessard et je suis une des citoyennes de Sutton qui a reçu la lettre d'HQ datée du 28 mai 2014, nous avertissant de leur projet d'installation massive des compteurs "intelligents" dans la ville. 
La coalition que nous avons formé trouve que cette lettre ne laisse pas de réel choix au consommateur et que beaucoup d'information supplémentaire devrait être partagée avec tous les citoyens: dont les nombreux inconvénients déjà observés liés à ces nouveaux compteurs, ainsi que les actions que nous pouvons poser si nous ne voulons pas de ce compteur sur notre demeure.
Pour ce faire, la coalition veut faire parvenir un feuillet informatif à toutes les adresses postales de Sutton pour s'assurer que chaque citoyen y aura accès. Cela engendre des coûts minimum d'environs 500$, d'où notre motivation de faire cette levée de fond. Si il y a des excédents, ils seront utilisés pour le financement d'avocats, pour un recours collectif, rassemblant tous les intéressés à Sutton.
Ce projet favorise une approche de précaution envers la technologie "Wi", pour le bien-être de toute les générations et surtout de nos enfants.
Il est temps que chaque citoyen fasse entendre son opinion.
En attendant, un site internet qui donne déjà beaucoup d'info:
refusonslescompteurs.wordpress.com
D'autres façons d'aider?
Prière de passer le mot et de faire la même démarche dans votre ville!!

Merci de contribuer à ce mouvement collectif pour la défense de nos droits de consommateurs.

Tulasi Lessard

story:
Wild Orca is a 501(3)(c) Non-Profit Organization. Donations are tax deductible.

Summary


Kenmore Air seaplanes are seen by thousands of people on a daily basis. We want to transform a 1950's deHavilland Otter seaplane into a flying ambassador for wild orcas.

We will use this platform to:

  • Inspire conversations about endangered killer whales,
  • Distribute information about local orca populations,
  • Educate people about what they can do to help protect the species,
  • Educate people how they can support long term orca research and conservation efforts.

We need your help to fund this project.

What We Need & What You Get

The $14,500 needed will cover the costs associated with:

  • The application of an original custom orca paint scheme,
  • The production of educational booklets.
In return for your generous donation, you will receive one of the attractive gifts offered here.
The Impact

This awareness campaign will educate the public about the threats facing endangered killer whales, and the steps people can take to minimize their own impact on the eco-system and the survival of wild orcas by:

  • Aiding in the recovery of chinook salmon,
  • Reducing toxins in the ocean,
  • Reducing marine noise pollution and supporting practices to limit disturbance,
  • Viewing wildlife using responsible practices.

Kenmore Air

Kenmore Air is a seaplane airline located near Seattle Washington. It was founded in 1946 by Bob Munro and has been family operated and owned ever since. Flying residents, families, tourists, researchers and doctors to destinations throughout the Pacific Northwest, Kenmore Air carriers over 75,000 passengers every year. The airline has generously donated the aircraft to be transformed into a Killer Whale free of recurring charges standard of a custom sponsored livery. The Orca paint scheme will be on the airplane for 6-10 years, during this time Kenmore Air will also distribute the educational booklets on all of their aircraft and will make them available to the general public at their passenger terminals.

    The Booklet

    We will produce a booklet about Wild Orcas. The information will include:

    • An introduction to Killer Whales in the Northwest,
    • Factors affecting the survival of wild Killer Whales,
    • Changes people can make in their daily lives to help the species recover,
    • Ways people can get involved in Killer Whale conservation,
    • How toxic chemicals find their way from our homes to our waters,
    • Regulations  and best practices for viewing marine mammals from a boat and the shore.
    This booklet will be placed in the seatback pockets of every Kenmore Air seaplane for passengers to read and take home. Additionally, it will be available to the public for free at seaplane terminals, marinas, education centers, and other venues.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you are unable to contribute financially, you can still help...

    • Spread the word about this campaign,
    • Visit wildorca.org to learn about the things you can do to make a difference and reverse the trend in the dwindling population of Southern Resident Killer Whales.

 This awareness campaign will educate the public about the threats facing endangered killer whales, and the steps people can take to minimize their own impact on the eco-system and the survival of wild orcas by: 
Aiding in the recovery of chinook salmon, Reducing toxins in the ocean, Reducing marine noise pollution and supporting practices to limit disturbance,
Viewing wildlife using responsible practices. 
  Kenmore Air Kenmore Air is a seaplane airline located near Seattle Washington. It was founded in 1946 by Bob Munro and has been family operated and owned ever since. Flying residents, families, tourists, researchers and doctors to destinations throughout the Pacific Northwest, Kenmore Air carriers over 75,000 passengers every year. The airline has generously donated the aircraft to be transformed into a Killer Whale free of recurring charges standard of a custom sponsored livery. The Orca paint scheme will be on the airplane for 6-10 years, during this time Kenmore Air will also distribute the educational booklets on all of their aircraft and will make them available to the general public at their passenger terminals.

  
The Booklet
We will produce a booklet about Wild Orcas. The information will include:


An introduction to Killer Whales in the Northwest,
Factors affecting the survival of wild Killer Whales,
Changes people can make in their daily lives to help the species recover,
Ways people can get involved in Killer Whale conservation,
How toxic chemicals find their way from our homes to our waters,
Regulations  and best practices for viewing marine mammals from a boat and the shore.

This booklet will be placed in the seatback pockets of every Kenmore Air seaplane for passengers to read and take home. Additionally, it will be available to the public for free at seaplane terminals, marinas, education centers, and other venues.
Other Ways You Can Help If you are unable to contribute financially, you can still help... 
Spread the word about this campaign, Visit wildorca.org to learn about the things you can do to make a difference and reverse the trend in the dwindling population of Southern Resident Killer Whales.

story:
Short Summary

I am Andrew Mupuya 5 year’s back, when my parents had lost their jobs and could only afford my school fees. I had to get to meet my basic needs by myself, I decided to face the world alone. After participating in the Junior Achievement company program at my school( Kololo sss).

By that time the government of Uganda announced that they were considering a ban on plastic bags to curb environmental damage. I immediately saw this as an opportunity to start a paper bag production company.

I conducted a feasibility study, market research around retail shops, kiosks, supermarkets around Kampala and discovered there is need and potential market for paper bags

To start I needed a capital of 36,000 Ugandan shillings ($14). I collected used plastic bottles and I was able to raise the first $11 then I borrowed the remaining $3 from my teacher and I started producing paper bags on a small scale.

Eco friendly paper bags campaign is aimed at sharing the pressing Environmental damage with YOU, currently Environmental pollution is high and has caused negative impact to the Globe, this initiative was started when Kampala a capital city of Uganda was polluted in form of air pollution when plastic bags are used, dumped and burnt, inform of water pollution like plastic bags blocking water streams leading to flooding and breeding grounds for disease vectors like Mosquitoes, like in 2000 there was an outbreak of cholera in Kampala. Land pollution where in areas where they have been deposited in large quantities, soil fertility has been lost. The polythene bags have also got acidic combination which with time disturbs the chemical formulas of the soils, this has affected the country’s Gross domestic product because 60% of Uganda’s economy is contributed by agriculture.
Plastics bags are also poisonous when they are burnt below 800 o Celsius. In slums Used

Plastic bags are at times re-used as mobile toilets and thrown on the ways in that when it’s re-used again it’s very dangerous to human health. 

A combination of released gases both at production of plastic bags and after usage is a great contribution to global warming.

Why paper bags?

Paper bags come from agricultural materials, which grow in the earth's soil. The materials needed to make paper bags are considered renewable resources that are controlled. Once paper is made, It can be recycled and used to create more paper goods. Bags made from paper are bio-degradable and hence highly environment friendly than plastic bags, which pose a threat to the environment. Paper bags decompose compared to polythene that take 15 to 1000 years to break down,Can be recycled to make new paper,require less energy than plastic to be recycled hence low cost, they also pose less of a threat to both domestic and wildlife than plastic.

Impact Created

Currently the project have created both direct and indirect impact in different ways by employing people up to 21 people are employed directly and we have supplied over 6 million paper bags to the community.


                               

What We Need & What You Get

Your great offer will help us build the production plant that will enable us produce, train and sensitize the community about environmental conservation, supply and distribute. We need to acquire paper bags production machinery that cost $150,000 USD F.O.B price in China or Germany, this machines are not made in Africa and this will be the first paper bag making machine in Uganda. it will enable us achieve the goal to supply the required quantities.

Your contribution will save the world from a high effect of cancer and air born diseases out of pollution caused by polythene bags, through application of technology and mechanization of the project that will lead to steeped and mass production of the eco-friendly paper bags. And this will lead to replacing and reducing the use of polythene and plastic bags.


The Impact

We need $200,000 USD to help us import paper bag making machinery and set up premises to help manufacture and recycling of paper.

This will create employment opportunities to communities, this machine will provide job opportunities to over 60 individuals.

Increase on the production capacity to help satisfy the currently pending markets where we are only able to supply 5% of the available market locally. this machine will produce 200 paper bags per minute.


We have been featured in different media that include;

http://edition.cnn.com/2014/01/23/business/paper-bag-empire-andrew-mupuya/index.html

http://www.google.co.ug/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=10&cad=rja&uact=8&sqi=2&ved=0CFMQFjAJ&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.anzishaprize.org%2Ffellows%2Fandrew-mupuya%2F&ei=rOyJU9K2CvCV7AbW6oHwAg&usg=AFQjCNECZKixOIjGbU_WqSI_z_VxwXQRZA&bvm=bv.67720277,d.ZWU

http://www.google.co.ug/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=11&cad=rja&uact=8&sqi=2&ved=0CFkQFjAK&url=http%3A%2F%2Fsponsor.ja-ye.org%2Fpls%2Fapex31mb%2Ff%3Fp%3D17000%3A1002%3A71437434547246%3A%3A%3A1002%3AP1002_HID_ID%2CP1016_HID_INSTITUTION_ID%3A12041%2C31740&ei=rOyJU9K2CvCV7AbW6oHwAg&usg=AFQjCNFoalJnJ0GuUWi-Ime6cx9wUSBIaQ&bvm=bv.67720277,d.ZWU

http://www.google.co.ug/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=15&cad=rja&uact=8&sqi=2&ved=0CHoQFjAO&url=http%3A%2F%2Fyouthhubafrica.org%2F2013%2F03%2F18%2Fandrew-mupuya-paper-bag-champion%2F&ei=rOyJU9K2CvCV7AbW6oHwAg&usg=AFQjCNF0oPA3q_IKZVdLogJ3X4bYXAjUnQ&bvm=bv.67720277,d.ZWU




Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not in position to contribute, you can help us spread the campaign to your potential networks and you will have contributed to Environmental safety.

story:
Kansas City Region

Rich in Natural Resources, History

What defines Kansas City for you? For those of us working for Heartland Conservation Alliance, our region is defined by its beautiful natural resources, including forests, glades, prairies, wetlands and stream corridors.

In these times we feel more than ever we must take action to protect these resources, not only for future generations, but to protect our heritage, our health and the heart of our region.

Our remaining natural areas are not only landmarks that define our place, but they provide needed outdoor recreation and opportunities to discover and experience nature.

They provide a connected network that improves our air and water, keeps streams more stable, reduces risks from flooding, protects wildlife habitat, and guides us to more sustainable urban development.

We are Just Getting Started

Heartland Conservation Alliance is taking action to protect these places before it is too late! We are building a connected network of land trusts, environmental education and advocacy groups, and public agencies to promote coordination and cooperation and expand our regional conservation efforts.

In order to become a nonprofit organization recognized by the IRS, we must submit an application and pay fees of $850. The Board and the Steering Committee members have contributed, but we need your help to raise  the IRS application fees.

This matters because as a nonprofit organization recognized by the IRS, we will become eligible to secure more critical funding for our work. which means we will we able to save more of the places you love.

Other Ways You Can Help

Perhaps you are unable to help us with our campaign, but there are so many ways you can support our work:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Share your ideas with us

story:
Culver City Salads is a little vegan salad truck in Vancouver.

We serve up a selection of delicious vegan salads, always packed full of colourful vegetables and proteins - always fresh and gluten free.

We use produce grown right here in Vancouver's urban farms, and strive to be as sustainable as possible, using organic produce and only 100% compostable packaging.

Our aim is to make healthy clean eating as effortless as possible for you!

But did you know that most food trucks run on gas powered generators?

Our goal for this project is to convert the our salad truck to a completely sustainable model. We will install energy efficient fridges that use 1/20th the energy of our existing fridges. We’ll install solar panels on the roof and replace our batteries with clean ones.

With these upgrades we’ll finally be free of our gas generator.

Who we are

We are Christina Culver, Sarah Culver, and Jesse Savath, friends, family, and business partners who share a love of healthy food and sustainability.

We started Culver City Salads two years ago. Back then, Christina was making salads in her home kitchen and delivering them to friends and colleagues. Needless to say, we’ve grown a lot. Now servicing all of Vancouver, we have a green food truck that you’ve probably seen parked in various locations throughout the city. We’re lucky to be a part of such a great community.

Christina is the oldest daughter in a family of eight, and cut her teeth keeping a large family of athletes well fed. 

Sarah was a professional ski racer, she combined her love for delicious food, health and wellness by training as a pastry chef and is studying to be a holistic nutritionist. 

Jesse has small business start-up experience, having helped found Salazar, a successful film company that shoots beautiful documentaries around the world.

The Salad Card Campaign

We're launching this pre-sales campaign to complete our vision of what Culver City Salads should be and hopefully inspire a solar panel initiative throughout the city.

We're aiming to raise $20,000 through pre-sales of Salad Cards. This money will go a long way in helping to complete the details that will make Culver City Salads more sustainable. We’ll outfit our kitchen with energy efficient fridges, exchange our batteries for clean ones, and install solar panels on the roof.

When you purchase one of our Salad Cards, you will get a card pre-loaded with that amount to spend at either our food truck or on our website for delivery. As well as helping us fund a really awesome project, we want you, our backers, to have something really great in return. We are offering some extra-special perks from our local partners. Things like: fresh juices from The Juice Truck, getting sweaty with Tight Life personal trainers, yoga classes at The Distrikt Movement, and a chance to get your hands dirty with Inner City Farms. Take a look on the right for more information on our rewards.

Had your fill of salad? Keen to give the gift of greens? Purchase a perk then send us an email at info@culvercitysalads.com with your purchase details and the name and email of the person you would like to give the perk to, and we will take care of the rest!

Where your funding goes:

Your pledges are as much an investment in us as they are in a sustainable future, a greener Vancouver, and let’s face it, a better life for our children.

There is no immediate financial profit to be made from installing solar panels. Rewards are down the road, we’re doing this out of a desire to hopefully be part of a much larger movement towards sustainability in the city and world. Your pledges, in addition to some of our own financing, will be used to cover our conversion expenses. Solar panels aren’t cheap - not even small ones! Please check the graphic below for a rough breakdown of the project’s budget:

Thank you!

Culver City Salads will be a very sustainable salad truck, converting the sun’s energy into delicious vegan salads for you. Whether you buy a Salad Card or share this video with your friends, we thank you for your support.

We look forward to serving you sustainable salads in the summer of 2014!


CCS Team

www.culvercitysalads.com

info@culvercitysalads.com


Thanks to our friends at The Juice Truck, Distrikt Movement, Tight Club Athletics, The Tight Life, and Inner City Farms.

www.thejuicetruck.ca

www.tightclubvancouver.com

www.thetightlife.com

www.distrikt.ca

www.innercityfarms.com
