Je ne peux tout simplement plus supporter de juste me plaindre dans mon coin et regarder l’environnement se dégrader sans participer à sa sauvegarde. Je me suis installé à Annecy il y a deux ans et j’ai voulu m’impliquer pour aider à garder le lac propre et préservé. J’ai été assez frustré de voir que les solutions actuelles de recyclages ou d’alimentation bio posent tout de même un problème environnementale à cause des emballages que ça génère et qui la plupart du temps finissent hors de la chaîne de tri avec les autres déchets. J’ai alors cherché la source du problème La réduction des emballages semble être une des solutions de base.En ville on peut facilement voir que les touristes comme les locaux achètent des bouteilles qui sont souvent remplis par de l’eau qui vient de la région, comme Evian par exemple. La qualité de l’eau courante à Annecy est comparable à l’eau minérale vendue dans le commerce, alors qu’elle est en libre accès et fraiche dans de nombreuses fontaines à travers la ville. La question qui se posait alors était « comment amener les gens à prendre l’habitude de ré-utiliser une bouteille en verre lorsqu’ils sont à Annecy ? » la Better Bottle est la réponse.Les contributeurs au projet nous donnerons les moyens à mon équipe et moi pour produire la Better Bottle, une bouteille de type bouteille de limonade à l’ancienne à remplir aux points d’eau qui seront recensés sur une carte spécialement créée et distribuée avec la bouteille. On espère pas seulement distribuer les bouteilles mais aussi participer au nettoyage de la ville et des berges du lac pour s’assurer qu’une plus grande quantité des déchets de la ville puissent être recyclés.La carte:
Les Frais & comment nous aider: 
Nous avons besoin de au moins $3000  pour fabriquer 500 bouteilles, se procurer un bateau  de nettoyage et un vélo de facteur avec sa remorque pour transporter les déchets recyclables qu’on aura collecté. J’ai également intégré dans le calcul de l’argent pour rémunérer un minimum l’équipe de jeunes pour les longues journées au soleil passées à distribuer nos Better Bottle, à nettoyer les plages et à mettre les mains dans les poubelles.
Coûts:

500 Bottles (minimum production run) : $1000 Matériel et rémunération de l’équipe : 650 $Canoë 3 personnes d’occasion pour le nettoyage des fonds : 650 $Vélo de transport des bouteilles : 550 $

Frais Indiegogo : 350 $

Recompenses au contribut:
Nous espérons vraiment ne pas devoir dépendre de la vente des Better Bottle aux touristes. L’efficacité de cette campagne viendra du fait que nous offrirons les bouteilles aux gens. Qui dira non si c’est gratuit ? Nous seront ouverts aux dons, cela relève du choix des personnes mais pendant toute la durée de la campagne il y aura plusieurs sortes de goodies avec les logos Better Bottle à vendre, et selon la contribution Indiegogo, vous pourrez vous en voir offrir. (Nous vous contacterons par e-mail pour votre adresse postale pour envoyer les produits une fois que nous sommes prêts à expédier en Août.)
Autocollant Better Bottle:La Bouteille Better Bottle:Sac en Cotton Bio:

T-shirt en Cotton Bio:Même si nous n’atteignons pas notre but sur Indiegogo, le projet verra le jour quand même. Même avec nos propres moyens, vélos, nous ferons notre possible pour produire et distribuer un maximum de bouteilles en collectant un maximum de déchets recyclables. À ce moment là nous serons forcés de faire un appel aux dons mais je crois que la clé du succès de ce projet se trouve dans la gratuité et la participation spontanée des gens à qui on offrira ces Better Bottle et que l’on pourra sensibiliser. L’eau doit rester gratuite.Nous pourrions également avoir recours au sponsoring de commerçants locaux qui pourraient acheter des encarts publicitaires sur le vélo et la carte des points d’eau mais TOUT les profits iront au projet et ne constitueront en aucun cas des revenus pour nous.
Si de l’argent venait à s’accumuler il sera reversé à des associations de protection de l’environnement comme la LPO (www.birdlife.org) et la FRAPNA (www.frapna.org) qui travaillent pour apporter une eau propre aux populations.
L’impact de la Better Bottle:
On essaie de résoudre le problème des déchets à la source. Les produits recyclables doivent être triés et jetés aux bons endroits, hors on peut voir que même pour les gens qui sont sensibles aux recyclage et le pratique chez eux, une fois en ville ou loin de chez eux très peu font l’impasse car peu saven où recycler  et il devient difficile de garder les bonnes habitudes.
Une seule Better Bottle peut faire la différence pour une personne, il est facile d’imaginer la différence que cela ferait si l’on pouvait en produire 500 ou même plus !

Prochaine étape:


D’ici l’été prochain nous espérons rendre le projet Better Bottle officiel auprès de la Mairie d’Annecy, fort de son soutien et de celui des commerçants locaux le projet pourrait prendre de l’ampleur voire s’exporter dans d’autres endroits où l’on vit au bord de l’eau. Si vous aimez l’idée, ne vous gênez pour faire la même chose chez vous, nous serons heureux de vous aider.
Si vous n’avez pas d’argent pour participer au financement, vous avez toujours une voix et le partage de notre projet est déjà une bonne chose, et nous savons que vous avez une bouteille de verre vide chez vous, alors rejoignez le mouvement et buvez votre eau local et motivent tous les gents de remplacer les bouteilles en plastiques avec un Better Bottle!N’hésitez pas à utiliser les outils de partage d’Indiegogo pour les réseaux sociaux.
Un grand MERCI!-The Better Bottle Project

 The Better Bottle idea: (english version)

My name is Alexis de Tarade, born in France from a Greek mother and grew up in the USA. I have worked in media for many years but with age I have become more and more concerned about ecology. Since I am not a scientist I am trying to use my visual arts skills and self-motivation to help make a difference. I simply  cannot stand on the sidelines anymore complaining and watching the environment crumble without participating towards its salvation. I moved to Annecy two years ago and decided to do something to help keep the lake clean and pure.I was frustrated with the current solutions such as organic food and recyclables since they often fall short of achieving a better planet due to their packaging. I wanted to get to the source of the problem and reduce the packaging being created in the first place. I noticed in town that locals and tourists were buying bottled water while living quite close from their source, like Evian. The water quality in town is comparable to bottled water and is offered free and fresh all over town via public fountains. The question was, "How to get the people to acquire the habit of re-using a glass bottle while in Annecy?". The Better Bottle was the answer.The contributors towards the project will give us the means for my team and I to produce the Better Bottle, a glass lemonade bottle, to be distributed to the people and refilled at one of the many watering points marked on the map provided. We hope to not only distribute the bottles, but help clean up the lake and make sure more recyclable material is actually recycled.

The map:(the map will be updated with further information at the time of production)

   How to Help Us & Rewards:  
We will need be about $3000 to make at least 500 bottles, get the canoe for lake clean-ups and the bike/trailer to transport the recyclable goods that we collect and dispose of correctly. Then I have calculated some money to feed and provide some minimal renumeration to the small team for long days in the sun distributing bottles, cleaning up the beaches and digging through the trash. COSTS: 500 Bottles (minimum production run) : $1000 Materials & crew costs: $650 3 person second-hand canoe: $650Bottle transport vehicle: $550


Indiegogo Payment: $350 Rewards to our contributers:

 We are really hoping to not depend on finding funds by selling bottles to the tourists. The effectiveness of this campaign will be in the fact that we are offering the bottle to people. Who will say no to a free bottle of water? If they want to give us a donation, that will be their choice but we intend to gather funds by selling the goodies with Better Bottle graphics. (We will contact you via email for your mailing address once we are ready to ship all the goods in August.)Sticker:Bottle:

Organic Cotton Bag:

Organic Cotton T-shirt:

 Even if we fall short of our Indigogo goal, we are going to do this project anyway. It might just end up being us on our bikes riding around cleaning up what we can and making as many bottles that the money collected will allow us to make. At this point we will be obliged to ask for donations when we distribute the bottles, but we believe the success in the project will be if we can offer people the bottles and revenues can be made on shirts & bags instead. The water must remain FREE in Annecy.

Local businesses can buy advertisement to be place on the trailer of the bike and on the map but ALL profits will be only feeding back into the project and never to accumulate revenue. If any superfluous funds are accumulated we plan to donate it to local preservation societies like the LPO (www.birdlife.org) & FRAPNA (www.frapna.org) and efforts that are working to bring clean water to people. The Impact of The Better Bottle:We are trying to plug the trash problem at the source, plastic bottles. Recyclable packaging is in vain if they all end of in landfills because people don't bother to recycle or don't know where to recycle. Many people recycle and are mindful of the environment but when away from home on holidays it can be hard to keep their good habits.
1 Better Bottle can make such a difference with one person. Imagine the difference we can do with 500 bottles or even more!The Next Step:


   We hope to eventually approach the town of Annecy and try to make this project official and backed by the town and local commerces. We are only working through the second half of this summer but all the material will be used next year for the bigger better project with the support of the town, hopefully. The project can be exported to wherever bountiful clean water exists and to help keep it that way. If you you like the idea, feel free to launch it in your area. We will be happy to give you any suggestions.    If you don't have money to help, at least you a have voice: 
If you are low on funds, we understand. Just help repost and share the project. We know you have a resealable empty glass bottle somewhere around your house so you can join the movement by drinking your local water. Let people know it's time we end the decades of plastics sitting in our soils and seas.
 Use the Indiegogo share tools to share on social networks.

We are filming our efforts all summer to submit to ARTE to be part of the CLIMATE OPS collaborative documentary that will be presented before the United Nations Conference on Climate Change in Paris this fall. More details:  http://info.arte.tv/en/climate-ops


A big green THANKS for helping us. Wish us luck and do what you can on your side of the lake to keep this planet clean!

story:
List of Perks

 

Mug $19

This sturdy white, glossy ceramic mug is an essential to your cupboard. Looking for the perfect amount of your hot beverage without refills? Search no more. 

iPhone Cover $24

This case looks sleek, but it's tough. Its solid construction fits your phone perfectly, and it protects from scratches, dust, oil, and dirt. The smooth finish also makes it stylish and easy to hold.

Options available; iPhone 5/5s SE, iPhone 6/6s, iPhone 7 Case, iPhone 7 Case plus

Mens T-Shirt $27

This is a classic tee that has a light feel. Made of 100% ring-spun cotton (except for heather colors: heather grey has 10% polyester, heather dark grey, heather green, heather purple, heather red, and heather blue contain 65% polyester).

Color; White, Black, Navy, Heather Blue, Heather, Dark Grey

Size; S, M, L, XL

Square Pillow Case $27 

  • 18x18 inches
  • 100% polyester
  • Soft, durable and suitable for fine print
  • Individually cut and sewn in LA
  • Double sided print
  • Concealed zipper
  • Machine washable
  • Pillow insert included (handwash only)
  • Resilient polyester filling retains shape

Women's Track T $29

An incredibly soft women's t-shirt with a unique cut. With a loose yet feminine cut, this t-shirt boasts a slightly low-rounded neckline. 

Color; Tri-Oatmeal, Tri-Black, Tri-Lemon, Tri-Evergreen

Size; S, M, L

Tote $29

  • 100% spun polyester weather resistant fabric
  • Dual handles 100% natural cotton bull denim
  • Bag 15" x 15" (38.1cm x 38.1cm)
  • 100% Made in California

 

We will start shipping all perks from December to January, so you will be receiving your order in January for the latest if not sooner.

Thank YOU!

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us drive the Project by blogging, tweeting and sharing our crowdfunding campaign,

story:
Bonjour à tous et à toutes !

Je vais vous raconter une histoire.

Il était une fois un petit garçon plein d'imagination. A 8 ou 9 ans, comme beaucoup d'autres enfants, il comprend l'importance de l'argent, et il se met en tête qu'un jour il sera riche. Il rêve d'être un adulte qui a du temps pour ses enfants. Il rêve de devenir suffisamment riche pour s'arrêter de travailler...

Au départ, on le laisse dire, et rêver... Ce n'est qu'un enfant après tout. 

A partir de 10 ou 12 ans, il commence déjà à développer des projets personnels, espérant ainsi accomplir son rêve. Il écrit un livre de nouvelles pour enfants (encore plus jeunes), ou il fait des peintures en espérant devenir le prochain Picasso. Il comprend l'importance que jouera l'école dans son objectif. Souvent premier de sa classe, il passe la plupart de son temps libre à "trouver l'idée qui le rendra riche".

Les adultes commencent à lui expliquer qu'il n'y a que très peu de chance que cela aboutisse, que les riches restent riches et les plus démunis restent démunis. Mais il n'entend rien. Il est déterminé. Sans doute piqué dans sa fierté, il se promet à lui même qu'avant 30 ans, il sera propriétaire de sa maison à la campagne, ou il pourra commencer à fonder une famille.

Vers 17 ou 18 ans, l'âge ou les autres enfants qui rêvaient commencent à se confronter à la réalité, il continue de croire qu'il pourra faire la différence. Il se lance alors dans l'aventure Internet qui a le vent en poupe à ce moment. Il fait des sites web, en espérant devenir peut être le prochain Google, ou Facebook. Mais rien n'y fait, ses projets et idées ne décollent pas. 

Il ne désespère pas. Il continue ses études à l’affût des opportunités autour de lui. Vers 22 ans, il commence à développer des applications mobiles. Peut être  sera-t-il le prochain candy crush, ou snapchat. Mais là encore, c'est difficile de percer.. :) (D'ailleurs au passage : https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=m...)

Aujourd'hui, le petit garçon a 29 ans. Cette année, la vie lui a offert un fils magnifique, et qu'il aime énormément. Et bien sûr, il ne peut que se rappeler la promesse qu'il s'était faite, d'avoir plus de temps pour lui.

Il me reste un an pour réaliser ce rêve d'enfant, à savoir, acheter une maison de campagne... Pour l'instant bloqué en région parisienne, je suis assez loin de ce que je rêvais pour lui...

J'ai besoin de vous! J'ai besoin que vous m'aidiez là ou vraisemblablement j'ai échoué seul. Aidez moi à prouver aux adultes d'autrefois qu'ils se trompaient, et qu'il est possible pour chacun de rêver.

Aidez moi à démontrer qu'il ne faut jamais abandonner ses rêves. Ce n'est pas que moi que vous aidez. Vous aidez tous les enfants de 8 ou 9 ans, qui ont besoin de voir que oui, leur rêves sont atteignables.

J'estime à 150 000€ le montant de l'achat d'une maison + travaux. En effet, je voudrais une maison la plus écologique possible. En harmonie avec la nature qui l'entourera. 

Bien sûr, l'argent n'est pas le seul moyen de m'aider. Vous pouvez tout simplement m'envoyer un message pour me dire "garde espoir, continue de rêver, parce que le rêve, c'est chouette". N'hésitez pas à partager autour de vous.

Vous pouvez tout simplement m'envoyer un message pour me dire "garde espoir, continue de rêver, parce que le rêve, c'est chouette". N'hésitez pas à partager autour de vous.

story:
Clean Water for Peru

Who are We?

We are a team of professionals from different backgrounds. Silver Living Tech is a research business dedicated to researching nano-particles of silver colloidal in size. We have been working on setting things in place for this project for the last 3 years. Alexander (my dad) and I are both from Arequipa-Peru. We were born there, raised there, and have been working there helping make a difference in the lives of many by working with the Production Ministry of Peru and the Pyme Chamber. 

Despite the economic growth Peru has been experiencing during the last 5 years, something as basic as pure potable water is not available to everyone.

So, Are You a Non-Profit or a For-Profit Business?

We are a for-profit business.  Silver Living Tech is a research business dedicated to researching nano-particles of silver colloidal in size. All of our member have their own jobs or are retired, with the exception of Rene, who sold his restaurant in Peru when he moved back to the US to help establish the company there. 

Do You Have Experience Doing This Kind Of Projects?

Yes,  Peter Reynolds has chaired various projects funded by the National Science Foundation, development projects for WICAT Institute and the Waterford Institute. He also researched the nano-particles of silver colloidal in size back in 1991 with a fellow of the Graham Laboratories back when not much was understood about these nano-particles of silver.

Alexander Nunez has over 5 years of experience working with the Peruvian government through the Production Ministry and the PYME Chamber helping them implement their different programs aimed at helping people as well as businesses.

Rene Nunez has been working with the Production Ministry and the PYME Chamber since 2011 and is the International Operations Manager for Silver Living Tech SAC in Peru and the legal representative of the company in the US.

Erin Shea is the newest member who has been working with us almost for a year now. She has invaluable knowledge about humanitarian projects which will help us when we are in Peru.

Tell Us, What is The Problem You Have Again?

Peru's economy is growing rapidly, and together with this amazing economic growth there is also contamination and pollution. Our beautiful Chili river which once had trout and shrimp is now a soup of germs. 


90 percent of the sewage water from Arequipa Peru (a city of a little over 1 million people) goes straight into the Chili river untreated. The contaminated waters are then used by the locals (who do not know any better and because the water already come as they like to say "fertilized") to irrigate their crops. These crops are sold at the markets and people become infected and sick. 

Another problem we have is that many international markets (because of their safety concerns) are not importing our products, thus affecting the micro economies of the people. 30 percent of the people of Peru depend on agriculture as their main source of income.

So, What is Your Plan?

Our plan is to research the use of nanoparticles of silver colloidal in size in the water disinfection process of waste water purification.

How Do You Plan On Doing This?

We are going to bring Doctor Peter Reynolds and his son Engineer Ben Reynolds to Peru to help us research the use of our nanoparticles of silver in the waste water purification process. We will be working with the Catholic University of Santa Maria in Arequipa-Peru.

Why Not Use The Conventional Methods and Build a Water Treatment Plant With That Money?

The conventional waste water purification methods are too expensive for us in Peru, not to mention they are dangerous for the environment.  A water treatment plant costs millions of dollars, what we are trying to do here is bring about a new technology to reduce the cost of waste water treatment and the impact it has in the environment. Also, the FINCyT program is designed to promote research, under their regulations they cannot use that money for anything else.

Conventional treatments include the use of Chlorine as the main disinfectant. The problem with Chlorine is that very large amounts are needed to disinfect the water (expensive), chlorine will destroy the flora (plant life) and fauna (animal life) of the ecosystem of the Chili river and the pampas of Arequipa-Peru, after the chlorination process a dechlorination process must be put in place before releasing the water back to the river (very expensive method).

Other disinfection methods are not strong enough because of the high levels of contamination the river has or will take too long before producing the desired outcome.

Our method is the best option available

Do Nano-Particles Of Silver Or Silver Ions Really Work?

Yes, they do. Some of you might have read about the germicidal properties of silver. Throughout history silver has been used for the same properties in many various ways. Nano materials such as silver nano-particles are not new but we have just began to understand the way they work in the last 20 years.

As it is mentioned silver ions have been utilized to some extent, our nanoparticles of silver are silver ions; a silver ion is just a charged particle of silver. please keep on reading to see why our method is the best option available.

The Peruvian government will give us 75 percent of the funds we need as long as we come up with the other 25 percent. (see below FINCyT Program for details)

What Did Peter Research About Nano-Particles Of Silver Colloidal in Size?

Doctor Peter Reynolds researched the Nanoparticles of silver colloidal in size back in 1991 and has a pretty good understanding of how they work. 

In his research, Peter found that there are certain characteristics that make these nanoparticles of silver safe for both animals and plants; in fact, they have the ability to promote their health. Together with his son Ben who works as one of their top engineers for the US Air Force, perfected the method to manufacture these nanoparticles of silver colloidal in size, making the process very cost effective.

Why Do You Need 150K?

Doing research is not cheap the 150K is only our 25 percent of the deal, the Peruvian government will fund the other 75 percent as long as we come up with our 25 percent.  

We are bringing Peter and Ben Reynolds to Peru for at least 3 - 4 months, we will have professional from Peru, from the Catholic University of Santa Maria working with us as well.  

After Peter and Ben return to the US, we will continue our research and finally present our findings to the commission in charge of reviewing the results from the projects they fund.

We are also planning on continuing our efforts working with the Production Ministry and the PYME Chamber by educating micro, small and medium size businesses about the dangers of polluting the river waters, ways to implement responsible waste water disposal, and to help them as we have so far become more competitive in the international markets.

What Happens After You finish Your Research?

As we said earlier, we will continue our research and finally present our findings to the commission in charge of reviewing the results from the projects they fund. After that we will seek to implement the use of nano-particles of silver in the waste water disinfection and purification they do in Arequipa. If we are successful then we will take it to other parts of Peru and eventually the world.

So This Is What We Plan To Accomplish

  • Research how to use the nanoparticles of silver to disinfect the waters of the Chili river while maintaining the ecosystem.
  • Show the Peruvian government a new waste water purification method which is cost effective and which can be used all throughout Peru and maybe the world.
  • Present plans to build new water treatment plants which will use our nanoparticles of silver for their disinfection needs.
  • Take the new technology to other countries where it can help with their waste water treatment.

What is the Time Frame?

By the end of May the review commission will do a final review, this is where we present our 25 percent of the project. By the end of August we will go to Lima to sign all the necessary paperwork and agreements and we will begin preparations to receive the 75 percent of the funds by the end of the year. We will begin our research on the 1st of January.

If we can reduce the cost of waste water disinfection, help reduce the coliform levels of the Chili river to a normal range, and eliminate the ecosystem safety concerns of using chlorine, then we can make a difference. We believe we can with our method.

We Need You

We cannot make this happen alone. We have been doing what we can to make a difference but now we need you. With your help we can revolutionize the way we treat water, we can provide clean water for thousands maybe even millions.

Your contributions will not go to waste. Please help us raise the money we came here to raise. We need to come up with 25 percent of the money needed to do our research, then the Peruvian government will give us the other 75 percent through the FINCyT Program.

The FINCyT Program

On July 19th 2006, the Peruvian government signed an agreement with the Inter-American Development Bank giving birth to the Science and Technology Program of Peru.

The FINCyT Program is designed to fund technological research projects of businesses, universities and research centers.

How Else Can You Help Us

If you cannot make a donation don't worry, you can still help us make a difference. Please let 10 of your friends know about our project and the impact it will have not only in Peru but in many other countries throughout the world.

The more we raise the more money we will receive from the Peruvian government to research our technology and help make a difference in the lives of millions.

In Silver Living Tech we believe people should play an active role in developing policies and programs that affect their health and lives.

Please help us spread the word.

What Do I Get For Supporting Your Research?

you will be supporting a technology for waste water treatment that has the potential to change the way we do waste water treatment. As we mentioned earlier, the conventional methods are either costly or dangerous for the environment and people or both. We can bring clean water without side effects to the world.

For helping us reach our goal we have prepared a few perks for you which will help the local economies of where we are at:

  • We have a handmade all natural soap with nanoparticles of silver.
  • We have baby alpaca wool sweaters like the one in the picture which are handmade by the indigenous communities of the andes of Peru, you get a beautiful, comfortable sweater and we get to contribute their local economy.
  • We have hand crafted gifts of various kinds which you will get with your contributions so you can always remember us and how you helped us.
  • And last, we have our nanoparticles of silver which you can keep for your emergency water purification kits or for other disinfecting uses you might have.

You will always know that you helped us change the lives of many by helping us help ourselves.


Thank You! ¡Gracias!
story_txt:
Clean Water for Peru
Who are We?
We are a team of professionals from different backgrounds. Silver Living Tech is a research business dedicated to researching nano-particles of silver colloidal in size. We have been working on setting things in place for this project for the last 3 years. Alexander (my dad) and I are both from Arequipa-Peru. We were born there, raised there, and have been working there helping make a difference in the lives of many by working with the Production Ministry of Peru and the Pyme Chamber. 
Despite the economic growth Peru has been experiencing during the last 5 years, something as basic as pure potable water is not available to everyone.

So, Are You a Non-Profit or a For-Profit Business?

We are a for-profit business.  Silver Living Tech is a research business dedicated to researching nano-particles of silver colloidal in size. All of our member have their own jobs or are retired, with the exception of Rene, who sold his restaurant in Peru when he moved back to the US to help establish the company there. 

Do You Have Experience Doing This Kind Of Projects?


Yes,  Peter Reynolds has chaired various projects funded by the National Science Foundation, development projects for WICAT Institute and the Waterford Institute. He also researched the nano-particles of silver colloidal in size back in 1991 with a fellow of the Graham Laboratories back when not much was understood about these nano-particles of silver.
Alexander Nunez has over 5 years of experience working with the Peruvian government through the Production Ministry and the PYME Chamber helping them implement their different programs aimed at helping people as well as businesses.
Rene Nunez has been working with the Production Ministry and the PYME Chamber since 2011 and is the International Operations Manager for Silver Living Tech SAC in Peru and the legal representative of the company in the US.
Erin Shea is the newest member who has been working with us almost for a year now. She has invaluable knowledge about humanitarian projects which will help us when we are in Peru.

Tell Us, What is The Problem You Have Again?
Peru's economy is growing rapidly, and together with this amazing economic growth there is also contamination and pollution. Our beautiful Chili river which once had trout and shrimp is now a soup of germs. 

90 percent of the sewage water from Arequipa Peru (a city of a little over 1 million people) goes straight into the Chili river untreated. The contaminated waters are then used by the locals (who do not know any better and because the water already come as they like to say "fertilized") to irrigate their crops. These crops are sold at the markets and people become infected and sick. 
Another problem we have is that many international markets (because of their safety concerns) are not importing our products, thus affecting the micro economies of the people. 30 percent of the people of Peru depend on agriculture as their main source of income.
So, What is Your Plan?
Our plan is to research the use of nanoparticles of silver colloidal in size in the water disinfection process of waste water purification.

How Do You Plan On Doing This?

We are going to bring Doctor Peter Reynolds and his son Engineer Ben Reynolds to Peru to help us research the use of our nanoparticles of silver in the waste water purification process. We will be working with the Catholic University of Santa Maria in Arequipa-Peru.

Why Not Use The Conventional Methods and Build a Water Treatment Plant With That Money?

The conventional waste water purification methods are too expensive for us in Peru, not to mention they are dangerous for the environment.  A water treatment plant costs millions of dollars, what we are trying to do here is bring about a new technology to reduce the cost of waste water treatment and the impact it has in the environment. Also, the FINCyT program is designed to promote research, under their regulations they cannot use that money for anything else.
Conventional treatments include the use of Chlorine as the main disinfectant. The problem with Chlorine is that very large amounts are needed to disinfect the water (expensive), chlorine will destroy the flora (plant life) and fauna (animal life) of the ecosystem of the Chili river and the pampas of Arequipa-Peru, after the chlorination process a dechlorination process must be put in place before releasing the water back to the river (very expensive method).
Other disinfection methods are not strong enough because of the high levels of contamination the river has or will take too long before producing the desired outcome.

Our method is the best option available

Do Nano-Particles Of Silver Or Silver Ions Really Work?

Yes, they do. Some of you might have read about the germicidal properties of silver. Throughout history silver has been used for the same properties in many various ways. Nano materials such as silver nano-particles are not new but we have just began to understand the way they work in the last 20 years.


As it is mentioned silver ions have been utilized to some extent, our nanoparticles of silver are silver ions; a silver ion is just a charged particle of silver. please keep on reading to see why our method is the best option available.
The Peruvian government will give us 75 percent of the funds we need as long as we come up with the other 25 percent. (see below FINCyT Program for details)
What Did Peter Research About Nano-Particles Of Silver Colloidal in Size?
Doctor Peter Reynolds researched the Nanoparticles of silver colloidal in size back in 1991 and has a pretty good understanding of how they work. 
In his research, Peter found that there are certain characteristics that make these nanoparticles of silver safe for both animals and plants; in fact, they have the ability to promote their health. Together with his son Ben who works as one of their top engineers for the US Air Force, perfected the method to manufacture these nanoparticles of silver colloidal in size, making the process very cost effective.
Why Do You Need 150K?
Doing research is not cheap the 150K is only our 25 percent of the deal, the Peruvian government will fund the other 75 percent as long as we come up with our 25 percent.  We are bringing Peter and Ben Reynolds to Peru for at least 3 - 4 months, we will have professional from Peru, from the Catholic University of Santa Maria working with us as well.  After Peter and Ben return to the US, we will continue our research and finally present our findings to the commission in charge of reviewing the results from the projects they fund.We are also planning on continuing our efforts working with the Production Ministry and the PYME Chamber by educating micro, small and medium size businesses about the dangers of polluting the river waters, ways to implement responsible waste water disposal, and to help them as we have so far become more competitive in the international markets.
What Happens After You finish Your Research?
As we said earlier, we will continue our research and finally present our findings to the commission in charge of reviewing the results from the projects they fund. After that we will seek to implement the use of nano-particles of silver in the waste water disinfection and purification they do in Arequipa. If we are successful then we will take it to other parts of Peru and eventually the world.
So This Is What We Plan To Accomplish

Research how to use the nanoparticles of silver to disinfect the waters of the Chili river while maintaining the ecosystem.
Show the Peruvian government a new waste water purification method which is cost effective and which can be used all throughout Peru and maybe the world.
Present plans to build new water treatment plants which will use our nanoparticles of silver for their disinfection needs.
Take the new technology to other countries where it can help with their waste water treatment.

What is the Time Frame?

By the end of May the review commission will do a final review, this is where we present our 25 percent of the project. By the end of August we will go to Lima to sign all the necessary paperwork and agreements and we will begin preparations to receive the 75 percent of the funds by the end of the year. We will begin our research on the 1st of January.
If we can reduce the cost of waste water disinfection, help reduce the coliform levels of the Chili river to a normal range, and eliminate the ecosystem safety concerns of using chlorine, then we can make a difference. We believe we can with our method.
We Need You
We cannot make this happen alone. We have been doing what we can to make a difference but now we need you. With your help we can revolutionize the way we treat water, we can provide clean water for thousands maybe even millions.
Your contributions will not go to waste. Please help us raise the money we came here to raise. We need to come up with 25 percent of the money needed to do our research, then the Peruvian government will give us the other 75 percent through the FINCyT Program.
The FINCyT Program
On July 19th 2006, the Peruvian government signed an agreement with the Inter-American Development Bank giving birth to the Science and Technology Program of Peru.
The FINCyT Program is designed to fund technological research projects of businesses, universities and research centers.
How Else Can You Help Us
If you cannot make a donation don't worry, you can still help us make a difference. Please let 10 of your friends know about our project and the impact it will have not only in Peru but in many other countries throughout the world.
The more we raise the more money we will receive from the Peruvian government to research our technology and help make a difference in the lives of millions.
In Silver Living Tech we believe people should play an active role in developing policies and programs that affect their health and lives.
Please help us spread the word.
What Do I Get For Supporting Your Research?
you will be supporting a technology for waste water treatment that has the potential to change the way we do waste water treatment. As we mentioned earlier, the conventional methods are either costly or dangerous for the environment and people or both. We can bring clean water without side effects to the world.
For helping us reach our goal we have prepared a few perks for you which will help the local economies of where we are at:


We have a handmade all natural soap with nanoparticles of silver.
We have baby alpaca wool sweaters like the one in the picture which are handmade by the indigenous communities of the andes of Peru, you get a beautiful, comfortable sweater and we get to contribute their local economy.
We have hand crafted gifts of various kinds which you will get with your contributions so you can always remember us and how you helped us.
And last, we have our nanoparticles of silver which you can keep for your emergency water purification kits or for other disinfecting uses you might have.

You will always know that you helped us change the lives of many by helping us help ourselves.
Thank You! ¡Gracias!

story:
Two High Schools So Different

California's Woodside High School has 2000 students. So does Tachilek High in Myanmar (Burma). But the two schools could not be more different.

  • The students and teachers in Myanmar are drinking water from ancient wells and cisterns, using coffee filters to screen out sediment.
  • The water is contaminated with bacteria and viruses.
  • Woodside High's Green Academy wants to provide water purification technology to solve their drinking water issue for the next ten years.

H2OpenDoors, a project of the two Rotary Clubs in Redwood City, California, is working with these schools to install a SunSpring system in Myanmar in February of 2014. Several students from Woodside will accompany the Rotarians on the installation expedition.

What We Need & What You Get

We want to raise $30,000 by October 15th, which will pay for:

  • One SunSpring Hybrid, powered by a wind turbine and solar panel, that will produce over 19,000 liters every day of pure water from any contaminated water source
  • Shipping of unit (about 1000 pounds) in a wooden crate that includes the complete system, spare parts and tools, and 150 pair of new Crocs shoes
  • A donation of $50 provides the equivalent of 40,000 gallons of pure water produced from the Sunspring, enough for a family of 10 to have a gallon per person every day for ten years.
  • If we fall short of the goal, all monies collected go towards the purchase, with other fundraising efforts required to make up the difference
  • If we exceed our goal, the funds will be used to help send students of families who cannot afford the airfare on the expedition with their teacher

The Impact

Imagine the power of students from a California High School presenting water purification technology to their peers in Myanmar, one of the poorest and most challenged countries on Earth.

  • Over 9000 people die every single day of waterborne disease, half of whom are children.
  • Contaminated water sources force these communities to spend up to half of what they earn each day on bottled water.
  • H2OpenDoors and Rotary provides the villages and schools the mentoring, monitoring and microfinancing to establish a social business where the surplus capacity can be sold.
  • The installation we just performed in a hill tribe community of 2500 was responsible for a 75% decrease in incidents of diarrhea in the first 5 months. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Your contribution goes to H2OpenDoors, a project of the Redwood City Rotary Clubs, and your receipt will acknowledge your donation and show the 501(c)3 EIN for Peninsula Sunrise Rotary Foundation in Redwood City, CA.

Students from the Green Academy will also accompany the installation team to a second village in Chiang Rai province in rural northern Thailand to install a second Sunspring at another school. The expedition will also travel to the installation sites from last February (2013) in Chiang Mai province to follow-up with those communities and guide their women's water councils towards the establishment of their water sales business. We will be joined by the Thai Rotary clubs and will enjoy the culture and warmth of these communities. Learn more at H2OpenDoors.org. Woodside's Green Academy, and several other schools are helping to spread the word. Use all the Indiegogo share tools. We know that the water crisis can be solved for the poorest among us...with a little technology, and a whole lot of soul!

story:
GMO FREE REBELS. Join us SATURDAY, OCTOBER 12th as we take over SAN PEDRO PARK for round two of the international March Against Monsanto. STAND UP with us for GMO Freedom as we demand Congress ban GMO foods and stop Monsanto and other GMO companies from poisoning our food. The rally will also show our support for the Organic Community. Speakers will tell their Monsanto war stories and share their knowledge about living GMO free. Come enjoy the comradery, music and displays. This is a family friendly rally. There will be a children's activities table. Stay adamant and HELL NO GMO!

Dear Contributors,

      You do not have to contribute an amount equal to the perks, you are welcome to just contribute ANY amount when you contribute. If you wish to contribute an amount equal to or over the amount of the perks, but do not desire to collect the perk, just simply contribute without claiming the perk. Thanks!

story:
Growing Futures Kenya is starting a compost business to make fertilizer available to disadvantaged farmers in Coastal Kenya. This business will fund our outreach to farmers about sustainable farming practices we are developing on our demonstration farm. These practices will increase food security in an area with high malnutrition and hunger. They also prevent desertification, erosion, and run-off that damage the precious reef. 

We need to buy transportation equipment, make road improvements, install water catchment, and pay employees.

 Evelyn Libal is a graduate of UW Madison with two degrees in International Horticulture and Environmental Studies and experience working on a composting operation. Jay is a bright Kenyan who cares deeply about his impoverished people. We are creating a system that will increase sanitation in the city with organic matter pick up, increase farmer’s yield by improving their soil with compost fertilizer, and work towards educating people about carbon sequestering farming and conservation practices with our demonstration gardens. 


 We are located in a quickly growing rural Mombasa area. This area is located near urban areas with large garbage generation and ready market for local vegetables. There are many farmers in this area that would like to make more from their farms though right now most people are unemployed and suffer hunger and malnutrition. The increase in population and slash and burn bare soil agriculture has a profound effect on the reef and all of the ecosystem services the reef provides.


 We would like to influence the development of this area into the sustainable, food producing suburbs by starting a composting business and demonstration garden. Our business goal is for as many people as possible to make enough rather than one person to make a lot and to empower and educate other people to create their own business. For upfront capitol and 3 months of operating costs until compost is ready will be $15,000. We are asking $20,000 because we need to finish our house (cob earthship) for my safety (a week ago people killed a cop in our area over a land dispute, welcome to the battles of land rights) and there are a lot of miscellaneous things we need that we have not thought of yet such as; paying people to take the grass off their land, we might need to buy more land to get an access road to our plot (our neighbors lied on our land agreement), we need to get Evelyn a permanent visa, get a title deed for our land, and get our project registered we have been trying for months but people say a lot of different things, and I have found everything costs a lot more than I predict. Almost everything in Kenya costs more than in the USA. Given that we can make a successful model we would like to make educational how-to material for enterprising farmers and for other people to easily build more sites around the world.   Please see our blog for more details about what we have been doing. Any extra money will go for community development projects i.e. road and planting trees along it. 

The beneficiaries are:

·  Public Sanitation- Organic matter disposal by compost will create a more hygienic market area and dumping sites (most dumps are open and near water sources and they are gross, horrendously gross)

·  Consumers and sellers- local non-fossil fuel dependent food supply will aid in stabilizing price

·  Farmers- access the high quality, soil building compost fertilizer and ideas on permaculture farming from our demonstration garden. Coastal farmers are FAR behind the rest of Kenya in crop production and fertilizer application (8% in coast compared to 78% national average). We are also in a semi-arid area so to water holding potential of compost and permaculture water management ideas are very important. Our market is small farmers with less than 5 acres. My neighbor invested about $200 to plant these tomatoes. He lost a lot of money.


·  New Florida area- there is currently no reliable employment in this area. By employing 4 other people at a high wage (500ksh/day which is what many people live on all week, or for example a security guard makes 380ksh for a 12 hour work day) and each employee usually supports many dependents. We also will be developing local infrastructure (to save money on fixing our vehicle and be able to reach the market to pick up garbage even after a rain we will make improvements to the road)(when someone clears a large area for their farm instead of paying someone to carry the material we will pay them to clear a road which we can then transport material) See here the improvements we have already made. We also keep money local when farmers buy our compost instead of paying a large corporation for chemical fertilizer and when people in town buy local vegetables instead of vegetables from across the country.   

·  Fisherman and the reef- demonstration gardens of conservation farming to reduce erosion and run-off damaging the reef

·  The future- compost fertilizer is a carbon sequestering form of farming where as conventional agriculture is very carbon intensive and depletes the soil of carbon. This area is already severely food insecure with highly infertile soil.


Benefits of compost

  • Increase soil structure (reduce run-off and flooding, easier to dig, facilitate root growth, current soil approximates cement)  
  • Increase water holding capacity (important in a semi-arid environment)
  • Increase nutrient retention and cation exchange capacity(plants ability to use nutrients)
  • Micronutrients as well as macronutrients
  • Beneficial microfauna increase plant disease resistance and increase nutrient availability  
  • Carbon sequestering farming to develop as the normal
  • Kills harmful bacteria present in raw manure

Employment

  • 3 people (women) to cut and carry 30 bags of carbon rich material (500ksh/person or US$5.90) *they may decide to split this work between more people so they can have days off* *this money will flow out to a lot of dependents*
  • Myself to build the piles and care for demonstration garden (500ksh/day US$5.90)
  • Jey to bring the waste organic matter (500ksh/day US$5.90)
  • 1 person turn compost pile (500ksh/day US$5.90)
  • With the profit we will invest in the farm building terraces, our earth ship, water catchment, water management(this is really important because we get floods that go through our vegetable garden that contain raw human sewage because of lack of toilets this water needs to be diverted and controlled) and other projects that will employ many other people.

Cost analysis for the first 3 months 1,059,500ksh or US$12,500

  • Employees- 270,000ksh US$3,176
    • 6 employees at 500ksh/day= 3,000ksh or US$35
    • Small costs covered by the 500 Jey and I get
    • For the first 3 months no income 3,000ksh/day x 90 days
  • Gas(estimate) 400ksh (4L)= 400ksh/day x 90 days= 36,000ksh US$425
  • Upfront capitol 753,500ksh US$8,700
    • Water barrel terrace 237,500ksh or $3,000
      • 100 barrels at 1,700ksh each for 170,000
      • Transport 7,000ksh
      • Water diversion staircase 60,500ksh
        • Cement25x700ksh=17,500ksh
        • 10,000ksh sand
        • 10,000ksh gravel
        • 7,000ksh transport
        • Labor 6,000ksh
        • Solar pump 4,000ksh
        • Pipe 6,000ksh

*Toilet for our uphill neighbors 16,000ksh

    • 3 wheel diesel motorcycle truck 500,000ksh or $6,000
  • Yield
    • 20 bags waste organic matter+30 bags high carbon material=16 bags or 4m^3 finished compost
    • 1 bag to be sold at 300ksh x 16 bags daily = 4,800ksh/day
    • 1,800ksh compost only profit/day for payback of investment in 1.6 years
    • This is in addition to 600ksh/day from eggs (chickens eat free from coconut, grubs, and vegetables from the market), 500ksh goat milk (goats eat from the 30 bags of C and add fertilizer to the compost), and ??? from farm vegetables payback from total farm yields (-vegetables) is about 10 months  (we hope)

Compare price with fertilizer

Commercial fertilizer with micronutrients is 5,500 Ksh for 50 kgs that will cover ½ acre or 11,000ksh/acre

At an application rate of 8 m^3 compost/acre and 1m^3 compost at 1,200ksh it costs 9,600ksh (until we can test our compost we only have an estimate of application rate of 20 to 25 m^3/ha)

Future

o  Develop educational materials for farmers

o  Increase earnings by making special compost with additions of fish and biochar, we need soil testing

o  Fuel our transportation with coconut biofuel.

o  This may not be a better price/liter to conventional diesel however it has other benefits

§  Increase farm income for a lot of small farmers (compost customers)

§  Give farmers the idea and experience to make on farm fuels

§  Coconut coir for compost

§  Glycerin for soap

§  Chicken and dog food

§  Carbon neutral fuel

o  This will require

§  Lye

§  Methanol

§  Containers

§  Scale

§  Measuring equipment

§  Bike blender

§  Experimentation

Challenges

  • Finding reliable employees (hopefully good pay will be and incentive for doing a good job)
  • Uncertainty about market (no one else is doing it here)
  • Unreliable quality of goods (will the motor tricycle break after a year?)
  • Evelyn’s visa problems
  • Need to figure out registration with government for our business/project
  • Land title deed
  •  Flooding and inaccessible roads

story:
Our IndieGoGo campaign is over now, but you can still donate to the project! 
Visit the Pollinator Stewardship Council Donations page to find out how.
Mark your donation for the Hive Tracking Project
Yes, bees are making this choice every day, and not by their own free will! The bees are in trouble. We want to find out why. Counting both summer and winter losses, beekeepers are losing about 50% of their colonies each year. 2014 has been particularly devastating for Midwest beekeepers. We humans are losing our field force for pollinating the fruits and vegetables we all depend on for a healthy diet.  We need to stop the downhill slide! To do that, we need to untangle the different factors that may be affecting the bees. We are focusing on evaluating the effects of pesticides, pathogens, and combinations of the two on honey bee survival.

What Is the Project?
Pesticide Research Institute (PRI) and Pollinator Stewardship Council (PSC) are working together to better understand how different stressors (pesticides, pathogens) affect bees' ability to thrive. Scientists from PRI and commercial beekeepers from PSC are working together to track 60 beehives over the course of a year and making measurements of:
  1. Pesticide residues in pollen, wax and honey (180 different pesticides)
  2. Pollen identification (to see what the bees are foraging on)
  3. Pathogen levels (in collaboration with Montana State University scientists)
  4. Varroa mite loads
  5. Hive strength, queen performance, disease, bee mortality, and any abnormal bee behavior


    We started the work in January, 2014 and have collected 4 out of 5 sample sets. We have made hive strength measurements and observations at regular intervals over the course of the year. The preliminary results are tantalizing, but definitive conclusions will require finalizing the sample analysis and then doing some serious number-crunching. We need your help to finish this project!

    What We Need

    We need funding to run our fourth and fifth batches of samples and help with the data analysis. At $332 per sample times 60 hives times two sample runs, it adds up fast. If we don't reach our funding goal, your help will at least make a significant contribution. 

    If we exceed our fundraising goal, any extra funds will go towards running additional samples to improve the statistics, and help the Pollinator Stewardship Council, a non-profit 501(c)(3) continue its important work helping the bees.

    What You Get

    We have a wide variety of gifts to thank you for your generosity, from an app that will help you make good pest management decisions to a visit and presentation from one of our staff. We hope you will also feel good about helping the bees—more than ever, they need you! 

    If you don't have the resources to donate now, you can still help by getting the word out. Please post this on your Facebook page and forward to your friends using the IndieGoGo share tools. We appreciate any support you can give—Thank you!

    Why This Project is Important

    This research will provide documentation of the types of pesticides and pathogens commonly encountered by commercial beekeepers in agricultural areas over the course of a year, with a focus on agricultural locations with almonds and corn—two crops that most U.S. bees are exposed to. The work will also provide insights into the effects of combined pesticide exposure and pathogen levels on hive health over time.  We anticipate that we can use the data in a number of ways.

    • At the regulatory level (US EPA), the research will provide data on which to base decision-making for pesticides to enhance pollinator protection.
    • For beekeepers, the study will provide a quantitative estimate of hazards posed by particular crop-pesticide combinations and will enable them, where possible, to keep their bees away from such crops.
    • Growers and Regional IPM centers will be able to use the information to make pollinator-friendly choices when selecting pest control products for crops.
    • Knowing which factors are most closely associated with decreased colony fitness will enable everyone to focus pollinator protection efforts on the factors that are most important for improving bee health.

    Why PRI and PSC?

    Pesticide Research Institute is an environmental consulting company headed by Susan Kegley, a PhD chemist who has been doing environmental chemistry for 25 years, with a focus on pesticides for the last 15 years. PRI develops information tools to better understand the risks of pesticides, does sampling for pesticides in air, water, and beehives, develops risk assessment models, and works with a number of non-profits to provide scientific support for their work. PRI has donated its staff time to develop the sampling procedures, help with the field sampling work, create a database that will help us organize and understand the data, and coordinate sampling events and project communications. PRI will be responsible for doing the final data analysis.

    Pollinator Stewardship Council (formerly known as the National Pollinator Defense Fund) is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization founded by commercial beekeepers to defend managed and native pollinators vital to a sustainable and affordable food supply from the adverse impact of pesticides. PSC provides beekeeper support for reporting pesticide-related bee-kills and keeps tabs on what US EPA is doing with regards to pesticide policies, contributing beekeeper voices to the decision-making process. PSC beekeepers, staff and colleagues are contributing their time and hives to the study, doing the field sampling work, and making regular hive health assessments. Coming from second, third, and fourth-generation beekeeping families, our three participating beekeepers have over 100 combined years of beekeeping experience.

    The Technical Stuff

    OK, we know some of you want to know more . . . to dig in a little bit and find out about the science behind our work.  So here goes . . .

    Overview

    Many causes for the unusually high managed honey bee colony losses have been proposed, including pesticides, the Varroa mite, pathogens such as Nosema and various viruses, and loss of forage due to increased corn production to make biofuels. It is likely that an interactive combination of these stressors is responsible for the observed colony declines. More study is needed to determine the primary factor or mix of factors causing colony losses, with a focus on combined effects.

    Understanding the relative contribution of the different factors to the problem of unsustainable colony losses is paramount to solving it, yet few studies are focused on this outcome. The PSC-PRI Hive Tracking Project will provide unique and valuable insights into the agricultural landscape in the U.S. and its effects on pollinators by evaluating multiple colony stressors and their interactions in commercial managed honey bee colonies.

    Previous work in this area has laid the groundwork for doing this study, showing the necessity of tracking the multiple parameters that may affect colony health. Van Englesdorp et al. conducted a comparison of multiple stressors (pesticides, pathogens, and parasites) on collapsed colonies vs healthy colonies[i] at a single point in time, finding no single factor that explained the differences. Runckel, Flenniken, et al. tracked pathogen loads for a migratory bee operation, assessing their changes over time and correlations to colony health, but did not measure pesticide residues.[ii], [iii] Flenniken and Andino have also studied the honey bee antiviral immune response,[iv] an essential piece of the puzzle for understanding potential interactions between exposure to immune-suppressing pesticides and a colony’s ability to combat pathogens.

    To date, there has been no prospective study that tracks temporal changes in pesticide residues, pathogen loads, and parasites in a migratory beekeeping operation, yet there is great potential to obtain data that will help untangle the role of multiple stressors on the bees. Ultimately, this work will provide data to inform evidence-based decisions regarding pesticide regulation, in order to better protect pollinators. The U.S. regulatory system is in dire need of such data, and a major part of the outreach efforts for dissemination of project results will focus on US EPA, USDA, the CA Department of Pesticide Regulation, and other Departments of Agriculture in states around the U.S. This study will provide data to document the scope and magnitude of agrochemical levels within managed honey bee colonies in agricultural areas—an essential first step to understanding the issue and providing a scientific basis for any needed regulatory change.

    The Role of Pesticides in Pollinator Declines

    Current agricultural systems are reliant on chemical inputs, many of which are toxic to bees and other pollinators and present in the environments they frequent. Thus, agrochemicals are one factor that may contribute to colony losses. Systemic, persistent pesticides—insecticides and fungicides—are among the primary suspects in the recent colony losses. These pesticides are sufficiently water soluble to be taken up through the roots and/or leaves of plants and translocated throughout the plant, including into the pollen and nectar on which bees feed. Their persistence ensures that the plant retains levels of the pesticide that may be toxic to pollinators for long periods of time—months for annual crops to years for perennial crops.

    Acute bee-kills are the most obvious form of harm caused by agrochemicals, but lower levels of pesticide exposure can also cause a decrease in hive strength or even colony failure by altering honey bee behaviors and impairing the immune response. A recent study demonstrated that field level exposure to one of the systemic neonicotinoid insecticides (imidacloprid) adversely affected the pollen-collecting efficiency of worker bees, leading to reductions in brood development and colony success.[v] Homing failure following low-level thiamethoxam exposure has also been observed in field experiments using honey bees.[vi] Other studies have shown that honey bees exhibit reduced activity levels,[vii] short- and long-term memory impairment,[viii], [ix] and reduced ability to recruit foragers by waggle dancing following pesticide exposure.[x]

    Dietary exposure to neonicotinoids has been shown to impair the reproductive capacities of both bumble bees and solitary bees. One study found that imidacloprid doses as low as 1 mg/L in sucrose solution significantly reduced bumble bee brood production.[xi] These results suggest that neonicotinoid exposure diminishes bumble bee queen fertility; however, reduced feeding activity in neonicotinoid treated bees was also observed, providing an alternative explanation for the diminished fecundity rates. Bumble bee colonies foraging for six days on clover in turf treated with a clothianidin grub-control product at label rates not only experienced bee kills, but the surviving bees produced no queens.[xii] Chronically exposed bumble bee colonies have also shown substantial (as high as 85 percent) reduction in the production of new queens, thus creating an enormous barrier to colony propagation.[xiii] Although no effects were observed on adult solitary bee mortality, sublethal exposure to less than 3.5 mg/kg of a neonicotinoid mixture (thiamethoxam plus clothianidin) in sugar solution decreased the nest building and brood cell construction rates.[xiv] Offspring production in the treatment group was reduced by almost 50 percent.

    Recent work by Sandrock et al.[xv] indicates that neonicotinoid pesticides may also have effects on reproduction in honey bee colonies, through effects on foraging efficiency and queen survival. Colonies that were fed pollen containing field-realistic levels of thiamethoxam and clothianidin (5.31 mg/kg and 2.05 mg/kg, respectively) gathered 19% less pollen on average than control colonies (P=0.01). While both the control and treatment groups collected similar amounts of pollen during the first three weeks of the experimental pollen feeding, colonies exposed to thiamethoxam and clothianidin consistently collected less pollen later on, with mean pollen collections barely reaching more than 50% of the control group during the last week of exposure. In this study, there was also a significant association between neonicotinoid exposure and queen supersedure,  with six out of 10 queens in the treatment colonies being superseded within one year of treatment, compared to zero out of 10 queens in the control colonies (P=0.01). Swarming, an event that is critical to colony reproduction was also statistically significantly lower in neonicotinoid-treated colonies in the spring following treatment (P=0.005). Exposure to mixtures of pesticides in hive matrices (pollen, honey, and wax) is common,[xvi], [xvii] and our results to date reinforce these findings. Synergistic effects of some pesticides have been studied,[xviii], [xix], [xx] but much remains to be done to understand the toxic effects of agrochemical mixtures.

    Effects on the immune system have also been observed (see below).

    The Role of Pests and Pathogens in Pollinator Declines

    The most significant CCD-associated variable characterized to date is increased pathogen incidence.[xxi] Although greater pathogen incidence correlates with CCD, the cause is unknown in part due to insufficient knowledge of the pathogenic and commensal organisms associated with honey bees.[xxii]

    Parasitic threats to honey bee colonies include viruses, Nosema, bacteria, and Crithidia. The majority of honey bee infecting viruses are positive-sense single-stranded RNA viruses of the Picornavirales order. They include acute bee paralysis virus (ABPV),[xxiii] black queen cell virus (BQCV),[xxiv] Israeli acute bee paralysis virus (IAPV),[xxv] Kashmir bee virus (KBV),[xxvi]  deformed wing virus (DWV),[xxvii] sacbrood virus (SBV),[xxviii] and chronic bee paralysis virus (CBPV).[xxix], [xxx]  

    Viral infections in bees can remain asymptomatic, or cause deformities, paralysis and/or death. Symptoms associated with specific viruses include wing deformities (DWV), hairless, dark, shiny bees (CBPV), swollen yellow larva and/or dark-brown larva carcasses in the cells of worker-bees (SBV) or queen-bees (BQCV). Bees frequently test positive for one or more viruses. [xxxi], [xxxii], [xxxiii]

    In addition to viral infections, honey bees are also readily parasitized by the microsporidia Nosema. [xxxiv], [xxxv] Historically U.S. honey bees were predominantly infected by Nosema apis, but recently Nosema ceranae infections dominate. [xxxvi], [xxxvii] The effects of Nosema infection on individual bee and colony health are unclear. [xxxviii],[xxxix] Some reports suggest infections decrease longevity and may lead to collapse,[xl], [xli],[xlii] but since Nosema is widespread and often detected in healthy colonies, its role in colony health requires further investigation. [xliii], [xliv],[xlv] Another fungal pathogen Ascophaera apis, the causative agent of Chalkbrood disease, kills infected larvae, but does not typically cause colony loss.[xlvi], [xlvii] Bacterial pathogens of honey bees include Paenibacillus larvae and Melissococcus plutonius, the causative agents of American and European Foulbrood disease.[xlviii], [xlix], [l], [li]

    Mite infestations (Ararapis woodi, Tropilaelaps sp., and Varroa destructor) are also common, weakening honey bee colonies.[lii], [liii] Introduction of V. destructor mites, which feed on the hemolymph of developing honey bees and transmit viruses (DWV, KBV, IAPV), in the late 1980s was devastating to the U.S. honey bee population.[liv], [lv], [lvi] Notably, the restricted genetic diversity of the U.S. honey bee population may make it particularly susceptible to catastrophic and episodic losses.[lvii], [lviii]

    How Pesticides and Pathogens Interact

    A functional immune system is critical for honey bee survival, but exposure to certain pesticides may impair bee immunity and result in increased vulnerability to pathogens. Several insecticides[lix],[lx], [lxi]  and fungicides[lxii] have been found to weaken the immune response in honey bees. This is particularly devastating to colonies when Varroa mites are present, since they transmit pathogens from bee to bee. A recent study examined the molecular biology responsible for this impaired immune response and found that exposure to the systemic insecticides imidacloprid and clothianidin resulted in impaired immune signaling involved in antiviral responses.[lxiii]

    Learning more about these interactions is critical to solving the problems of unsustainable colony losses. This project will contribute to our understanding of the science, and provide insights into pollinator-protective solutions.

    Data Analysis

    1) Principal Component Analysis: PRI will utilize Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and regression tree analysis to conduct a multivariate exploratory data analysis of hive strength and survival as a function of the following variables:

    • Concentration of each pesticide and combinations of pesticides. In particular, we will evaluate combinations of pesticides known to interact synergistically to enhance overall toxicity, such as the Ergosterol Biosynthesis Inhibitor (EBI) fungicides in the presence of certain insecticides.
    • Presence/absence of pathogens and combinations of pathogen loads with pesticide residues.
    • Total load of pesticides according to mechanism of action, to enable visualization of trends that may be related to synergism, and/or induced metabolic changes that may disable detoxification pathways.

    We will evaluate which of the measured parameters or combination of parameters are most highly correlated with colony success or failure.

    2) Lethality Loading: In order to more fully understand the effects of mixtures of agrochemicals on honey bee colonies, we will assess what we call the Lethality Loading of the pollen, in terms of oral LD50 equivalents detected in the colony, based on typical pollen consumption for a nurse bee. This builds on Stoner and Eitzer’s use of Pollen Hazard Quotients[lxiv] to evaluate pesticide residues in pollen, but takes the analysis a step further to account for all residues present in the hive. For pesticides for which oral LD50 values are not available, we will use contact LD50 values. Where data are available, we will account for changes in the LD50 values due to synergistic effects, as per the method described by Sanchez-Bayo.[lxv]

    3) Comparison to predicted colony growth: Because the population of a colony is not static, colony strength on a specific date will be compared to predicted strengths based on population models. Several models of varying levels of sophistication and data input needs have been developed and are summarized by Becher et al.[lxvi] including BEEPOP and derivatives thereof,[lxvii], [lxviii] the BEEHAVE model,[lxix] HoPoMo,[lxx] and the Khoury model.[lxxi] We will evaluate the suitability of the available bee population models for our particular data set and utilize one or more of them to compare the observed changes in colony strength to that predicted by the model.

    4) Comparison of pesticide use during almond bloom across counties: We will use the California Pesticide Use Reporting (PUR) data to evaluate historic agrochemical use during the almond bloom, to evaluate cross-county differences in pest management approaches, as an informational tool for growers.


    [i] vanEngelsdorp D, Evans JD, Saegerman C, Mullin C, Haubruge E, Nguyen BK, et al. 2009. Colony Collapse Disorder: A Descriptive Study. J. Browned. PLoS ONE 4:e6481; doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0006481.

    [ii] Runckel C, Flenniken ML, Engel JC, Ruby JG, Ganem D, Andino R, et al. 2011. Temporal Analysis of the Honey Bee Microbiome Reveals Four Novel Viruses and Seasonal Prevalence of Known Viruses, Nosema, and Crithidia. R.F.A. Moritzed. PLoS ONE 6:e20656; doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0020656.

    [iii] Flenniken ML, Kunitomi M, Tassetto M, and Andino R. 2010. Insect Antiviral Defense; the Antiviral Role of RNA Interference. In Insect Virology, Asgari, S. and Johnson, K. (eds.), (Norwich, UK: Horizon Scientific Press).

    [iv] Flenniken ML and Andino R, 2013.Non-specific dsRNA-Mediated Innate Immune Response in the Honey Bee. PLoS ONE 8(10): e77263.

    [v] Gill RJ, Ramos-Rodriguez O, Raine NE. 2012. Combined pesticide exposure severely affects individual- and colony-level traits in bees. Nature 491: 105–108; doi:10.1038/nature11585

    [vi] Henry M, Beguin M, Requier F, Rollin O, Odoux J-F, Aupinel P, et al. 2012. A Common Pesticide Decreases Foraging Success and Survival in Honey Bees. Science 336: 348–350; doi:10.1126/science.1215039

    [vii] Medrzycki P, Montanari R, Bortolotti L, Sabatini AG, Maini S, Porrini C. 2003. Effects of imidacloprid administered in sub-lethal doses on honey bee behaviour. Laboratory tests. Bulletin of Insectology 56: 59–62.

    [viii] Williamson SM, Wright GA. 2013. Exposure to multiple cholinergic pesticides impairs olfactory learning and memory in honeybees. Journal of Experimental Biology 216: 1799–1807; doi:10.1242/jeb.083931

    [ix] Decourtye A, Armengaud C, Renou M, Devillers J, Cluzeau S, Gauthier M, et al. 2004. Imidacloprid impairs memory and brain metabolism in the honeybee (Apis mellifera L.). Pesticide Biochemistry and Physiology 78: 83–92; doi:10.1016/j.pestbp.2003.10.001

    [x] Eiri DM, Nieh JC. 2012. A nicotinic acetylcholine receptor agonist affects honey bee sucrose responsiveness and decreases waggle dancing. Journal of Experimental Biology 215: 2022–2029; doi:10.1242/jeb.068718

    [xi] Laycock I, Lenthall KM, Barratt AT, Cresswell JE. 2012. Effects of imidacloprid, a neonicotinoid pesticide, on reproduction in worker bumble bees (Bombus terrestris). Ecotoxicology 21:1937–1945; doi:10.1007/s10646-012-0927-y.

    [xii] Larson JL, Redmond CT, Potter DA. 2013. Assessing Insecticide Hazard to Bumble Bees Foraging on Flowering Weeds in Treated Lawns. N.E. Raineed. PLoS ONE 8:e66375; doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0066375.

    [xiii] Whitehorn, Penelope R., O’Connor, Stephanie, Wackers, Felix L., Goulson, Dave. 2012. Neonicotinoid Pesticide Reduces Bumble Bee Colony Growth and Queen Production. SciencExpress.

    [xiv] Sandrock C, Tanadini LG, Pettis JS, Biesmeijer JC, Potts SG, Neumann P. 2014. Sublethal neonicotinoid insecticide exposure reduces solitary bee reproductive success: Loss of pollinator fitness. Agricultural and Forest Entomology 16:119–128; doi:10.1111/afe.12041.

    [xv] Sandrock C, Tanadini M, Tanadini LG, Fauser-Misslin A, Potts SG, Neumann P. 2014. Impact of Chronic Neonicotinoid Exposure on Honeybee Colony Performance and Queen Supersedure. N. Desneuxed. PLoS ONE 9:e103592; doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0103592.

    [xvi] Mullin CA, Frazier M, Frazier JL, Ashcraft S, Simonds R, vanEngelsdorp D, et al. 2010. High Levels of Miticides and Agrochemicals in North American Apiaries: Implications for Honey Bee Health. F. Marion-Polled. PLoS ONE 5:e9754; doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0009754, and references cited therein.

    [xvii] Sanchez-Bayo F, Goka K. 2014. Pesticide Residues and Bees – A Risk Assessment. R.N.C. Guedesed. PLoS ONE 9:e94482; doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0094482, and references cited therein.

    [xviii] Zhu W, Schmehl DR, Mullin CA, Frazier JL. 2014. Four Common Pesticides, Their Mixtures and a Formulation Solvent in the Hive Environment Have High Oral Toxicity to Honey Bee Larvae. PLoS ONE 9:e77547; doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0077547.

    [xix] Glavan G, Bo\vzi\vc J. 2013. The synergy of xenobiotics in honey bee Apis mellifera: mechanisms and effects. Acta Biologica Slovenica 56: 1 and references cited therein.

    [xx] Johnson RM, Dahlgren L, Siegfried BD, Ellis MD. 2013. Acaricide, Fungicide and Drug Interactions in Honey Bees (Apis mellifera). PLoS ONE 8:e54092; doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0054092 and references cited therein.

    [xxi] vanEngelsdorp D, Evans JD, Saegerman C, Mullin C, Haubruge E, Nguyen BK, et al. 2009. Colony Collapse Disorder: A Descriptive Study. J. Browned. PLoS ONE 4:e6481; doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0006481.

    [xxii] Martinson VG, Danforth BN, Minckley RL, Rueppell O, Tingek S, et al. (2011) A simple and distinctive microbiota associated with honey bees and bumble bees. Mol Ecol 20: 619–628.

    [xxiii] Govan VA, Leat N, Allsopp M, Davison S (2000) Analysis of the complete genome sequence of acute bee paralysis virus shows that it belongs to the novel group of insect-infecting RNA viruses. Virology 277: 457–463.

    [xxiv] Leat N, Ball B, Govan V, Davison S (2000) Analysis of the complete genome sequence of black queen-cell virus, a picorna-like virus of honey bees. J Gen Virol 81: 2111–2119.

    [xxv] Maori E, Lavi S, Mozes-Koch R, Gantman Y, Peretz Y, et al. (2007) Isolation and characterization of Israeli acute paralysis virus, a dicistrovirus affecting honeybees in Israel: evidence for diversity due to intra- and inter-species recombination. J Gen Virol 88: 3428–3438.

    [xxvi] de Miranda JR, Drebot M, Tyler S, Shen M, Cameron CE, et al. (2004) Complete nucleotide sequence of Kashmir bee virus and comparison with acute bee paralysis virus. J Gen Virol 85: 2263–2270.
