story_txt:
Our IndieGoGo campaign is over now, but you can still donate to the project! Visit the Pollinator Stewardship Council Donations page to find out how.
Mark your donation for the Hive Tracking ProjectYes, bees are making this choice every day, and not by their own free will! The bees are in trouble. We want to find out why. Counting both summer and winter losses, beekeepers are losing about 50% of their colonies each year. 2014 has been particularly devastating for Midwest beekeepers. We humans are losing our field force for pollinating the fruits and vegetables we all depend on for a healthy diet.  We need to stop the downhill slide! To do that, we need to untangle the different factors that may be affecting the bees. We are focusing on evaluating the effects of pesticides, pathogens, and combinations of the two on honey bee survival.



What Is the Project?


Pesticide Research Institute (PRI) and Pollinator Stewardship Council (PSC) are working together to better understand how different stressors (pesticides, pathogens) affect bees' ability to thrive. Scientists from PRI and commercial beekeepers from PSC are working together to track 60 beehives over the course of a year and making measurements of:




Pesticide residues in pollen, wax and honey (180 different pesticides)


Pollen identification (to see what the bees are foraging on)


Pathogen levels (in collaboration with Montana State University scientists)


Varroa mite loads


Hive strength, queen performance, disease, bee mortality, and any abnormal bee behavior




We started the work in January, 2014 and have collected 4 out of 5 sample sets. We have made hive strength measurements and observations at regular intervals over the course of the year. The preliminary results are tantalizing, but definitive conclusions will require finalizing the sample analysis and then doing some serious number-crunching. We need your help to finish this project!


What We Need
We need funding to run our fourth and fifth batches of samples and help with the data analysis. At $332 per sample times 60 hives times two sample runs, it adds up fast. If we don't reach our funding goal, your help will at least make a significant contribution. 
If we exceed our fundraising goal, any extra funds will go towards running additional samples to improve the statistics, and help the Pollinator Stewardship Council, a non-profit 501(c)(3) continue its important work helping the bees.

What You Get


We have a wide variety of gifts to thank you for your generosity, from an app that will help you make good pest management decisions to a visit and presentation from one of our staff. We hope you will also feel good about helping the bees—more than ever, they need you! 




If you don't have the resources to donate now, you can still help by getting the word out. Please post this on your Facebook page and forward to your friends using the IndieGoGo share tools. We appreciate any support you can give—Thank you!



Why This Project is Important

This research will provide
documentation of the types of pesticides and pathogens commonly encountered by
commercial beekeepers in agricultural areas over the course of a year, with a
focus on agricultural locations with almonds and corn—two crops that most U.S.
bees are exposed to. The work will also provide insights into the effects of combined pesticide exposure and pathogen levels on hive health over time.  We anticipate that we can use the data in a number of ways.


At the regulatory level (US EPA), the research will provide data on which to base decision-making for pesticides to enhance pollinator protection.
For beekeepers, the study will provide a quantitative estimate of hazards posed by particular crop-pesticide combinations and will enable them, where possible, to
keep their bees away from such crops.
Growers and Regional IPM centers will be able to use the information to make pollinator-friendly choices when selecting pest control products for crops.
Knowing which factors are most closely associated with decreased colony fitness will enable everyone to focus pollinator protection efforts on the factors that are most important for improving bee health.


Why PRI and PSC?
Pesticide Research Institute is an environmental consulting company headed by Susan Kegley, a PhD chemist who has been doing environmental chemistry for 25 years, with a focus on pesticides for the last 15 years. PRI develops information tools to better understand the risks of pesticides, does sampling for pesticides in air, water, and beehives, develops risk assessment models, and works with a number of non-profits to provide scientific support for their work. PRI has donated its staff time to develop the sampling procedures, help with the field sampling work, create a database that will help us organize and understand the data, and coordinate sampling events and project communications. PRI will be responsible for doing the final data analysis.
Pollinator Stewardship Council (formerly known as the National Pollinator Defense Fund) is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization founded by commercial beekeepers to defend managed and native pollinators vital to a sustainable and affordable food supply from the adverse impact of pesticides. PSC provides beekeeper support for reporting pesticide-related bee-kills and keeps tabs on what US EPA is doing with regards to pesticide policies, contributing beekeeper voices to the decision-making process. PSC beekeepers, staff and colleagues are contributing their time and hives to the study, doing the field sampling work, and making regular hive health assessments. Coming from second, third, and fourth-generation beekeeping families, our three participating beekeepers have over 100 combined years of beekeeping experience.
The Technical Stuff
OK, we know some of you want to know more . . . to dig in a little bit and find out about the science behind our work.  So here goes . . .


Overview
Many causes for the unusually high managed honey bee colony
losses have been proposed, including pesticides, the Varroa mite, pathogens such as Nosema
and various viruses, and loss of forage due to increased corn production to
make biofuels. It is likely that an interactive combination of these stressors
is responsible for the observed colony declines. More study is needed to
determine the primary factor or mix of factors causing colony losses, with a
focus on combined effects. 
Understanding the relative contribution of the different
factors to the problem of unsustainable colony losses is paramount to solving
it, yet few studies are focused on this outcome. The PSC-PRI Hive Tracking
Project will provide unique and valuable insights into the agricultural
landscape in the U.S. and its effects on pollinators by evaluating multiple
colony stressors and their interactions in commercial managed honey bee
colonies. 
Previous work in this area has laid the groundwork for doing
this study, showing the necessity of tracking the multiple parameters that may
affect colony health. Van Englesdorp et
al. conducted a comparison of multiple stressors (pesticides, pathogens,
and parasites) on collapsed colonies vs
healthy colonies[i] at a single point in time, finding
no single factor that explained the differences. Runckel, Flenniken, et al. tracked pathogen loads for a
migratory bee operation, assessing their changes over time and correlations to
colony health, but did not measure pesticide residues.[ii], [iii] Flenniken and Andino have also studied the honey bee
antiviral immune response,[iv]
an essential piece of the puzzle for understanding potential interactions
between exposure to immune-suppressing pesticides and a colony’s ability to
combat pathogens.
To date, there has been no prospective study that tracks
temporal changes in pesticide residues, pathogen loads, and parasites in a
migratory beekeeping operation, yet there is great potential to obtain data
that will help untangle the role of multiple stressors on the bees. Ultimately,
this work will provide data to inform evidence-based decisions regarding
pesticide regulation, in order to better protect pollinators. The U.S.
regulatory system is in dire need of such data, and a major part of the
outreach efforts for dissemination of project results will focus on US EPA, USDA,
the CA Department of Pesticide Regulation, and other Departments of Agriculture
in states around the U.S. This study will provide data to document the scope
and magnitude of agrochemical levels within managed honey bee colonies in
agricultural areas—an essential first step to understanding the issue and
providing a scientific basis for any needed regulatory change. 
The Role of Pesticides
in Pollinator Declines
Current agricultural systems are reliant on chemical inputs,
many of which are toxic to bees and other pollinators and present in the
environments they frequent. Thus, agrochemicals are one factor that may
contribute to colony losses. Systemic, persistent pesticides—insecticides and
fungicides—are among the primary suspects in the recent colony losses. These
pesticides are sufficiently water soluble to be taken up through the roots
and/or leaves of plants and translocated throughout the plant, including into
the pollen and nectar on which bees feed. Their persistence ensures that the
plant retains levels of the pesticide that may be toxic to pollinators for long
periods of time—months for annual crops to years for perennial crops. 
Acute bee-kills are the most obvious form of harm caused by agrochemicals,
but lower levels of pesticide exposure can also cause a decrease in hive
strength or even colony failure by altering honey bee behaviors and impairing
the immune response. A recent study demonstrated that field level exposure to one
of the systemic neonicotinoid insecticides (imidacloprid) adversely affected
the pollen-collecting efficiency of worker bees, leading to reductions in brood
development and colony success.[v] Homing failure following
low-level thiamethoxam exposure has also been observed in field experiments
using honey bees.[vi]
Other studies have shown that honey bees exhibit reduced activity levels,[vii] short- and long-term
memory impairment,[viii],
[ix] and reduced ability
to recruit foragers by waggle dancing following pesticide exposure.[x] 
Dietary exposure to neonicotinoids has been shown to impair
the reproductive capacities of both bumble bees and solitary bees. One study
found that imidacloprid doses as low as 1 mg/L in sucrose solution
significantly reduced bumble bee brood production.[xi]
These results suggest that neonicotinoid exposure diminishes bumble bee queen
fertility; however, reduced feeding activity in neonicotinoid treated bees was
also observed, providing an alternative explanation for the diminished
fecundity rates. Bumble bee colonies foraging for six days on clover in turf
treated with a clothianidin grub-control product at label rates not only
experienced bee kills, but the surviving bees produced no queens.[xii]
Chronically exposed bumble bee colonies have also shown substantial (as high as
85 percent) reduction in the production of new queens, thus creating an
enormous barrier to colony propagation.[xiii]
Although no effects were observed on adult solitary bee mortality, sublethal
exposure to less than 3.5 mg/kg of a neonicotinoid mixture (thiamethoxam plus
clothianidin) in sugar solution decreased the nest building and brood cell
construction rates.[xiv]
Offspring production in the treatment group was reduced by almost 50 percent.
Recent work by Sandrock et
al.[xv]
indicates that neonicotinoid pesticides may also have effects on reproduction
in honey bee colonies, through effects on foraging efficiency and queen survival.
Colonies that were fed pollen containing field-realistic levels of thiamethoxam
and clothianidin (5.31 mg/kg and
2.05 mg/kg, respectively) gathered 19%
less pollen on average than control colonies (P=0.01). While both the control
and treatment groups collected similar amounts of pollen during the first three
weeks of the experimental pollen feeding, colonies exposed to thiamethoxam and
clothianidin consistently collected less pollen later on, with mean pollen
collections barely reaching more than 50% of the control group during the last
week of exposure. In this study, there was also a significant association
between neonicotinoid exposure and queen supersedure,  with six out of 10 queens in the treatment
colonies being superseded within one year of treatment, compared to zero out of
10 queens in the control colonies (P=0.01). Swarming, an event that is critical
to colony reproduction was also statistically significantly lower in
neonicotinoid-treated colonies in the spring following treatment (P=0.005). Exposure
to mixtures of pesticides in hive matrices (pollen, honey, and wax) is common,[xvi],
[xvii]
and our results to date reinforce these findings. Synergistic effects of some
pesticides have been studied,[xviii],
[xix],
[xx]
but much remains to be done to understand the toxic effects of agrochemical mixtures.
Effects on the immune system have
also been observed (see below).
The
Role of Pests and Pathogens in Pollinator Declines
The most significant CCD-associated variable characterized to date
is increased pathogen incidence.[xxi] Although greater pathogen
incidence correlates with CCD, the cause is unknown in part due to insufficient
knowledge of the pathogenic and commensal organisms associated with honey bees.[xxii]
Parasitic threats to honey bee colonies include viruses, Nosema, bacteria, and Crithidia. The majority of honey bee
infecting viruses are positive-sense single-stranded RNA viruses of the Picornavirales
order. They include acute bee paralysis virus (ABPV),[xxiii] black queen cell virus
(BQCV),[xxiv] Israeli acute bee
paralysis virus (IAPV),[xxv] Kashmir bee virus (KBV),[xxvi]  deformed wing virus (DWV),[xxvii] sacbrood virus (SBV),[xxviii] and chronic bee
paralysis virus (CBPV).[xxix], [xxx]  
Viral infections in bees can remain asymptomatic, or cause
deformities, paralysis and/or death. Symptoms associated with specific viruses
include wing deformities (DWV), hairless, dark, shiny bees (CBPV), swollen
yellow larva and/or dark-brown larva carcasses in the cells of worker-bees
(SBV) or queen-bees (BQCV). Bees frequently test positive for one or more
viruses. [xxxi],
[xxxii], [xxxiii]
In addition to viral infections, honey bees are also readily
parasitized by the microsporidia Nosema. [xxxiv], [xxxv] Historically U.S. honey bees were
predominantly infected by Nosema apis,
but recently Nosema ceranae
infections dominate. [xxxvi],
[xxxvii] The effects of Nosema infection on individual bee and
colony health are unclear. [xxxviii],[xxxix] Some reports suggest infections
decrease longevity and may lead to collapse,[xl], [xli],[xlii] but since Nosema is widespread and often detected
in healthy colonies, its role in colony health requires further investigation. [xliii], [xliv],[xlv] Another fungal
pathogen Ascophaera apis, the
causative agent of Chalkbrood disease, kills infected larvae, but does not
typically cause colony loss.[xlvi], [xlvii] Bacterial pathogens of
honey bees include Paenibacillus
larvae and Melissococcus plutonius,
the causative agents of American and European Foulbrood disease.[xlviii], [xlix], [l], [li]
Mite infestations (Ararapis
woodi, Tropilaelaps sp., and Varroa destructor) are
also common, weakening honey bee colonies.[lii], [liii] Introduction of V. destructor mites, which feed on the
hemolymph of developing honey bees and transmit viruses (DWV, KBV, IAPV), in
the late 1980s was devastating to the U.S. honey bee population.[liv], [lv], [lvi] Notably, the restricted
genetic diversity of the U.S. honey bee population may make it particularly
susceptible to catastrophic and episodic losses.[lvii], [lviii]
How Pesticides and
Pathogens Interact
A functional immune system is critical for honey bee survival,
but exposure to certain pesticides may impair bee immunity and result in
increased vulnerability to pathogens. Several insecticides[lix],[lx], [lxi]  and fungicides[lxii] have been found to
weaken the immune response in honey bees. This is particularly devastating to
colonies when Varroa mites are
present, since they transmit pathogens from bee to bee. A recent study examined
the molecular biology responsible for this impaired immune response and found
that exposure to the systemic insecticides imidacloprid and clothianidin
resulted in impaired immune signaling involved in antiviral responses.[lxiii] 

Learning more about these interactions is critical to solving
the problems of unsustainable colony losses. This project will contribute to our
understanding of the science, and provide insights into pollinator-protective solutions.
Data Analysis
1) Principal Component
Analysis: PRI will utilize Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and regression tree analysis to conduct a
multivariate exploratory data analysis of hive strength and survival as a
function of the following variables:



Concentration of each pesticide and combinations
of pesticides. In particular, we will evaluate combinations of pesticides known
to interact synergistically to enhance overall toxicity, such as the Ergosterol
Biosynthesis Inhibitor (EBI) fungicides in the presence of certain
insecticides.


Presence/absence of pathogens and combinations
of pathogen loads with pesticide residues.


Total load of pesticides according to mechanism
of action, to enable visualization of trends that may be related to synergism,
and/or induced metabolic changes that may disable detoxification pathways.


We will evaluate which of the measured parameters or
combination of parameters are most highly correlated with colony success or
failure. 
2) Lethality Loading: In
order to more fully understand the effects of mixtures of agrochemicals on
honey bee colonies, we will assess what we call the Lethality Loading of the
pollen, in terms of oral LD50 equivalents detected in the colony,
based on typical pollen consumption for a nurse bee. This builds on Stoner and
Eitzer’s use of Pollen Hazard Quotients[lxiv] to evaluate pesticide
residues in pollen, but takes the analysis a step further to account for all
residues present in the hive. For pesticides for which oral LD50
values are not available, we will use contact LD50 values. Where data
are available, we will account for changes in the LD50 values due to
synergistic effects, as per the method described by Sanchez-Bayo.[lxv]
3) Comparison to
predicted colony growth: Because the population of a colony is not static,
colony strength on a specific date will be compared to predicted strengths
based on population models. Several models of varying levels of sophistication
and data input needs have been developed and are summarized by Becher et al.[lxvi]
including BEEPOP and derivatives thereof,[lxvii], [lxviii] the BEEHAVE
model,[lxix] HoPoMo,[lxx] and the Khoury model.[lxxi] We will evaluate the suitability
of the available bee population models for our particular data set and utilize
one or more of them to compare the observed changes in colony strength to that predicted
by the model.
4) Comparison of
pesticide use during almond bloom across counties: We will use the
California Pesticide Use Reporting (PUR) data to evaluate historic agrochemical
use during the almond bloom, to evaluate cross-county differences in pest
management approaches, as an informational tool for growers.



[i]
vanEngelsdorp D, Evans JD, Saegerman C, Mullin C, Haubruge E, Nguyen BK, et al.
2009. Colony Collapse Disorder: A Descriptive Study. J. Browned. PLoS ONE
4:e6481; doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0006481.



[ii]
Runckel C, Flenniken ML, Engel JC, Ruby JG, Ganem D, Andino R, et al. 2011.
Temporal Analysis of the Honey Bee Microbiome Reveals Four Novel Viruses and
Seasonal Prevalence of Known Viruses, Nosema, and Crithidia. R.F.A. Moritzed.
PLoS ONE 6:e20656; doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0020656.



[iii]
Flenniken ML, Kunitomi M,
Tassetto M, and Andino R. 2010.
Insect Antiviral Defense; the Antiviral Role of RNA Interference. In Insect
Virology, Asgari, S. and Johnson, K. (eds.), (Norwich, UK: Horizon
Scientific Press).



[iv]
Flenniken ML and Andino R, 2013.Non-specific dsRNA-Mediated Innate Immune Response in the Honey Bee. PLoS ONE 8(10): e77263.



[v]
Gill RJ, Ramos-Rodriguez O, Raine NE.
2012. Combined pesticide exposure severely affects individual- and colony-level
traits in bees. Nature 491: 105–108; doi:10.1038/nature11585



[vi]
Henry M, Beguin M, Requier F, Rollin O, Odoux J-F, Aupinel P, et al. 2012. A
Common Pesticide Decreases Foraging Success and Survival in Honey Bees. Science
336: 348–350; doi:10.1126/science.1215039



[vii]
Medrzycki P, Montanari R, Bortolotti L,
Sabatini AG, Maini S, Porrini C. 2003. Effects of imidacloprid administered in
sub-lethal doses on honey bee behaviour. Laboratory tests. Bulletin of
